Following up her album "21" which sold over 30 million copies worldwide, it's more of what we've come to expect from Ms. Adkins which should please most, and infuriate those willing her to experiment. But why should she when it's worked so well so far, and when what we have is this good?Lead single and opening cut "Hello" is a haunting piano ballad building to a bombastic chorus, her vocals a force to be reckoned with - effortless or explosive as the need arises with some soulful raspiness. There's more where that came from; the heartfelt "When We Were Young" (which finds her singing "You look like a movie, you sound like a song... My God, this reminds me of when we were young"), the spare and resonant piano ballad "Remedy", the enchanting and theatrical "Love In The Dark", the incredibly stunning Chanson-tinged guitar ballad "Million Years Ago" ("I miss when life was a party to be thrown, but that was a million years ago" - my favorite), the yearning "All I Ask", and the ode to her 3 year old son Angelo "Sweetest Devotion" ("There is something in your living that tears down my walls" she sings to a bluesy groove).The Max Martin-produced "Send My Love (To your New Lover)" has a playful pop lilt. "Treat me soft but touch me cruel, I want to teach you things you never knew" she sings to a staccato of skittery beats and whisps of Gregorian chants on "I Miss You". The haunting gospel-tinged "River Lea" is co-written and produced by Brian "Danger Mouse" Burton, the most out there offering on this collection but in an understated way, and lyrics touching on her Tottenham roots. "When I was a child, I grew up by the River Lea, there was something in the water, and now that something's in me" she sings.Lyrically, we find her embracing growth and adulthood, with some fleeting glances behind. Musically, she eschews current trends and does her own thing. I did mention she's on the cusp of musical history. "Hello" is the first single to sell over a million downloads in a week in the US, while the album is expected to shift over 2 million in a week. It might not be groundbreaking, but she's sure to move the earth with this. Beautiful.

For album number 5, Editors self-produce and largely ditch the guitars for a dark electro sound. Opening cut "No Harm" perfectly encapsulates this, stark swirling synths which gradually build and lead singer Tom Smith's vocals flitting from baritone to falsetto and back. Very Bowie meets Depeche Mode."Ocean Of Night" is a brooding ballad featuring Slowdive's Rachel Goswell adding some ethereal harmonies (she appears again on the similar guitar-sprinkled "The Law"), followed by the even gloomier (but still melodic) "Forgiveness".Upping the tempo is the catchy eighties-sounding indie pop "Life Is A Fear" (with Bowie-sounding vocals) much like a ray of sunlight after all that darkness, while the falsetto-sung hypnotic synth-pop of "Our Love" takes another leaf from Depeche Mode as well as Bronski Beat. "Don't stop believing" they repeat in the songs piano-sprinkled coda. The stomping "All The Kings" is fittingly triumphant in feel with a tender piano coda ("Send me to Venus, send me to Mars"). Closing is the hymnal "Marching Orders" which slowly builds, falls back, then levels off.This isn't a commercial collection, but repeated play reveals its beauty. Fans of the band's earlier sound may frown as there isn't any "Munich" or "Smokers Outside The Hospital Doors", but those willing to allow the band spread their wings should enjoy the ride.

Birmingham producer Joe Flory is Amateur Best and his new album "The Gleaners" comprises harrowing fluttery electro soul grooves. Vocally, he recalls Seal or Gruff Rhys of Super Furry Animals, while sonically the album has a late night club feel.Opening is the gloomy ballad "Rely" which finds him crooning "Cool cats love attack, stab yourself right in the back, I was never catching, I was always falling with you" against haunting synths. It contrasts sharply with bouncy songs like "Marzipan" which sounds as sweet as its name suggests ("You shouldn't worry about your figure, you should worry about your soul" he sings to dizzying synths and club beats), or "They Know" which rides on clipped beats, alternating between somber verses and euphoric bursts.He lets the electronics shine on the upbeat cascading instrumental "Part Timer", and the gloomy tempo-shifting "Night Shifter" (with beats and his melancholic vocals ebbing in halfway through the song), while the tender ballad "Hey Darlin'" has lovely Beach Boys-style harmonies and a bridge that sounds other-worldly.Closing is "No Sleep", the album highlight, a soulful synth ballad with warbled effects and a shiny undulating tempo.A serene, yet interesting experience from start to finish. Fans of everyone from James Blake to Jamie XX to Hot Chip will love this.

"Unbreakable" is Janet Jackson's first album in 7 years and finds back with Jam and Lewis who produced most of her hit-filled career from "Control" to "20 Y.O." It more than lives up to expectations as we get back the fun Janet who made us dance as well as pensive Janet making us think.The retro neo soul title track opens the album and finds Janet in a reflective mood telling us "Anytime I get lost in the world, you'll always be there". The groovy electro dance number "BURNITUP!" features Missy Elliott getting Janet and everyone hyped up, and showcases Janet's duskier sounding vocals. "Dammn Baby" is a funky midtempo number and is absolutely brilliant. The gently swinging electro "The Great Forever" takes the tempo down with Janet sounding very much like brother Michael as she pleads "Hate will only divide"."Shoulda Known Better" builds from a hush to anthemic pop/EDM and back as Janet takes a look at the state of the world and borrowing some of Michael's vocal tics, as well as name checking her "Rhythm Nation". "When you're young, you feel like I can change the world... and then you look 25 years later and you go; Okay, I should have known better" she explains in an interview. "After You Fall" is a tender piano ballad with tremulous affecting vocals and lovely guitar solo that should please fans of "Again". "Night" is a magical club number with heavenly harmonies, jazzy piano and sprinklings of guitar. Lead-single the laid back "No Sleeep" features J. Cole and recalls "That's The Way Love Goes". "Dream Maker / Euphoria" is a trippy soul ballad with shades of Shuggie Otis. "Take Me Away" is shimmery dance/pop with a squealing guitar coda. "Black Eagle " is a finger snap-driven ballad with lyrics about resilience; "You'll never know, unless you've been there" she croons. "I've come a long way, got a long way to go" she sings on the hymnal "Well Traveled", while closing the album is "Gon' Be Alright", a raucous jam with Janet vocally recalling Diana Ross in parts (and singing in different voices in other parts) as she sings to a horn-laced Motown-style bounce.The album is sonically diverse and Janet thankfully does away the with overtly sexual lyrics of her recent past (you know, songs like "Warmth", "Moist" or "Love Scene"). "Unbreakable" is a solid work, I daresay her best since "Velvet Rope", and it's great to have Janet back showing how it's done. "Hello, it's been a while, lots to talk about, I'm glad you're still here, I hope you enjoy" she says after the title track fades, and we sure do enjoy it.

"Love + War" is UK soul singer Kwabs' debut, and his sound can best be described as brooding synth soul with a touch of jazz and dance. It also helps that he has an incredibly beautiful smoky and sonorous voice.The mournful title track opens the album with a gospel-style chorus joining in towards the end. "Save yourself while you can" he pleads. "Fight For Love" is left-of-centre, starting off beguilingly in a soul direction then veering into clubby territory."Perfect Ruin" is a somber piano ballad with barely there percussion and hushed strings, "Forgiven" sounds like blues and a black spiritual simultaneously, while  "Layback" is jazzy Neo soul.Upping the tempo is the groovy "Make You Mine" reminiscent of The Weeknd's smash "Can't Feel My Face" with a euphoric gospel-tinged chorus and a retro feel. "Father Figure" isn't the George Michael hit but a hymnal ballad, as is the heartfelt "Cheating On Me". "I don't want to be your leader, I don't want to let you down" he sings on "Wrong Or Right" as synths stab and cascade over electro beats.A soulful delight.

UK band New Order return with their 10th album and first since 2005. Fans of the band will be enamoured with "Music Complete" comprising lengthy pieces with extensive instrumentation, the band back at their best.Shimmery synth pop rocker "Restless" opens the album with lead vocalist Bernard Sumner's laid back vocals and spidery guitar riffs, it recalls "Regret". "Singularity", "Academic" and "The Game" are similar and just as maddeningly catchy with a touch of melancholy.Elly Jackson of La Roux appears on a trio of songs, the very Giorgio Moroder-ish "Plastic" (which recalls Donna Summer's "I Feel Love"), the chugging Eurodisco "Tutti Frutti", and "People On The High Line" (with funky Nile Rodgers-style guitars.The dark atmospheric "Stray Dog" features a growled narration by Iggy Pop, while "Unlearn This Hatred" is the only surrender to contemporary dance sounds before morphing to shimmery rock. Closing is "Superheated" featuring Brandon Flowers and recalling A-Ha's "Take On Me", shiny and bouncy. "Sometimes I wake up, and the sky is red, when you're not here, by my side" go the forlorn lyrics. Great to have them back, and on form.

Jack White returns with his other side group Dead Weather, and "Dodge and Burn" is their third album.The squealing bluesy "I Feel Love (Every Million Miles)" opens the album with pulsing synths and Alison Mosshart on vocal duty. White appears against a wall of wailing and squealing guitars on the oddball tempo-shifting "Three Dollar Hat" speaking/rapping lines like "Johnny said, Jackie, dont take my life, I got three young kids and a badass wife"With Mosshart handling the more frenetic break. Very White Stripes."Lose The Right" is a reggae-tinged rocker with Mosshart on vocals, while "Rough Detective" is an exchange between White and Mosshart, an interrogation of sorts. "Be Still" is dark alternating between calm and explosive bursts with both again sharing vocals. "Mile Markers" finds Mosshart turning in a spoken delivery over playful beats and buzzing guitars.Other standouts are the slinky groovy "Cop And Go", the gritty quivery "Too Bad", and closing cut  "Impossible Winner", a piano/string ballad with a theatrical bent, very much a curveball coming on the heels of all the blistering rockers.

UK dance duo Disclosure are back with their sophomore album "Caracal". Like its predecessor "Settle" it features a plethora of guest vocalists and a welcome variety of sounds.The Weeknd appears on opening late night club number, the aptly titled "Nocturnal". Sam Smith who appeared on their top 10 hit "Latch" returns on "Omen" singing "Oh oh oh omen" and more in a nasal falsetto, while the house anthem "Holding On" features jazz musician Gregory Porter."Hourglass" features Lion Babe starting off minimalist with instrumentation building in. The haunting "Willing & Able" takes the tempo down and features soul crooner Kwabs on something that wouldn't sound out of place on his album. A sultry Lorde appears on the moody soulful "Magnets". "Let's embrace the point of no return" she pleads.Everything stands out really, from the dark clubby "Jaded", the spare hypnotic "Good Intentions" featuring Miguel, the woozy "Superego" featuring London songstress Nao, the skittery bounce of "Echoes", the slow burning D'Angelo-style "Masterpiece" featuring the soulful Jordan Rakei, the late night groove "Molecules", the trippy ballad "Moving Mountains", and the hushed pulsing Jamie XX-style "Afterthought" which is anything but.Another winner!

The Microsoft Arc Mouse is stylish and ergonomically perfect, fits my hand just right. Smooth movement and precise response/selection with no lag, it uses 2 AAA batteries. The mouse folds away for storage (and to switch off), with the micro-transceiver tucked beneath magnetically.It has left and right click buttons and scroll wheel (the wheel can be customised), and a left side button (for browser back). Can be used on pretty much any surface (even a mirrored one).My only peeve is that the micro-transceiver is larger than average. Other than that, just about perfect for me.

My Philips Shoqbox Bluetooth speakers packed up after two and a half years of use so I looked out for a replacement. I travel a lot and like to have all my music with me always so portable speakers are a must for me.I saw the Harman Kardon Esquire Mini in a store and fell in love with it, tested it and was pleased with the sound.It is tiny, small enough to put in ones pocket. The design is stylish, eye catching and sturdy with a leather back and lanyard, steel edges, and either a black, silver, gold, or brown top.On top is a power button (a white light comes on when powered with a beep), a Bluetooth button (light turns cobalt blue when Bluetooth is in use with a series of beeps), a phone button (to take phone calls), and volume control.Left has 5 lights which show charge (it takes about 3 hours to charge fully and a charge lasts for about 8 hours), and the microphone. The right has 3.5mm audio jack (for non-Bluetooth devices), the charging port, and a USB port (to which you can connect your phone or iPod to charge).At the rear is a kick stand which can be pushed out. Connecting to Bluetooth is a breeze, turn on the Bluetooth, search for speakers on your phone/iPod, pair, and you're good to go. Unlike other speakers I have used, the speakers always remember my device(s) so no need to keep pairing. The connection is strong and steady.Now, onto sound. For such a small fellah, it packs a big punch. Clear and sharp, pianos, guitars and horns sound almost live. I've played different genres from Dance to Funk to Acoustic to Rock to Jazz and I like the sound. It could go with a bit more bass though. To counter this, I change my phone/iPod equaliser settings to Dance or Bass boost. Also, placing it on a solid surface, in a corner, or against a wall helps to bounce and improve the acoustics.The speakers do show up the defects in low quality music files, with a discernible hiss and some distortion. There is also some distortion at high volume, so best to keep it moderate. It's definitely no replacement for a powerful home stereo.Perfect for the office (my workmates never want me to take it home), hotel room, bedroom, and anywhere else one may go.

UK trio Years & Years won the BBC's Sound of...2015 award (past winners include Adele, 50 Cent, Ellie Goulding, and Sam Smith) and big things are expected of them. "Communion" is their debut album and is moody synth pop with an R&B feel. Lead vocalist Olly Alexander's soulful croon recalls Nina Simone on the mournful percussion-free "Foundation" which starts off stark till swirling synths and harrowing harmonies creep in. An absolutely fantastic way to open the album. Aptly titled, it sets the foundation for the album; think James Blake meets The Weeknd. "Real" is house music driven by claps/finger snaps with a brooding feel, while the sublime "Shine" explodes into exuberance in the chorus.Everything is brilliant really, the gently bouncy "Take Shelter" with jabbing bass and dreamy harmonies, the lightly thundering "Worship", the piano/finger snap-driven ballad "Eyes Shut", the gently pulsing "Ties", the upbeat irresistible UK #1 "King", the incredibly groovy "Desire", the wispy beauty of "Gold" (which builds to a euphoric chorus), the synth ballad "Without" ("You don't belong to me, you're too far away, everything falls apart, when I try to say you're in love, in love, without me") the skittery groove "Border", and the gospel/R&B-tinged ballad "Memo".The deluxe edition features the exceptional R&B ballad "1977", the piano ballad "Ready For You", the elemental house groove "I Want To Love", and a piano ballad version of "King" proving that shorn of all electronic flourishes, it's still a great song. An outstanding debut.

Bilal's fourth release "In Another Life" continues the prolific spurt he's experienced since 2010. It is More of what we've come to expect from the Neo soul singer, which is the unexpected. Vocally, he darts from a fragile croon to falsetto to yelp, depending on the mood.He turns in a haunting vocal to match the spectral sound of "Star Now", while "Open Up The Door" has a Stevie Wonder feel; "It's a long cold winter, but when it rains we grow" he sings to the light Cuban-tinged bounce. "Pleasure Toy" features Big K.R.I.T has electro beats with Bilal channeling Prince in parts, while "Lunatic" is an abrasive groove with smidgens of rock guitar and yelping Prince-style vocals."Money Over Lover" is a retro "Shaft" groove featuring spit-fire verses from Kendrick Lamar right after a sudden break. "Love Child" isn't The Supremes classic but a trippy blissed out ballad, as is "Holding It Back" which features Kimbra perfectly blending in. The horn-flecked "Spiralling" is breezy soul with skittery beats, while "Bury Me Next To You" takes the tempo down even further to a bluesy trot.Produced by Adrian Younge, a perfect match to Bilal's uncompromising style, the album has a live jazzy limber feel, as though recorded in a single take. Along with D'Angelo, Lamar, and Miguel, Bilal is flying the soul flag real high.

R&B singer Miguel is a supremely talented singer who should be bigger than he is, much like Janelle Mone. Fittingly, he appeared on her last album "Electric Lady", while his last album "Kaleidoscope Dream" peaked at #3 on the Billboard charts and won a Grammy for the million-selling single "Adorn".His new album "Wildheart" should see him continue on the upward trajectory his career has been taking. It's more of his Soul/Funk/Rock/Electronica sound, you know, that hazy reverb-filled sound juxtaposing ragged guitars and heavenly harmonies. There's a heavier rock influence on songs like the woozy "A Beautiful Exit", the gently galloping yet gritty "Waves", the funky "Hollywood Dreams", the spare echoey "Leaves", and the tender "Face The Sun" which builds and builds and features Lenny Kravitz serving up a squealing guitar solo.The upbeat "Deal" is a retro groove with a deceptively downbeat intro, a live party feel, and a slowed-down coda, while the trippy electro "The Valley" drips lascivious lyrics (as does much of the album really). Lead single "Coffee" is a dreamy pulsing affair with the line "I wish I could paint our love, these moments and violet hues", while "NWA" features Kurupt and a falsetto-singing Miguel channeling his inner Marvin Gaye. "...goingtohell" alternates between garage rock and woozy R&B, "Flesh" is a smouldering slow jam that wouldn't be out of place on the "Fifty Shades Of Grey" soundtrack, while "Destinado a morir (enter.lewd)" is a moody interlude.Highlight has got to be the questioning confessional "What's Normal Anyway" which finds him singing "Too proper for the black kids, too black for the Mexicans... In a crowd and I feel alone, I never feel like I belong" against clipped beats, acoustic guitar and cascading spectral harmonies.The deluxe edition features 4 additional tracks, the ominous hip hop-laced "Gfg", "Destinado a morir" (which gets stretched out into an ominous ballad), the moody "Simple Things", and the thundering rock-driven "Damned".What an exciting piece this is, treading the path led by artists like D'Angelo, Stevie Wonder and Prince. "Wildheart" is a genre blurring classic.

British indie band Everything Everything burst into the scene in 2010 with their quirky and eclectic sound.Album number three "Get To Heaven" is no different, opening almost acapella on "The Blade" before bursting into life and making several angular detours. Lead vocalist Jonathan Higgs sounds brilliant, deftly moving from falsetto to a yelp at the blink of an eye. "Distant Past" is a funky rocker with spoken/sung lyrics and skittery beats, followed by the even groovier "Get To Heaven" with a whistle refrain and exotic guitar sounds.The album is laden with catchy danceable tunes, produced by Stuart Price, they sound like Duran Duran meets Radiohead. Inspired by shootings, ISIS and other current world affairs, the dark cryptic lyrics contrast the bright melodies. The retro "Regret" recalls Edwyn Collins. The galloping "Spring/Summer/Winter" finds them declaring that they "don't want to get older", "Fortune 500' is a gently pulsing number with twitchy guitar effects. "I've won I've won they told me that I've won" goes the echoey refrain, while the nervy sounding "Blast Doors" has the line "I can smell your fingerprints all over my computer, you can fire a rocket, it's the future"."No Reptiles" is spatial with haunting synths and keys with an insistent thump and the menacing line "I'm going to kill a stranger", while pleasantly discordant almost jazz/funk "Warm Healer" closes the album.The deluxe edition has 6 extra songs, the charming ballad "We Sleep In Pairs", the skeletal groovy "Hapsburg Lippp", the Duran Duran-aping "President Heartbeat", the choppy groovy "Brainchild", the pulsing glitchy instrumental "Yuppie Supper", and the jerky rocker "Only As Good As My God". All are vital.Like their name goes, they throw everything but the kitchen sink into their sound. Chameleonic rock of the first degree.

Leon Bridges is 25 and grew up listening to Usher and Ginuwine, but you wouldn't know it listening to his debut "Coming Home" which sounds like it was recorded in the fifties or sixties. His simple organic soul/blues/gospel sound recalls Marvin Gaye, Otis Redding and Sam Cooke with references to New Orleans and The Mississippi.Concise at 10 tracks, his smoky world weary vocals shine on every track, from the bluesy title track, the Doo-wop-laced "Better Man" which finds him declaring that he loves her "Better than all those Jezebels lurking under perfumed sheets", while "Brown Skin Girl" is a horn-peppered slowly swinging piece.Upping the tempo are the bouncy "Smooth Sailin'" and "Flowers", while "Shine" is an organ-driven blues/hymnal ballad. Highlight has got to be the autobiographical "Lisa Sawyer", an ode to his mother set to a strolling pace and soothing harmonies (of "Pa pa doos"). Closing is the acoustic tambourine-garnished gospel-tinged ballad "River" with a lovely bridge which finds him harmonising with some haunting female vocals.Produced by Austin Jenkins and Joshua Block of indie rock band White Denim, the album was recorded on vintage analogue equipment virtually live. Right from the retro cover art to the throwback sound, this sounds like a lost classic rediscovered. Leon Bridges is the real deal.

"The Bright Side" is Australian singer/songwriter Lenka's fourth album. Concise at 10 tracks, the tone of the album is sunny and optimistic.The uplifting gently swinging "The Long Way Home" opens the album comprising mainly piano, horns and percussion. "Blue Skies" is more dense, electropop laden with pulsing and shimmery synths and a melancholic mien. "Free" is rhythmic and bouncy, sprinkled with hand claps. "I like to move around to a different beat... I don't really mind what you all think" she sings on the sunny folky "Unique" and that's just what she sets out to do on this album.The sugary sweet "Get Together" sets a xylophone and ukulele to the bouncy beat, while the enchanting "Go Deeper" is a moody synth R&B-ish ballad with wispy vocals, as is the similar "Hearts Brighter". "We are invincible, we are unique, we are incredible, we are free" she sings on the whistle-driven "We Are Powerful". "My Love" is a bouncy singalong affair, as is the retro-sounding closing cut "The Bright Side" with an a capella coda.Pop music all bright and shiny.

"Alternative Light Source" is British Electronica act Leftfield's third album and first in 16 years. Now down to one man, Neil Barnes, the album comprises 10 tracks featuring guest vocalists.Tunde Adebimpe from TV On The Radio gives a spoken/sung delivery on track 1 "Bad Radio", a buzzing intense aural assault. The pummelling "Universal Everything" embellishes vocal samples of Georgia Barnes. "Bilocation" features Channy Leaneagh from synthpop band Polia, shimmery with an electro bounce. She appears again on the swirling hypnotic "Little Fish".Seaford Mods vocalist Jason Williamson features on "Head And Shoulders", his very English delivery atop the wobbly bass and funky guitars. "Levitate For You" features Ofei, a brooding piece with haunting synths sweeping in and out dramatically.Everything else is instrumental; the gentle "Dark Matter" which ebbs and shimmers beautifully, the soothing "Storms End", the cinematic acoustic-laced title track, and the upbeat discordant yet satisfying "Shaker Obsession".Good to have him/them back.

It's hard to believe it's been 8 years since UK singer Mika made his technicolor debut with his fun piano pop sound. "No Place In Heaven" is his fourth album and opens with the piano-driven disco-tinged "Talk About You". "All She Wants" is a bouncy clap-filled Beatles-meets-Beach Boys affair."Good Guys" is a lovely ballad which appears again on the deluxe edition as the "Night Time Mix", a groovier fuller sound, while the title track is a lilting folky song. "Staring At The Sun" isn't the U2 hit but a gently pulsing pop number on which he declares "my love is blind from staring at the sun".For the most part, Mika has capped his hyperactive vocals and turns in a calm, almost lifeless delivery. The pretty "Hurts" is a spare piano ballad, while the tender piano ballad "Ordinary Man" with the line "spent the day playing Nina Simone, reorganised every record I own" recalls Elton John in his seventies hey day. Absolutely enchanting!Other tracks on the deluxe edition are the glam pop/rock "Promiseland", the falsetto-sung trippy synth ballad "Porcelain", and the catchy string-swathed disco "L'amour Fait Ce Qu'il Veit" sung in French and co-penned by Pharrell Williams. To be honest, the bonus tracks are much better than most of the album, injecting much needed life and fun. I'm a big fan of Mika and I hate to have to give this 3 and a half stars.

"Lantern" is Scottish electronic act Hudson Mohawke's sophomore album. He's one half of the duo TNGHT and has also worked with Drake and Kanye West.His album is an eclectic mix with guests from different genres yet still giving a cohesive sound. The general sound is wispy and light on bass. The hip hop-laced "Very First Breath" features Irfane, while "Ryderz" incorporates sped up soul samples sounding vintage, much like early Kanye West.The mellow soulful "Warriors" features Ruckazoid and Devauex and an uplifting choir chorus. The moody "Indian Steps" features Antony Hegarty's mournful croon. Miguel features on the ghostly apparition that is "Deepspace" singing lines like "All my anger spilling over pavement, please don't go" against faintly wailing guitars, while Jhen Aiko appears on the floaty soul "Resistance" with soft skittery beats.Everything else is instrumental, highlights being the tinkling and cinematic "Kettles", the tinkling Oriental-tinged "Lil Djembe", "System" which starts off widescreen before pounding beats take over, and the constantly morphing "Brand New World".This fittingly titled Lantern leaves an incandescent glow on the dancefloor.

Indie band Fun. don't do subtle, and lead singer Nate Ruess' solo debut "Grand Romantic" is more of the same, comprising grandiose Queen-sounding ballads. His love for bombast recalls Killers' frontman Brandon Flowers.The brief choral "Grand Romantic (Intro)" leads to the theatrical "AhHa" with thundering martial beats, while lead-single "Nothing Without Love" finds Ruess belting his heart and lungs out to the triumphant tune.Things get more tender on the retro sounding "Take A Bow' which features Wilco's Jeff Tweedy on guitar, while "You Light My Fire" starts off sounding somewhat like Beyonc's "Single Ladies", but it's a bouncy pop song. "What The World Is Coming To" features Beck and is a folky song recalling John Lennon.Everything stands out really, the big catchy "Great Big Storm", the piano ballad "Moment" ("I'm fine, I just need a moment to cry"), the Elton John-style piano heartbreak ballad "It Only Gets Much Worse" (my favourite), the freeform hymnal title track (with Ruess hitting some big and high notes, it also incorporates the chorale flourishes of the intro into its coda), the cinematic "Harsh Light", and closing cut "Brightside", a charming piano ballad adorned with soft strings and "La la las" (another favourite of mine).Nate Ruess' solo debut is fun.

"The Way" is Macy Gray's 8th album, coming on the heels of a pair of cover albums in 2012; the delightful eclectic "Covered" and the Stevie Wonder tribute "Talking Book". Her latest is more of her brand of kooky Soul with her distinctive raspy delivery unchanged by time. Featuring several producers on ten tracks, the sound is cohesive, from opening moody "Stoned" (with hand-tapped percussion), the Bluesy "Bang Bang" with an abrasive riff and gangster video, to the uplifting "Hands" (with lovely harmonies), everything fits like a glove."I Miss The Sex" is an interesting experiment, an African-ish groove with a Jazzy lilt. The string-swept ballad "The First Time" is co-written by Booker T. Jones (who produced Bill Whithers' "Ain't No Sunshine") and sounds like a classic. "Hey baby, I've called to say I gave up that narcotic" she sings on the lilting title track "The Way". "Queen Of The Big Hurt" is reminiscent of earlier songs like "I Try" or "Still". Album highlight "Me With You" appeared online in a soulful incarnation a few years ago. Here, it gets a sublime Disco makeover with a haunting feel. Brilliant.Closing are the acoustic "Need You Now", and "Life" which finds her declaring "Life is beautiful" over rattling percussion. It's a real shame Gray doesn't have the success her unique sound and hard work deserves. This is a good album.

Flying Lotus's new album "You're Dead" is more of his futuristic Jazz/Hip Hop/Electronica sound. Horns traipsing across skittery beats, sudden bursts of guitar, and other-worldly bleeps, it's a free-for-all jamfest.The first four tracks are brief and fly past fast sounding like different movements of a single piece. "Never Catch Me" is a trippy piece with Kendrick Lamar. "Dead Man's Tetris" features vocals by Flying Lotus (as Captain Murphy) and Snoop Dogg. "Turkey Dog Coma" is a shimmery tempo-shifting piece. "Siren Song" features Angel Deradoorian's vocals against a quivery backdrop. The brief "Descent Into Madness" features Thundercat. Captain Murphy appears again on "The Boys Who Died In Their Sleep". The shimmery "The Potential/The Beyond" features Niki Randa (with her voice sounding like a cascading waterfall), while Kimbra features on closing cut "The Protest".The only other album I've heard this year that's in a similar vein is Taylor Mcferrin's "Early Riser". Just amazing.

31 year old Kat Edmonson is a one time American Idol contestant. Rather than go for big showy songs and belting, she goes for a more intimate sound similar to Norah Jones', Jazzy Folk with a touch of Country. A fan on classic black and white movies, she tries to make her music a sonic equivalent.She co-wrote 11 of the dozen tracks, and her nuanced nasal delivery perfectly suits the songs. Highlights include opening cut the gorgeous "Rainy Day Woman" (drenched in theatrical strings and sprinkled with horns), the slinky Bossa Nova "You Said Enough", the tender acoustic Bluesy "Oh My Love" (which finds her singing in a smoky lower register - absolutely brilliant), "Crying" (with lovely harmonies), the elegiac "Till We Start To Kiss", the playful cabaret Pop "The Best" (with Jazzy scatting), the quivery Country-tinged "Dark Cloud" ("They settled it up in Heaven, now I'm just waiting on you"), and closing cut the Country ballad "Who's Counting".My favourite though is "You Can't Break My Heart" (the one song she didn't have a hand in writing), delicately plucked guitar, magnificent strings, and barely there percussion, and a quivery guitar solo, it wouldn't sound out of place on a spaghetti western - incredibly beautiful!

The announcement "Welcome home class, you've come a long way" opens Prince's new album "Art Official Age" leading into a four to the floor propulsive track titled "Art Official Cage" garnished with choral flourishes, a Dubstep breakdown, and a rap.As with most recent Prince releases, this will divide some who will compare it to his eighties classics. While not quite up there with those classics, this has its moments if one gives it a chance. It's a concept album of sorts finding Prince awakening sometime in the future after being in suspended animation, with UK Soul songstress Lianne La Havas's sensual voice guiding him on what to expect in the new society in a series of string/piano "Affirmations"."Clouds" is an incredibly funky midtempo electro groove with a Jazzy lilt ("You should never underestimate the power of a kiss on the neck which she doesn't expect" - it also features Lianne La Havas), the incredible ballad "Breakdown" which starts off with a soft falsetto croon leading to a screeching/yelping climax. The horn-punctuated "Gold Standard" has a retro feel, while the floaty "U Know" (punctuated with "Uh-huh uh-huh" said by some female) shows he's aware of the Frank Oceans, Weeknds and Miguels.Other highlights are the moody "Breakfast Can Wait", the beautiful semi-biographical ballad "Way Back Home", and the skeletal Hip Hop-tinged groove "Funknroll" which races frantically towards the end with Camille on vocals.There is much to love here, and the album grows on you the more you listen to it. In my opinion, Prince's best album since "3121".

"I Need Church" is a blistering rocker with stomping beats and sawing guitars, that is until The Eminem-esque vocals come in and you realise it's Professor Green. "Growing Up In Public", his 3rd album, comprises 10 tracks, getting straight to the point.The pensive "Lullaby" featuring an angelic Tori Kelly looks at his battle with depression. "I don't want to do what my dad did with a rope" he raps recalling his Dad's suicide. It reminds me a wee bit of Diddy's "Coming Home". Not everything is weighty though. He takes aim at The Script's Danny O'Donoghue and Robbie Williams in the afore mentioned "I Need Church" (even appending an irate voice mail from Williams at the songs end), includes the line "Millie I'm gonna be with you forever, or until the day that we divorce and I get taken to the cleaners, probably for  getting caught fondling the clean...er" in "Dean Man Shoes" (Millie being his new bride), and takes a look at his arrest for drunk driving in the bouncy title track. "Little Secrets" features a creamy sounding Mr. Probz, while the bouncy "Name In Lights" featuring Rizzle Kicks recalls The Streets. Slowing things down is "Fast Life", a look at his past hedonistic living, a thing of the past now he's settled down."Can't Dance Without You" is Drum & bass with juddering bass and featuring Whinnie Williams. Highlight has got to be "Not Your Man" with an acoustic intro and a heartbroken soulful delivery from Thabo.

UK Indie band Alt-J's debut "An Awesome Wave" won the 2012 Mercury Music Prize with their inimitable style, a folky electronic rock blend. Their sophomore album "This Is All Yours" opens with "Intro", a theatrical instrumental garnished with choral flourishes. "Arrival In Nara" has a lovely piano intro that takes up almost half the song before transforming into a cinematic acoustic ballad, while the brilliant ballad "Nara" about a Japanese city with roaming deer has a magical timbre and builds to an incredible crescendo. The last part of the trilogy "Leaving Nara" is a beautiful Sigur Rs-style warble, with a trippy and delightful cover of Bill Withers' "Lovely Day" tacked on as a hidden track."Left Hand Free" is a Bluesy rocker with vocalist Joe Newman slipping (as he often does) into what sounds like an extra terrestrial language at times, while the tender falsetto-sung "Choice Kingdom" has an other-worldly aura. The acoustic "Hunger Of The Pine" features a sample of Miley Cyrus repeating "I'm a female rebel", whimsical and absolutely enchanting. The Bon Iver-like "Warm Foothills" features Conor Oberst, Lianne La Havas and Sivu sharply alternating vocals and adding whistles to the folky ballad. "Bloodflood Pt II" is the sequel to "Bloodflood" from their debut, a mysterious ballad with haunting synths and guitar and gently clattering percussion, swelling and ebbing to dramatic effect, an absolute highlight!With the bar raised this high, it will be interesting to see how Alt-J can follow this up.

For their third album, The Drums find themselves reduced from a quartet to the duo of Jonathan Pierce and Jacob Graham (the empty space for two on the sofa on the cover art should be a big clue) and adding a darker tint to their Indie Pop sound.Opening cut "Magic Mountain" is a raucous punk number which keeps stopping and starting, taking one on a jerky but fun ride. Filled with distortion, yelps and harrowing effects, it at once distances itself from the band that gave us sunny Pop like "Let's Go Surfing". Slowing things down are "I Can't Pretend" and "I Hope Time Doesn't Change Him", pretty and calming belying the dark lyrics (the latter is a charming tune about killing someone), before the lean bouncy Smiths-esque "Kiss Me Again" raises the tempo again."Let Me" ("They might hate you, but I love you, they can go kill themselves" - inspired by homophobia in Russia) and "Face Of God" are a frenetic pair with sawing synths, racing beats and ghostly harmonies which find the pair channeling their inner Robert Smith."U.S National Park" is a lovely ballad that wouldn't be out of place at a sixties prom. "I don't want to die alone by the campfire" croons Pierce. "I buried you deep in my heart" he sings on the pulsing upbeat "Deep In My Heart". "There Is Nothing Left" is driven by jangly chiming guitars, while closing is "Wild Geese", an enchanting ballad with haunted whistles, dreamy synths, and echoing harmonies. "You and me, we're like wild geese that fly through the thunder". Incredibly beautiful!Through even the sunniest sounds runs a thread of melancholy. Gloomy yet beautiful all at once. The Drums are dancing to a new beat which might just be their best yet.

I came across Tweedy on the soundtrack to the brilliant movie"Boyhood". The song used there, "Summer Noon", is a breezy song with dreamy vocals and a familiar feel which also appears here. Tweedy are a father/son duo comprising Jeff Tweedy (of Wilco) on vocals and guitar and his teen son Spencer on drums."Sukierae" is an album of melancholic Folk/Rock with dashes of psychedelia. A double album of 20 tracks, everything is beautiful and makes for compulsive listening, from the cleverly titled messy-sounding garage rocker "Please Don't Let Me Be So Understood", the dark "Diamond Light Pt. 1" (with clattery percussion, a creepy piano riff and ghostly effects, with Jeff singing "Are you scared? are you frightened? Terrified of being alone?"), the tender acoustic "Pigeons", the experimental "Slow Love" (with gently crashing beats, eerie effects and a pseudo Jazz feel), "Nobody Dies Anymore" (with its wall of Ooohs), the upbeat "I'll Sing It" (with catchy Yeah yeah yeahs), "Where My Love" (with lovely piano breaks), and closing cut "I'll Never Know", with tenderly plucked guitars and accidental-sounding horns.Inspired by Jeff's wife's battle with cancer, the album is named after her (Sukierae is her nickname), It's a beautiful collection.

At age 50, Lenny Kravitz looks unchanged and rocks as hard as ever, when he's not acting that is. "Strut", his 10th album, is more of his Rock/Funk/Soul/Blues sound. Not as brilliant as his last album "Black and White America", but still pretty good. Besides, an off Lenny Kravitz still beats most hands down.Opening is the rocker "Sex" with stomping beats and crunchy guitars, Rock with a funky edge. "Strut" is similar but with an anthemic chant for a chorus. "Dirty White Boots" is midtempo with a blistering riff. "I'm A Believer" isn't The Monkees hit but a bouncy clap-filled rocker with catchy chants of "Hey!", while the sax-peppered sing-along "Happy Birthday" recalls Springsteen.For ballads, we have "The Pleasure And The Pain", "She's A Beast", the Bluesy "I Never Want To Let You Down" (on which he pledges allegiance to the flag of love), and the lovely Doo-wop "Ooo Baby Baby" with such gorgeous harmonies, a Miracles cover which really displays his soulful chops.As good as all these are, the triptych of highlights are the galloping Funk/Rock "The Chamber" which is so dancey, the groovy "New York City" ("She's lived and died so many times... She's a queen that stands her ground, nobody can take her down" he sings affectionately about the big apple, there's also a nice spoken section and he also throws in a few yelps), and the brilliant Bluesy "Frankenstein" which feels like a familiar friend.Doesn't break new ground, but sometimes all you need is to do what you do very well. To appropriate one of his album titles, Let Rock rule!

Jennifer Hudson digs out a disco ball and her dance shoes for "JHUD", her third album. Most of the album is upbeat and at 10 tracks, concise and to the point. Compared to her last album which was recorded under a pall of tragedy, it is a major improvement and Hudson sounds like she's having fun.The titular "Dangerous" kicks things off with funky Chic-style guitar and the lyrics "I do it for the thrill, even if it kills", followed by the R. Kelly penned and assisted "It's Your World", a smooth groove with a powerful vocal performance from Hudson which dares you to sit it out. "He Ain't Goin' Nowhere" has a baseline reminiscent of "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life" by In Deep. Penned and produced by Pharrell, it features Iggy Azeala. Pharrell also provides "I Can't Describe (The Way I Feel)", an eighties-sounding groove featuring T.I., and the irresistible piano-sprinkled "Just That Type Of Girl" which reminds me of Mariah Carey's "Make It Happen"."Walk It Out" is a more modern sounding slinky midtempo number produced by and featuring Timbaland. My favourite song is the haunting Eurodisco-sounding "I Still Love You" which sounds like Donna Summer meets The Supremes. "Bring Back The Music" is a lilting retro-sounding midtempo song with lovely harmonies. The bouncy Pop "Say It" sounds like eighties Whitney Houston.Closing is the near seven minute-long ballad "Moan" which if it were on a Janet album would mean something entirely different. It is a Gospel-tinged song, a collaboration with Mali Music, reminiscing about her mother and the power of having a good cry. Starting off gentle, she gradually builds on the emotion and power, especially as a choir comes in to assist the jazzy piano backing. This performance alone reminds one why we fell in love with her.

Purchased this to replace the original blade on my MM875 lawnmower that wore down over the course of five years. I used the original for 5 entire years, never bothering to sharpen or maintain it one single time (oops!). Quite a testament to the blade though, that it still seemed to function great after being neglected for half of a decade. It still cut fine at the time of replacement, but if the grass was slightly wet, the mower began to bog down and not be able to keep up with my lawn.I purchased this new blade, followed the safety instructions and swapped it into my MM875 in about 15 minutes time, and the mower was back to being good as new. One bolt and bracket off, one bolt and bracket back on, and your mower is good to go. It cuts great and restored my faith in my mower to last me for many more years to come.

In what ended up being one of the best decisions we made in terms of product purchases since becoming parents, my wife and I discovered the glory of the HALO SleepSacks when we bought the newborn sized ones with the built in velcro swaddle. The swaddlers sleepsacks took the headache, hassle, and difficulty out of swaddling. We were sold and have been buying SleepSack products in larger and larger sizes as our son grows up.He has slept in a HALO SleepSack product every single cool or cold night since the day he was born. They are extremely high quality, they hold up perfectly wash after wash. He looks comfortable and sleeps soundly while wearing this sleepsack. We have this micro-fleece version for the coldest nights, and the thinner cotton versions for the more mild nights. The design of these SleepSacks is incredible. The SleepSacks zip from the top on down, keeping the zipper at the bottom of the SleepSack where your child cannot easily find it and unzip it, and it also won't be a bother for children who sleep on their stomachs. And it's nice knowing that this product is much safer and provides way more peace of mind than putting a blanket in the crib.This particular one now marks the sixth HALO product we have purchased in the first 14 months of our sons life. We will no doubt be purchasing the larger sizes as he grows, and are sold for life.

Chances are if you are buying this replacement Carafe, you are doing so because you broke your original one that came with the coffeemaker. Our original carafe lasted about a year, until one night while washing it in the sink, the side of the carafe ever so slightly touched the edge of our granite countertops and the carafe shattered to pieces. Because we can't live without coffee for long, I quickly logged onto Amazon to check the cost and availability of a replacement carafe.I was a little shocked to find that the replacements are as expensive as they are. For $22, you could almost buy a cheaper replacement coffee maker. I was hesitant, but after some discussion, we decided we loved our coffeemaker enough to buy the replacement. This replacement is identical to the original carafe that came with the coffee maker. These carafes honestly has a very cheap, minimalist feel to them. The glass feels like it is about as thin as physically possible, and the fit and finish of the plastic components isn't super high. It's a shame, because the coffeemaker itself is a top notch appliance and feels like it would last a lifetime. It's a shame that instead of making these out of cheap glass, that they couldn't instead come up with some kind of BPA-free polycarbonate that can handle the heat of the coffee, or some other kind of less shatter-prone material.I have a feeling that I will be getting roped into buying a replacement carafe again in the future. And that's unfortunately not a great thing to say about the product in this case.

These handkerchiefs are of a higher quality than I expected based on some of the other reviews I read beforehand. They feel like they are stitched well. The designs are simple but elegant. I've washed these roughly 15-20 times each so far, and none of them show any signs of extraordinary wear outside of what I'd expect to see. I have no doubt that I will still be using these for a long time to come.

We bought this musical table for my son when he was very young, about 3.5 months old. We left it without the legs in place, so that we could hold it up in front of my son, and he would hear the sounds and see the reactions when he reached out and smacked any button or object his hand could hit. He seemed to love it and he would always laugh and smile when he was able to play with it. As he grew up, and began to sit up and crawl, we attached the legs (which you can attach and detach very easily with no tools). He was able to stand up and hold himself up, and over time, he even used the table as a device to help him cruise and step around while on his way to walking. He's now 14 months old, and still to date, loves to play with his musical table for many minutes each day.So you can see where I am going with this; not only is this a toy that brings a ton of enjoyment to my son as he plays with it, but it is a toy that helped him grow and develop in other ways. It is built to take a beating too; this table has been smacked, pushed, and whacked over and over again for a year now by my son, and you can't tell any difference from the day it was new. The battery life lasts surprisingly long, we've only had to replace the batteries about once every 3 or 4 months so far. You can quickly adjust the volume to two different positions, and you can even switch the audio from English to Spanish to get exposure to different languages if you so desire.If you buy this table, prepare to have the sounds and songs stuck in your head for a long time, because this toy will likely be loved  by your child for a long time. The one and only thing I would caution to parents as a potential negative, although the build quality is high and sturdy, this table can be pushed around by a child if they attempt to do so. The legs give it a wide base and it is very tough to tip over, but if your child is able to walk, he/she will be able to grab hold of the side and push it around on a hardwood floor or very low pile carpet. It hasn't been a safety issue for us, and in fact it has acted at times like a walker to help my son learn how to walk, but I think it's worth mentioning to any potential buyers out there. Overall, a sure fire 5 star toy that is well worth the cost.

I am not a doctor or medical professional, so I won't waste time talking about the perceived benefits of taking fish oil tablets or what they may or may not help you achieve from a health standpoint. I have been taking fish oil tablets daily for almost a decade now, and for the first 5 or so years, I wasn't brand loyal; I would buy whatever brand was for sale at the grocery store I was in at the time, and use them up. Having bounced around so many brands over the years, I grew very tired of the tablets that had a foul taste to the coating, and even worse, the dreaded "fish burps" that would follow shortly after taking them.Then one day I happened to pick up the Barleans fish oil tablets with the orange flavored coating from a local health supplements store. Loved them. The coating on the pills is a very mild but pleasant flavor. And most importantly, I take the pill, and never taste it again once I swallow it. I've been using Barleans for about 5 straight years now, and not once during this time did I have a single case of the fish burps. Not sure how they accomplish this where others fail so badly, but it works and I am a very satisfied customer. I now reorder regularly on Amazon when I need a refill and I have finally become brand loyal to a fish oil tablet. Highly recommended five star product.

I'll keep this review short but sweet. You are getting a 2 meter long HDMI cable as described. The cabling and the connectors both feel like they are of perfectly high quality and on par with all other HDMI cables I have used. They work fine and serve their purpose as intended, and I have no qualms in recommending them for any reason assuming that this is the length you are looking for. Five star product, offered at a very competitive price. Thanks Amazon.

The Safety 1st Heavenly Dreams mattress is an incredible value for the money, and we couldn't be more thrilled with it. It's not just worth it as a value purchase; I know not everyone is on the same budget as everyone else, but you don't want to go into buying a product like this solely because the cost is low. It's a product that involves the health, safety, and comfort of your child which is something that is worth the consideration at any price. We have two cribs; one at our own house, on which we have a Moonlight Slumber foam mattress that cost us in the neighborhood of $180 (purchased from Amazon as well). The Moonlight Slumber mattress is incredible and we have had no problems whatsoever with it. This Safety 1st mattress was purchased by us to keep at a relatives house for when they watched our child on occasion.Our thoughts were, because this mattress would be used very infrequently, we would just buy a cheaper one and hope for the best. We were incredibly surprised by the quality we received in this product for less than 1/3rd of the cost of the one we used ourselves at home. I would have absolutely no problem recommending this mattress to anyone with a child of any age, from the week they were born on forward. It is firm enough that a newborn can safely use it without undue fear of SIDS risk, but yet just slightly giving enough that it seems like it would be comfortable for the baby. We've been using it for almost a year now as our secondary home for our child and it has performed and held up wonderfully, and my son sleeps great on it.If you're looking for good value in a mattress, this is the one for you. If you're looking for something that appears and feels like it will be safe and comfortable for your child, this is the mattress for you. Highly recommended, and we will be purchasing one of these without hesitation when we have our second child in the future.

I use this product in my 2012 Hyundai Sonata sedan as a holder for my cell phone to allow me to use it as a GPS device while driving. The cell phone I currently use in this mount is a Google LG Nexus 5, which is encased in a Spigen TPU case. The Mountek mount is very easy to install and remove from the CD player slot in my car. I just push it into the slot, turn the knob a few times, and voila, in seconds the mount is ready to go and stable. The "arms" that encase the phone are spring loaded and open with the touch of the top button with surprising force. Then you just sit your phone in and push the arms shut until it is snugly fit around your phone. The mount is adjustable enough that I could see almost any phone fitting fine in this, even something huge like a Galaxy Note phone. They even thought to put a hole on the bottom plate of the mount, which I can run the charging cable through for my phone and charge it while it is on the mount. I've been using it for months now, and never once had the phone or mount dislodge while in use, so I am happy with it in that regard.The one and only caveat, which is mentioned in many of the other reviews, is that this mount will very quickly cause some permanent warping in the fabric "dust cover" that protects your slot loading disc player in your car. Even after just an hour or two of use, you'll notice some permanent misshaping of the dust cover. It doesn't have any effect whatsoever on the performance or functionality of my cd player, it's merely a cosmetic issue, but it happens fairly quick and I can't think of any easy way to fix it. It's barely noticeable, but worth pointing out to any potential future buyers. For this reason, I deducted one star, but overall still highly recommend this mount to almost anyone.

This is certainly the one and only time I've ever placed a pre-order on a children's book, and it was well worth it. Ever since my wife and I came across the "Pigeon" series by Mo Willems, and bought the first one for our son, all three of us have been crazy about his books ever since. My son owns and loves all of them, including the pigeon activity book.The Pigeon Needs a Bath is another great hit in the series, and honestly I feel is the best book yet in the series. The story is humorous; my son especially loves the very impressively thorough page where the Pigeon is coming up with his excuses as to why the water in the bath is too hot, too cold, and the many other reasons he justifies not wanting to get in. The story was humorous for both adults and children alike. It's longer than some of the other pigeon books, but still short enough that it can frequently be read and reread in a reasonable amount of time. And like the other Mo Willems books, on top of being great and wacky stories about the adventures and misadventures of the pigeons, the artwork is phenomenal and humorous as well. The artwork is simple yet very expressive. It's easy on the eyes, and I have a feeling that both the comical stories and artwork in these books will make them fairly timeless. Our son is still young, but I can already imagine myself taking these books back out to one day read them to my grandkids and I don't feel as if they will seem aged or out of date.Overall, whether you are completely new to the pigeon series, or a long time reader, The Pigeon Needs a Bath is an outstanding addition to the Mo Willems collection and a book that I can imagine almost any child being excited to read and laugh about over and over again. Bonus points too, it even seemed to make my kid more excited about bath time as well!Thank you Mo Willems, and please keep the Pigeon series coming!

I have another light like this one, and it is one of my favorite designs.  While it doesn't look fancy, it is compact and lightweight, making it easy to mount pretty much anywhere.  There is no articulating arm for the solar panel, which limits where it can be put, but also removes a potential point of failure.  Once it is turned on, it will output a dim amount of light once it is dark outside.  The light is sufficient to see the area, but also conserve battery life.  When motion is detected, which it does surprisingly well, the light is much brighter, which is nice for security as well as walking safely or parking.If you are looking for something inexpensive with a long battery life, this is a good choice.  There is nothing particularly fancy about it, but it survives a lot of rainfall and keeps going.Thank you to the company for a review unit.

There are many factors to take into account when designing wireless networks. As such, it is hard to predict exactly what, if any, benefit these antennas will give you. What I can say is that they have a much higher build quality than those included with standard routers, with durable connectors and an internal ratcheting mechanism to hold them in the correct position. That is important, since these are omni-directional along a horizontal plane perpendicular to the antenna. If it isn't angled correctly, it may give a worse signal than the cheapest antennas.For a standard home or small business network, the most efficient solution might be to use repeaters or a custom firmware to increase signal strength. With my relatively high end router, which includes decent antennas, these did not make much difference. However, when a higher build quality is important or for replacing poorly designed antennas, these are a good choice.

I was a bit scared to try this after reading the reviews, but I found it surprisingly good and a nice upgrade over the standard canned soup.  First, the packaging eliminates the metallic flavor that can come with tomato based products.  It is creamy, with a white tint, rather than the bright red of classic Campbell's tomato soup.  The carries over to the texture and flavor as well, adding a bit of richness and some slight herb flavor.  I do wish that there was a brighter herb flavor.  I would definitely buy it in the future, but only with a good discount over the current price.

I have a couple closets with no lighting, so I end up using a flashlight to navigate them pretty regularly.  While I would eventually like to install strip lighting to illuminate all the shelves, this iHomeSet motion sensor light was a surprisingly effective quick fix.  The build quality is good and it is nice and small, but still puts out a good amount of light.  Others I've used had a button, but this one is automatic, and smart enough to know not to turn on if the closet is lit up already.  I like that a lot and have increasingly been automating lighting where it makes sense.In short, a small and attractive light way to quickly add light to a small closet or pantry.Thank you to the company for a review unit.

I don't know how the world of merchandising works, but there are few different models of humidifiers being sold under different brand names.  I've tried the main variations (as gifts from my mom or, in this case, because they sent me one to review), and this is my favorite.  The primary reason is that it creates a lot of scent with a relatively small amount of scented oil.  The larger units water down the oil too much, making them humidifiers more than appliances for aromatherapy.  Apart from that, the design is attractive and compact and it is easy to operate.

0:21 Mins Light bars change the whole feeling of driving in the woods at night and make it safer, but are also a relatively cheap way to add dramatic landscape lighting or light up tight spaces like attics.  My interests are mainly the latter, and this light bar does an excellent job.  It is super bright and the angle lights up a wide area rather than the tight directional beam that some create.  The design and build quality are high, with metal fins to keep things cool and it feels surprisingly solid for the price.  I see that some people have issues with broken LEDs, but all mine are functional so far.  I will update my review if any stop working.Thank you to the company for a review unit.  It looks like this is the company to go with when I purchase more.

Overall, I am really impressed with the quality of this artwork for the price.  The wood frame is nice, and the canvas is wrapped without any defects.  These particular paintings are beautiful and versatile, working with a lot of colors and room styles.  Standard mounting hardware is also included.  My only critique is that the print is a bit too glossy, which gives it less of a "canvas" look and more of a glossy photo print aesthetic.  Still, they are a nice way to add art to a bare room.Thank you to the company for a review unit.

Philips has made waves with their recent headphones, with the A5Pro being a catalyst.  They compete well with headphones from other brands that cost more while doing some unique things to set themselves apart.The build quality of these is the highest I've ever seen.  They are metal (aluminum and steel), with no obvious weak points.  That means they are ready for many nights DJing or just surviving travel.  The earpads and cord are also easy to replace, making this substantial investment more palatable.All of that durability does come at the cost of a little weight.  But, at over 400 grams, I still find them very comfortable because of their design.The sound quality is impressive and not what you might expect from DJ headphones.  Rather than boomy, with exaggerated bass, there is an intricacy and accuracy that is breathtaking.  At the same time, they are fast and adept with more fragmented sound.  At the same time, they create an openness and intimacy that, again, I would not expect given the branding.Overall, the A5Pro headphones show that Philips is serious about taking market share from the audiophile crowd.  The build quality is exceptional, and the audio quality doesn't fall short.

I have saved a lot of money using space heaters, but they can be dangerous around young children.  This Vornado heater does a lot to mitigate that, though it isn't perfect.The general build quality of this fan is good, if not unusual.  It is all plastic, which prevents the surface from heating up.  The cord is thick, with a convenient hidden storage loop.  In order to prevent tipping, the base it wide.  It looks like the fan should be able to tilt in different directions, but unfortunately it is static.The first safety feature I noticed was the toggle switch that prevents the heater from being turned on by a baby.  A toddler may find this pretty easy to figure out (slide the arm out of the way before turning on), but it is a nice feature regardless.  On the bottom of the heater is a button that must be depressed for the heater to work.  So, if the heater tilts or is picked up, it will stop.  The grill is also designed to not allow small fingers to reach inside.Otherwise, the heater has the standard features, including two heat modes and fan only mode.  The controls are analog, which I like because it can be used with a thermostatic timer.My only critique is that the fan developed a rattle sound within minutes of my first use.  It is not terrible, but also disappointing for this higher priced fan.In short, this fan really is safer for children to be around, and is otherwise a standard fan heater.  If not for the rattle, I would give it 5 stars.

There is something to be said for simplicity.  This car charger has only one port and nothing external to set it apart, though the build quality is good for the price.  What little it does, though, it does very well.  With 2.4A, it charges fast and the port gives a snug fit to hold USB cables in place.  If you only need to charge one device at a time, I think this is just what you need.Thank you to the company for a review unit.

This deodorant will leave you feeling and smelling fresh with its 24 hr protection. It feels a bit wet and icky when first applied but it quickly air dries, without an issue. The Large All Season Heavy Duty Boot Tray / Utility Tray / Litter Tray / Shoe Mat / Plant Tray / Trunk Tray 100% Green Made By Recycled Material Environmentally Conscious by Simple Living is truly an all purpose sturdy rubber tray that is useful for many areas around the home. G.G.Martinsen 32 GB Mini Usb Port Slim Small Multi-lingual Selection 1.78 LCD Portable Mp3/Mp4 Player is a very compact media player that can display photos, play your music (various formats), videos (Im not sure what formats/untested), and ebooks. It comes with instructions, USB cable, and earbuds. The earbuds are average on sound quality and so I prefer to use this with much higher quality buds and cans but then all of those cost much more than the media player itself so that isnt at all surprising. With higher quality headphones the audio quality is excellent. The player itself works very well once you get used to the menu system (its not too difficult - I didnt need to read the instructions). I tested connecting this device to my Linux and Windows systems and it showed up right away. Transferring files to it was a breeze and just like transferring files to any USB stick. The now nearly ubiquitous control ring has menu, next, previous, and play/pause buttons. You control the player using those buttons with short and long presses. Where this unit really excels is in a low cost music player and voice recorder for note taking (mic quality is passable imo). I have a phone that can do all of these things better, however I dont always like lugging my much bigger phone around and sometimes I work in areas where my phone might be targeted for theft so I like to keep it out of sight. I'm chose this data cable to use with my iPod because I move around a lot while listening to audio books on my iPod. I love these small washcloths and use one every day. They are gentle enough to use on a newborn's skin, and they're gentle enough to use on my aging skin.  With six in the package, I have to wash them once a week, and I'm ready to go again.Very, very gentle -- those with aging skin will love these washcloths as much as I do.

This day pack is large enough to hold a large laptop in the interior pocket.  Two mesh sleeves on the outside will hold water bottles, making this a good pack for hiking or for school.  A diagonally zippered pocket on the front is perfect for small items, such as pens, insect repellant, or similar things.What bothers me about this pack is the construction.  While the materials appear to be quality, padding is minimal and stitching is very poor.  Seams are uneven and, in some areas, they catch the material outside of the seam creating a very uneven appearance.  Stitching is poor, and missing are double stitched seams to reinforce areas of stress. I doubt that this pack will last long, and, due to the design, repairs will be difficultTWO STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

Its great to find that smoke alarms no longer have to be the large, clunky things that adorn(?) the ceilings in my house.  This alarm is about three inches in diameter and comes with a fitting for installing it on the ceiling.  Its battery powered (battery included), and I appreciate that because weve had problems with our alarms which are wired to our house circuits and go off unexpectedly when we when lose power.I tested the alarm with a match that smoked slightly.  The alarm registered the smoke and went off.  Wow, very loud alarm, loud enough to rouse the soundest sleeper.Theres a test button on the front of the alarm.  Press it to hear the alarm.  In addition, it flashes about once a minute to let you know its working perfectly.Consider these alarms when its time for replacement of your old alarms.  Theyre an improvement over the old, wired variety.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

After years of use, my old desk magnifying glass was scratched so badly that it distorted the magnified image.  Ive used it for actually reading the fine print when it was so fine, it defied reading by ordinary eyes.  Now Ive received this new magnifying glass with a lovely rosewood handle.I like the fact that it is attractive, the first magnfying glass I could say was pretty.  In addition, its lens is very good with only minimal loss of clarity at the edges of the magnified image.  I keep it out on my desk, but this time, Im keeping it covered by the plastic bag it came with.  With care, Im expecting this one to last me a lifetime.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

This thermal flask will hold a close temperature of either hot or cold drinks for up to six hours.  And you can boost the effect by pre-heating or pre-chilling the flask.  Its double wall construction is the genie in the bottle.  The most interesting thing about this thermal flask, however, is the cap.  A switch on the side of the cap locks it tight, or, when released, pressing the cap button will flip open the cap so you can drink directly from the flask while minimizing the chances of spilling liquid.This flask is shaped perfectly for fitting into the cup holders in my car.  My ceramic mug was slightly too large, so, before using this flask for travel, I was often spilling coffee on the seat or on me.It hold about 8 ounces of liquid, more than enough for short trips.  For longer trips, consider getting and filling two.  It would make a great gift for anyone who makes frequent car trips.FOUR STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

This small waterproof battery is a champ.  With 5600mAH, it recharged both my cell phone and my iPad with just a little power to spare.  An overnight charge will be it back to full power in storage. Other batteries can perform just as well, so whats great about this one?Its the size (about four inches long and one inch thick) and the waterproof covering.  Its a terrific battery for sports.  I keep it in my bike bag where its small size still leaves room for a tool kit, keys, and other essentials while I ride.The waterproof covering is especially important because theres often a puddle you cannot avoid, and you end up wet with your bike and bike bag wet as well.  No worries about this battery.  If you make certain youve closed the door that houses the input and output ports, youre safe from splashes.  And youve still got the power you need to make a call in case of trouble.In addition, this battery offers two lights, one white with steady and flashing modes, one red. Buttons for powering on the battery and another for lights make it easy to operate.Very nice, and a nice gift for cyclists!FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

Just What I NeededThis 4-in-1 socket adapter has solved a long-standing problem in my car.  How can I use my independent GPS, my air purifier, and my recharger for electronic devices  all at once.  This adapter has three sockets and a usb interface in case I need an extra port. Included as a part of the socket adapter is a long cord, so Im able to move the adapter away from the cigarette lighter and out of the way of my gear shift lever.  When Im not using it at all, I stow it in the console, ready for the next trip.In addition to my need to use all three sockets at once, I also enjoy the temperature reading for each of the sockets. Im sure it will tell me when something is failing and getting too hot or not warm at all.  Also available are voltage readings.Each socket is controlled individually with its own on/off switch, so youre not wasting any power.The brushed aluminum cover of this adapter is very attractive and modern looking.  Its a pleasure to use and really improves my travel time.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

Heres a surge protector with something new and very, very useful  the outlets rotate.  What this means is that you dont have to replace all the plugs to make room for a very large plug like those that sometimes accompany electronic devices.  Simply rotate the outlet, and your large plug will fit on the outside of the surge protector, no longer interfering with other plugs. This is an innovation that really helps when your surge protector is full.  Now you can use all the outlets at once, regardless of the size of the plug.In addition to the six rotateable outlets, there are two usb ports included with this surge protector.  Charge up the many devices that use usb cables without adding extra charging devices.Im really pleased with this surge protector.  Ill be replacing all my old power strips with more of these.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

Wow! Im impressed with this flashlight.  It offers five light modes:1) super bright;2) normal light;3) low light;4) strobe; and5) slow flash.A brief tap on the green switch on the end of the flash light will change the mode.The flashlight is constructed of a sturdy metal, and it is a tactical type flash light.  Included with the flashlight is a holder that will allow you to use the light on your bicycle.  I attached it to the handle bar on my bike and compared it to the light I had been using.  This light is much brighter than my old light and allows me to see much farther into the distance at night, so I feel more secure riding at night. I'm leaving it on my bicycle, but it can be easily removed without the need for tools.The flashlight is small enough to fit in a pocket, less than six inches in length.  It is powered by a battery that can be recharged, and the charger is included with the light.Im amazed at the modest cost of this light, less than 20% of the cost of my older tactical flash light.  When you need a new flashlight, get this one.  Small, bright, rechargeable, and very sturdy.  I'm delighted, and I feel sure you will be as well.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

If youve got a dog who grows hair like mine (Yorkie), youve got to pay a monthly grooming fee (expensive for a Yorkie) or learn to trim the dog yourself.  I decided to learn to trim her both for the savings and for avoiding the trauma that she feels every time we go to the groomers.  These grooming scissors help make the job quick.Included in the set are straight scissors, curved scissors (especially helpful for trimming the feet), and thinning scissors.  Molly has so much hair that the thinning scissors are used most often, in fact every time shes bathed.  She has heavy hair on her rump, and thining out that thick hair there makes it easier to clean her up.  She might not agree, but she does love doing her business without getting it stuck in heavy hair.All three pairs are sharp, so I can easily remove hair that needs trimming without hurting the dog.  Tips are almost blunt, very rounded with no sharp points.  While Molly is no fan of grooming, she also sits quietly while I do it, knowing that it will soon be over.Give this scissor set a try if you decide to groom your dog.  They are modestly priced but work very well.  Im pleased.FIVE STARS!Sample provided for impartial review.

What a lovely wallet!  Its genuine leather and is small enough to fit into a pocket with hanging out.  Heres what I like about this wallet;1) Small but roomy - This wallet offers six slot holders for various cards and has a flip-out holder for drivers license or alternate forms of ID. A battery charger is just a battery charger unless its this battery charger.  It does its job speedily and effectively, but other chargers do that as well. Secured by Velcro straps, this bag fits tightly over the center front bar of my bike.  The first thing you see is a pocket for my cell phone. I love French press coffee, and this one makes enough for all day long.
