The Audible app for recorded books also works well on this phone, better than on my Samsung tablet (where it would turn off every time I drove over a bump or tried to use it on a treadmill). Typing is also easier on this phone than on smaller phones since the keyboard is proportionately larger.So what's not to like? I've had a few issues getting used to the power button and how it works. When passing around the phone to show friends, they kept hitting the power button on the side, and that would cause a delayed restart without warning. I had a similar thing happen when I tried to turn off the screen while listening to an Audible book. On my tablet, I'm used to just getting my book going, then hitting the power button to turn the screen off to save the battery while I listen. But when I hit the power button to turn off the screen on this phone once I got my book going, the phone did a delayed restart. Pressing the power button and holding it in just started a cycle of delayed restarting. I had to take my hands off the phone and let it restart a bunch of times before I could get it going steady again. So when I listen to Audible books, I've found I just have to let the screen time out on its own--the book keeps going even after the screen turns off. I've also noted that the standard email program oddly updates only about every 12 hours, even though I've changed the settings to every 5 minutes. (On the other hand, FaceBook on this phone grabs dozens of stories, while FaceBook on my tablet only lets me have 10 stories an hour--odd application-specific limits). I had to reset the screen brightness to Auto on this phone about 5 times before it finally stayed there for good. Still, when I'm reading the screen in a quiet room with steady illumination, with the brightness set to Auto, every few minutes, the brightness setting cycles through dim to super bright, before resettling back to the appropriate brightness. Annoying, but not impossible to live with. Battery life is about comparable to my tablet--I can usually get through an entire day on a single charge on this phone, unless I'm doing a lot of reading. If I'm using the phone just as a phone with minimal screen time, a single charge can last several days.I'd like to get a hard leather case for this phone to protect it, but such cases are not yet available. On the other hand, I've found that a Ghirardelli 3.5 ounce chocolate bar wrapper box is a perfect fit for a temporary case. I might even just stick with the chocolate bar wrapper even after proper cases become available for this model, if only for the shock factor when people see me pull what appears to be a chocolate bar out of my bag or pocket and begin talking on it! And if my homemade Ghirardelli case wears out, I can always eat more chocolate to get a new one.Overall, though, this is a great phone, especially for folks who prefer to talk to the phone carriers on their own terms. If you really want a phone contract, you can take this phone to your carrier of choice and get a discount price on their contracts, or you have the freedom to pay by the month, or pay by the use as I do. If you take the time to run the numbers, you would never, ever sign a contract that includes a phone, since you will end up paying 1.5 to 2x as much as the phone is worth over the length of the contract. Pay the money up front for this contract-free phone, and you'll be far better off, with a phone of your choice instead of one dictated by your carrier. Plus, with 2 SIM card slots on this phone, you can easily access 2 different phone networks, such as one for domestic calls and one for traveling (with no expensive roaming surprises!). The large sharp screen makes this phone a great choice for readers, making it possible to carry around just one device for calling, texting, emailing, and reading. Yes, this phone has a few quirks to get used to, like that odd power button and the random cycling brightness issue, but once you get used to these minor quirks, you will really like the phone.

This is a pair of rubber handled spring-assist clippers. The metal blade is 2 inches long, inserted into a pink contoured plastic handle that measures 5 inches long. I'm not sure where the 6 measurement listed on the package comes from, because I get 7 from stem to stern, but that's OKthe clippers fit my hand well. Since there are no loops on the handle, the clippers are completely ambidextrous. The blades are labeled titanium bonded, and a note on the package says this will make them harder than stainless steel so they should stay sharp longer. The clippers have a tensioning adjustment accessible under a plastic cover at the joint; you will need a medium sized screwdriver to use this adjustment. Included in the package are a tight fitting plastic blade cover (you will need thisthose points are sharp!), and a lanyard to hang the clippers around your neck so they don't get misplaced. There are cutouts in both the blade cover and the clipper handles that the anchor string of the lanyard can fit into. A thumb-operated lock on the upper handle locks the blades shut for storage and opens them for use.I am pleased with how well these clippers cut. In shape and function, they are most like the thread clippers in my sewing kit, and they cut thread well. They also snip tight corners in paper and make quick work of plastic packaging, mailing tape and boxboard. So they're handy to have around when you're opening the mail or the shopping! Note however, that the blade is very shortjust 2 total, so if you have long stretches of cutting to do, feet of cutting instead of inches, you're going to have to do a lot of pumping those little blades to get through it, and with so many pumps, it will be hard to stay in a straight line. So I'm not sure why this product is labeled scissors. I would call these things clippers, great little blades for making small, precise cuts. But for a big job, I would use proper scissors instead. Nevertheless, for small jobs, these clippers are sharp, easy to cut with it, and brightly colored so they can't hide!

This is a case of 12 17.5 oz cans of coconut water. Ingredients include coconut water and nothing else. According to the label, one 8 oz serving provides 50 calories, so drinking the whole can (about 2 servings), will give you 109 calories. In addition to calories, there are small amounts of sodium, potassium and sugars, and a significant amount of manganese, all naturally occurring in the coconut water. The cans are metal, stamped BPA free, and have a use-by date that suggests you can store the cans for at least 18-20 months. The label notes that flavor is best if you serve the beverage chilled. The cans have push tabs so that they can be opened by hand without any need for a can opener.Coconut water is an excellent rehydration fluid, since it is low calorie and naturally lightly sweetened. Many other coconut water products have added flavors like coconut and pineapple, so if you are used to drinking those products, the flavor of this pure coconut water may surprise you at first. Sweetness in this coconut water is subtle, and not specifically fruity. I usually buy coconut water in juice boxes, and I was a little wary of this product at first because so many canned juices taste like cans. However, I was pleased to find no taste of can in this formulation, especially when served in a drinking glass. A plus of packaging in cans is that the entire can is recyclable, so you won't need to fill up your trash can if you buy a case of this beveragethe empties can just go out with the recycling. In contrast, few recycling programs accept juice boxes, so a case of juice boxes means a case of empties to send to the landfill.Note that this is coconut water, not coconut milk. Coconut milk is a creamy white product made from pulverized coconut meat and used in cooking or for making mixed beverages. It is much too thick and rich to drink straight, and it is also high in fat. Coconut water is the liquid contained in green coconuts; it is clear, thin, fat-free and suitable for drinking straight, but does not have the heavy coconut flavor that you might want for cooking.

This is a 16 foot roll of black kinesiology tape for binding common joint and muscle injuries. The uncut roll comes in a plastic container with screw lids on either side to make it more manageable for storage or travel. Also included in the package is a KT sticker and one page brochure with a list of possible uses. Instructions and photos are included on the brochure for knee support, plantar fasciitis, achilles, and calf wraps and links to a website with videos and instructions for many more uses. This black tape is KT's pro version, which lasts 4-5 days, depending on the application.I started using kinesiology tape on the advice of my physical trainer to help heal minor ankle and knee injuries. I have been really pleased with how well it works. In addition to providing support, it may also help promote the flow of lymph and thus speed healing. KT makes both precut and uncut tape, like this roll. For most applications, I prefer the uncut version since I can cut it exactly to my specifications, although the precut version can come in handy if scissors aren't available. The key to making uncut tape stick is to round the edges of each piece when cutting the strips. This black pro tape is long lastingeven with frequent showering, a single application will last almost a week.

This is an LED light bulb that produces light equivalent to a 60W incandescent bulb. The bulb is shaped like a standard incandescent bulb, so it will fit in ordinary lamp fixtures and lamp shades will clamp securely to it. The outer casing of the bulb is plastic, so there is no danger of shattering if you should happen to drop the bulb. The translucent portion of the bulb extends approximately 2/3 of the way down the globe, providing light in almost all directions. The bulb is bright, providing 800 lumens of light, slightly less than a 60W incandescent, but more than a comparable 15W CFL. The light color temperature is 2700K, a warm shade reminiscent of ordinary incandescent bulbs. The bulb is rated for 15000 hours, which comes out to about 13.7 years at 3 hours of use per day. The bulb is dimmable.I placed this bulb in a cool hallway light fixture to replace a 15W CFL bulb. The CFL bulb wasn't working well in the hallway because of the cool temperatures; it was always slow and dim to start. In contrast, this LED bulb comes on instantly and is noticeably brighter than the old CFL. The LED bulb is rated down to -20C, or approximately 0F, cooler than any ordinary indoor temperature. Not only does the new LED bulb work better than a CFL at cool temperatures, but it is also cheaper to run over the long term when compared to either a CFL or an incandescent bulb:Bulb  Hours Watts Purchase 1 Purchase/25 yrs Electricity/25years Total/25 yearsThis bulb  15000 10.5  $9.99  $16.65  $31.50  $48.15Incandescent 4000 60  $0.82  $13.67  $180.00  $193.67CFL  8000 15  $3.22  $13.42  $45.00  $58.42(These calculations assume an average electricity cost of $0.12/kWhr.) Overall, I really like this bulb. It works better than a CFL, it's safer than either a CFL or an incandescent (it won't shatter, doesn't contain mercury, and runs cool), lasts longer and is cheaper to use over the long run. And it produces a pleasing bright light.

This is a starter kit for creating decorative punched borders in paper or cardstock for matting artwork. The kit consists of a plastic baseplate with paper guides and a cartridge stamp cutting tool. The cutting cartridge pairs securely to the baseplate with magnets. To make a border, you begin by measuring your paper and deciding how large a hole you would like in your mat, and what the outer dimensions of the mat should be. Then you line up one corner of your paper on the appropriate corner guide on the base plate, the one that matches your chosen dimensions. Place the cutting cartridge on the baseplate, and the magnets instantly align it correctly. Press down on the cartridge and your corner is cut! Cut the remaining corners similarly, then use the guides on the baseplate to align your paper to cut the straight sections between the corners. In the box, you get the baseplate, a cutting cartridge with two flowery cut-outs that makes a lacey border, and instructions in English, Spanish, and French. For more variety of cut-out shapes, you can purchase other cartridges separately. This kit is designed for cutting single sheets of paper or light cardstock; it will not cut regular mat board. The paper guides on the base plate are set for a sheet with minimum outside dimensions of 3x3 inches; there is no limit on maximum sheet size. The paper guides accommodate mat widths from 1/2 inch to 3 inches.I was surprised at how easily I was able to get this kit up and going. Within minutes from opening the box, I had a lacey matted frame cut out. I did make one goof in interpreting the instructions on that first fame and made one cut in the wrong direction, so you might want to practice one or twice before you move on to expensive paper. But compared to cutting frames out of mat board with knives, this is a snap and joy! I was very impressed with how well the magnets aligned the cutter cartridge with the baseplate. All you have to do is get the cartridge somewhere near home and it snaps exactly into position. Do note that there is no collection device on the bottom of the baseplate, so you will end up with a bunch of tiny paper scraps on your table. Thus, it might be a good idea to do your cutting work on a table that is easy to wipe clean (not on a rough table, or over a textured tablecloth, for instance). Overall, though, this is a nifty little device, useful for crafters and framers, and simply fun to use.

This is a substance designed to kill crawling insects through abrasion. The active ingredient is diatomaceous earth, which is a natural substance made from fossilized marine skeletons. To use this product, you carefully spread it where your crawling insects must travel. As they try to crawl over the powder, they acquire fatal abrasions. According to the label, this product is effective against cockroaches, ants, earwigs, millipedes, centipedes, crickets, silverfish, fleas, carpet beetles, and bed bugs. Warnings on the label note that the product can cause moderate eye irritation, and that you should avoid contact with eyes or clothing and washing hands thoroughly before eating, drinking, chewing gum or tobacco, or using the toilet.I would have liked to know more about exactly what is in the bag before purchasing the product. The label says the active ingredients are 85% silicon dioxide and 15% other ingredients. There are no notes on the label about whether the product is approved for organic gardens/farms, and not enough information about the "other ingredents" to make that decision yourself. Fortunately, there is an 800 number on the back of the package, so I called it to get more information. The customer service representative who answered told me that silicon dioxide is the only active ingredient and that she has no information about what the other ingredients are. She also said that this product is ONLY for surfaces, indoors and out, and not for gardening of any kind. In my own further research, I found that inhaling crystalline silicon dioxide can cause bronchial disease and cancer, but that most diatomaceous earth is of the less toxic amorphous form of silicon dioxide. In any case, it is vitally important to follow the instructions on the bag about spreading this product carefully so that you don't breathe it in; it's best to wear a dust mask when applying it. And other research about using diatomaceous earth to control insects notes that it is far more effective when dry than wet, so you may have more luck with it indoors, or you may need to reapply it after rain. According to OMRI (Organic Materials Review Institute), diatomaceous earth is an approved for some organic farm usages, with restrictions. But without further information about the "other ingredients" in this product, it is hard to tell if this particular product would be OMRI approved. In any case, if applied with care in places where small children aren't about to eat the dust, diatomaceous earth is probably one of the safest and most effective ways to control crawling insects.

This is a heavy duty stapler for attaching 2-60 sheets of paper. The base and handle are black and grey plastic, while the mechanism and plate are steel. There are rubber grip pads on the bottom of the stapler to prevent slipping on a desk. The stapler ships with a long handled staple puller and 800 heavy duty steel staples.My husband unpacked this stapler and loaded it for its first use. He told me he had some trouble figuring out how to load it, but it seemed to work fine once loaded. We tested it on a batch of 58 sheets of paper. It stapled them easily with no jams. Then I tried loading the stapler myself. Since there were no written instructions for loading the stapler, I examined the pictoral instructions on a sticker on the stapler carefully. After about 3 minutes of studying the pictures and trying a lot of different moves, I got the stapler drawer to open and put some new staples in. I closed the stapler and tried to staple, but the loading drawer kept popping open. I couldn't get it to stay closed. Next thing I knew, the drawer popped way out while I was stapling and the rod bent severely. Dead stapler. I already have enough paper weights, so sadly, I had to throw the brand new stapler in the trash. If only there had been some written instructions to go with the pictures! At least I have the heavy duty stapler puller and 800 staples for consolation. Too bad--just a few words on a paper insert to explain the pictures on the sticker might have kept this stapler alive.

This is ready-to-use organic coconut flour in a plastic package with a zip-type recloseable seal. The list of ingredients contains one item: organic coconuts, whose origin is listed as the Philippines. Other information on the label notes that the coconut flour is non-GMO, vegan, and gluten free as well as organic. The label mentions a website with recipes, but the site does not appear to be working yet, at least not with the web address given. The manufacturer recommends storing the coconut flour in the refrigerator or freezer after opening.I was quite pleased with the flavor of this product straight out of the bag. It tastes fresh, and appropriately, like coconuts. Following a suggestion on the label, I substituted 1/3 of the total wheat flour in my usual pumpkin muffin recipe with coconut flour, and the result was quite tasty. The key for such substitutions is to add an equal amount of extra liquid. The first time I made pumpkin-coconut muffins using this flour, I added some extra liquid, but probably not enough since my muffins came out a little grainy. The second time, I added more liquid, and I was very pleased with the resultmoist, creamy muffins with a subtle coconut taste. The muffins were a little more filling than usual, a little more dense, and tasted somewhat sweeter, even though I used the same amount of sweetening as usual.According to the nutritional information label on the bag, the standard serving size is 2 tablespoons, which corresponds to 32 servings for the entire bag. Those 2 tablespoons supply 62 calories, including 2 gm of fat, 8 gm of carbohydrates, 5 gm fiber, and 2 gm of protein. Coconut flour is naturally low in sodium, and provides significant iron (2 tablespoons coconut flour corresponds to 10% of iron requirements on a 2000 calorie diet). It may also lower the glycemic index of foods that it is added to. Keep in mind that the fiber content is very high for a flour, so easy does it. Too much of a good thing can cause excitable bowels.If you're not sure what to do with coconut flour, just search the internet for recipes. There are plenty of recipes out there, including muffins, cookies, crackers, quick breads, brownies, and more. Many of the recipes are gluten free and also suitable for those following paleo diets. Or, like I did, you can adapt your own favorite recipes from home by substituting some coconut flour (plus extra liquid) for some other flour. In any case, note that even a small bag like this one of coconut flour will last a while since recipes using coconut flour generally use no more than  cup at a time, even to make a full batch of muffins. A little goes a long way.

This is a roll of uncut kinesthesiology tape for supporting muscles and tendons to promote healing. This version of KT tape is 100% cotton, latex free. According to the manufacturer, when compared to KT Tape's other product, KT Tape Pro which is made of synthetic materials, you can expect to get 1-3 days of wear per application from this tape, rather than the 4-7 days from KT Pro. They also say that this tape provides Good level of support, while KT Tape Pro provides Best. Inside the box, you will find a 16 foot cellophane-wrapped roll of tape and a 1-page instructional brochure demonstrating various applications. The brochure includes links to videos, printable instructions, and social media. Instructions are available for injuries from runner's knee, plantar fasciiitis, should pain, lower back pain, AC joint pain, wrist sprain, calf strain, and many others.I began using kinesthesiology tape on the advice of both my chiropractor and my physical trainer. The tape has been invaluable for promoting heating of some nagging injuries, including both a recent shoulder injury and an ankle sprain from long ago. The tape works by providing external support at the site of the injury, as well as promoting the flow of lymph under the skin. Overall, I found this version of KT Tape very effective as well as handy and economical to use. I like the fact that it is uncut, so that I can use exactly the length that I need (although that does mean that I have to hand trim the edges to round them  to get maximum adhesion). This particular roll is good for wraps that will only be staying on a short whileI save the more expensive Pro version for wraps that need to last all week. In general, I've been pleased with this tape, how well it stretches and sticks, and how well it lasts. So far, I've relied on my physical trainer to explain and demonstrate specific wraps, but it's great to see that the manufacturer has also provided so many instructional videos if you're unsure about how to do a specific wrap.

This is a pair of protective earmuffs designed to suppress gunshot sounds while amplifying low-level sounds such as conversations. The muffs are black, well padded, and weigh 10 ounces with batteries installed (2 AAA batteries, not included). Fully folded, the muffs form a tight ball, about 5 in diameter and 4 wide. The muffs are fully adjustable, with a stiff padded headband and slider bars so they will fit many head sizes from quite small to very large. The ear pieces have thick  rubber padded sealing rings that conform to the shape of your face. The lid to the battery compartment has a plastic tether making it less likely that you will drop or lose the lid. The muffs work by first blocking as much sound as possible physically, then by capturing sound through two microphones, one located on the outside front of each ear piece, and filtering it electronically so that loud, percussive noises are suppressed while quiet noises are amplified. Thus, wires pass from each ear piece through the padding on the headband to carry sounds between the two ear pieces. A single volume knob is located on the back of the right earmuff for controlling amplification. On the front of the right ear muff is a 3.5 mm audio input jack that allows you to directly patch in sounds from a standard radio, two-way radio, music player, or other device. Also included in the package is a 3 foot long 3.5 mm audio patch cable and a small 14 page instruction brochure. The earmuffs have a 22 decibel noise reduction rating.I find these earmuffs much more comfortable and form fitting than my old set, which was a Peltor Tactical 6S. The 6S just wasn't very adjustablethey're hard to fit onto smaller heads. But the adjustability of this new Peltor Tactical 100 makes it a clear choice. They fit well on smaller women and children's heads, yet they also expand to fit larger heads that the 6S couldn't reach around. I also like that fact that the Peltor 100 only takes 2 batteries instead of 4. What it really comes down to though, is noise protection. At 22 decibels of noise reduction, these earmuffs do a good job at reducing noise and protecting ears. According to the noise reduction ratings, they aren't the most protective muffs on the market, but they're probably good enough for most situations. Amplification of ambient sounds is sharp, and the aux input is clear. The earmuffs are great for shooting on a range, especially for matches when it is crucial to hear conversations and instructions. They also work well for hunting, watching motorsports, and other loud activities where hearing protection is required.

This is a set of 2 WeMo controlled lightbulbs and a WeMo link transmitter to control these bulbs or other WeMo bulbs that you may purchase separately. Other products that you can purchase separately to add functionality to the bulbs are a motion sensor (so that the bulbs turn on automatically when you walk into your room) or an insight switch (so that the bulbs turn off automatically when you plug in your phone to charge at night). The bulbs themselves are excellent quality. They provide 800 lumens of  warm light with a bulb shape and glow that is comparable to a 60W incandescent bulb, but they draw only 9.5W of energy. The translucent section of the plastic bulb cover extends far below the meridian, so there is a wide angle of light coverage (in some LED bulbs, the translucent cover ends at the meridian, so all the light goes up, which isn't very useful for table lamps since you depend on light below the shade for reading, not above it). The bulbs weigh only 3.5 ounces, much less than the old first generation LED bulbs. They will work with or without the WeMo transmitter. The WeMo transmitter is a small brick, 2  inches square by 1  inches deep. It will fill half of a standard light socket without interfering with the other half. It needs to be plugged in somewhere where it can reach your WiFi network and your bulbs. It draws only about  W of electricity, so you can plug it in somewhere and forget about it, once you set up your system. When plugged in, it produces a faint green glow, less that you might get from a small LED nightlight.I found the setup for this set rather straightforward. Following the instructions on the paper quickstart sheet, I screwed in the bulbs, turned them on, plugged in the transmitter, and downloaded the free WeMo app onto my Android tablet. Using the WeMo app, I finished setting up the transmitter for my network. Then I could easily turn the bulbs on and off from the app controls on my tablet. Other controls on the app were a lot harder to figure out. Apparently, you might be able to set the bulbs to turn on automatically at scheduled sunset time for your area, and turn off at dawn. Or easier than that, turn on and off at specific times automatically. I couldn't figure out these controls at all, though. I pushed and punched a lot of buttons throughout the app, but couldn't make headway at programming the bulbs to do what I wanted. Overall, the app is rather non-intuitive and quite frustrating, with little to no documentation (at least that I could find). Hopefully, though, the app will be improved with time, because these lightbulbs are designed to last. With their 25 year expected lifetime, they will clearly outlive any devices you might use to control them. So the controls will no, doubt, evolve and improve.As I decided where and how to put these bulbs into service, I began to really think through the concept of controlling lightbulbs through apps. While it sounds like a cool idea initially, in practice, it doesn't make as much sense as you might think. Does it really make sense to have to reach for your phone in order to turn a bulb off or on when you're sitting right beside your lamp? And what about other people in your house? How convenient is it for them to have to ask you to get out your phone in order to turn the lamp off if they're sitting right beside it? And if you decide to add motion sensors to turn on bulbs automatically when you enter a room, do you really want the bulbs to turn on every time you enter the room, even when it's daylight? Maybe it might be more convenient after all to control the bulbs manually. Most bulbs, that is. There are some locations, however, when bulbs like these make a lot of sense and are the perfect solution. For instance, if you have a sentinel lamp, one that you use to show that someone is home in your house. With bulbs like these, you can program them to turn on and off at certain hours, or control them remotely, even from the other side of the world through the internet. And if you add a motion sensor, you can add further suggestions that someone is home, through turning on these or other bulbs around your house. So for security purposes, these bulbs are great.I really like these bulbs a lot. They provide great quality light, and through the app, you can dim them, even if they're in lamps that don't provide dimming controls. Like other LED bulbs, these bulbs are mercury-free, so they're safer than CFLs. They use only a tiny bit of electricity compared to regular incandescents, so they're cheaper to run. They will last for decades. So, let's hope the next generation of the control app lives up to the promise of the bulb's capabilities.

This is a battery operated cordless electric shaver for facial hair. The shaver weighs 4.3 ounces. It is 6  inches long, 2  wide, and 3 inches deep at its widest points. It runs on a rechargeable lithium battery. Also included in the box are a snap-on side burn trimmer, a transformer/cord that works with either 110 or 220 V input, a zippered hard shell carrying case, a plastic cleaning/recharging station, a plastic cleaning cartridge with cleaning fluid designed to last 3 months, and a 40 page product guide in English. Controls on the handle turn power, speed settings (3 choices), and a travel lock. LED indicators on the handle light up to show the need for cleaning (after every use), travel lock on, battery charge level, replace shaving heads, and blocked shaving heads. A full charge can take as long as an hour, and provides up to 50 minutes of shaving time, or the shaver can be plugged in for just 5 minutes to provide a one-shave quick-charge. The shaver cannot be operated when plugged in. The shaver itself is water resistant so it can be used in the shower, but the cleaner unit must not get wet. The cleaner unit stands 10 inches tall and is 6 inches in diameter, so it takes up a hefty footprint on the counter. To use the cleaning unit, you snap the razor in place and press the on button. Active cleaning takes 10 minutes, followed by a drying cycle of 4 hours. Meanwhile, the razor is also charged while it is being cleaned. Alternatively, you can plug the razor directly into the charger instead of charging it with the cleaning unit, if, for instance, you are travelling and don't want to carry the cleaning unit with you. The razor and trimmer can also be cleaned by hand under a tap with running water if the cleaning unit is not available.My husband is quite impressed with this shaver. It gives a closer, more comfortable shave than his old razor, a Norelco Sensotouch3D, which was also a really good shaver, but this one is even better. The travel case is quite handy, as is the travel lock control. He found that the scent in the cleaning cartridge was somewhat overwhelming, so he won't be using the cleaning system until Norelco comes out with an unscented cleaning cartridge. He also finds the LED indicator lights on the handle a bit dim, hard to read unless he is in a dark room. Another possible problem is that the shaving heads and trimmer are separate snap-on pieces on this shaver, so they could get lost more easily than with shavers where these pieces are more permanently attached. Overall, though, the closeness and comfort of the shave with this shaver far outweigh any of these issues. My husband is extremely satisfied with this razor and it has replaced his former favorite, the Sensotouch 3D.

This is an electric toaster oven for baking small casseroles and cakes. The oven weighs a little over 13 pounds. Outer dimensions are 9 inches deep, 21 inches wide, and 12 inches tall. The oven area itself measures 12 inches deep, 9 inches tall, and 16.5 inches long. The slots for the baking rack are halfway up, so the distance from the rack to the top of the inside is 5. There is a clip on one side wall that holds the rack firmly so that it doesn't tip or fall out. According to the manufacturer, the oven will accommodate a 9x13 baking pan or a 12 pizza. There are heating elements top and bottom. All visible parts of the oven are made of steel, the sides, the top, the rack, the control knobs, except for the door, which is thick tempered glass, and the side attachments for the handle and feet (the oven stands an inch above the countertop). The electric cord is 24 long, grounded and 3 pronged. The 3 knobs on the front control temperature, time, and toast doneness. A red LED indicator light comes on whenever the toaster is in use. The toaster draws approximately 1340 watts when the heating elements are on. In the box, you get the oven itself, a crumb tray, a bake pan, a metal wire rack, and a fold-out paper instruction brochure in English, Spanish, and French. The oven comes with a 2 limited warranty (the warranty does not cover commercial use, misuse, abuse, neglect, product modifications, service outside the purchase country, glass parts, shipping or handling). The appliance is made in China.I was extremely impressed with how well this appliance works as an oven. When I set it for 350 degrees F, it went from room temperature to the target 350 in under 2 minutes. Wow! That's the power of convection! The temperature stayed right at 350 or very close, rising to as much as 365, but never more. While the  oven was baking at 350, the temperature on the outside top surface never went higher than 120 degrees F. This is far better than my old Black & Decker toaster oven, a small non-convection oven, which topped out at 330 after taking 10 minutes to get there, while the top surface reached 200. In general, I'm really impressed with how well this new Black & Decker oven cooks. With the fast heating time and even convection heat, small casseroles and cakes really cook extremely well in this oven. They cook faster in this toaster oven than in my gas oven, with no burnt edges. The convection oven also does a great job of roasting nuts without burning them. The timer knob for the oven is also quite useful. You can use it to set the oven to bake for an exact number of minutes (1-60), or use the "Stay On" setting.This oven is really too big to be an effective toaster, though. It's big enough to hold 8 slices of toast at once. But the toast cycle takes a full 7 minutes. In my old Black & Decker oven, toast took only 2 minutes. Since the electric draw is about the same for both toasters, that means that the new oven takes 3 times as much electricity for each round of toast (although the old toaster only holds 3-4 slices).  So, while you can use this new Black & Decker oven for making toast, it wouldn't be my go-to toasterit's too slow and expensive for everyday toasting.For the right purposes, however, this is a very impressive and useful appliance. It would be an ideal small oven for someone without a full kitchen, enabling fast and safe baking, even of casseroles and frozen pizzas. It could be useful in RVs with limited kitchens, for example, or student apartments or dorm rooms. Given how well the convection function works, it would also be useful as a supplemental oven in a fully equipped kitchen, great for baking small to medium dishes without heating the whole house up. It would make a wonderful housewarming or wedding present. Overall, highly recommended!

This cube is for optimizing camera and software lighting settings for digital photography. The cube measures 1.5 inches square and weighs 1 ounce. It has 3 black sides, one fully grey side with the Spyder cube logo printed in white, and 2 sides that are diagonally half grey and half white. The cube is designed to be screwed onto a tripod mount by the bottom corner, which is surrounded by the 3 black sides. One of the black sides should face the camera when in use; this side has a  inch hole designed to act as a black trap. In this orientation the 2 half and half sides will be facing up and meeting at the corner pointing to the camera, with the white sides lower and the grey sides above, meeting at the top corner of the cube. On the very top of the cube is a plastic ball painted shiny silver (or maybe it's some sort of metal rather than plastic) with a black elastic loop sticking out the very top. Also included in the package are a nylon carrying pouch, a black neck strap with a quick release clip, and a paper insert in Italian, German, French, Spanish, English, Japanese, Korean, Russian, and 2 versions of Chinese. The instructions say Place the Cube in lighting conditions under which you will be photographing. Orient the cube so that the lower black face, containing the black trap, is at the bottom front, and the two split white/gray faces are both visible. Take a photograph that includes the Cube. This photo will capture important information about the shooting conditions, to be use in making basic RAW adjustments. After you take all your photos in the location where you set the cube, you go to your digital processing software, such as LightRoom, and use the photo of the cube as a reference to adjust white balance, exposure, brightness and blacks. One way to do this is by using the eyedropper tool in your software and clicking on the photo of the better lit (lit by primary light source) grey face of the cube, since it is 18% grey, or the black trap of the cube to set black levels. Thus, the cube works much like an 18% grey card, but with the greater sophistication of the silver ball to hunt for catch lights and the black trap for finding absolute blacks.I really didn't know what to expect when I ordered this cube. I had expected some bit of software or plugin, given the price of the product, but coming up with how to use the information captured in a photo of the cube is really up to you. I thought the cube would work like a grey card, but would have the added convenience of greater portability.  Since the cube really needs a tripod to stand on its own, that may mean using a second tripod, which rather negates the portability advantage. Overall, I found the printed instructions extremely obtuse and hard to follow. On one side of the instruction page are some drawings without words. If you study the drawings for a while, you may figure out what they are trying to say. The drawings do convey some important information not covered in the textual instructions, however, such as the need for a tripod to mount the cube on. Neither the drawings nor the textual instructions mention the included neck strap with the quick release clip. I have no idea how the strap is intended to be used with the product, or what the quick release clip might clip to. At the end of the sparse verbal instructions is a link that says For more information: www dot datacolor dot com slash sypdercube. That link leads to a webpage that points to an article on using the cube posted on another website; the linked article is now defunct. So, you're on your own. If you know enough about photography to appreciate the design of this little plastic cube and how to use it, you may find it very useful. For instance, if you already rely heavily on grey cards, this could take your exposure adjustments to a new level. But if you don't know how to use a grey card or you already get good results without one, you may find this little plastic cube bewildering.

This is a serrated knife suitable for cutting bread or vegetables with soft smooth skins like tomatoes. The blade is 8" long, and it has a 5" rubber grip handle, so the knife is 13" long in total. The blade is solid stainless hardened steel from its tip through the heel of the handle. The rubber grip wraps around the handle in one solid piece; thus this knife is not going to fall apart or split if it gets wet. The knife weighs 6 ounces and feels very well balanced in the hand. The scallops of the serrations are on the right side of the blade only and start 1/2" back from the tip (this 1/2" of flat blade at the tip is sharpened as well). The blade shows a slight taper from cutting edge to the top. Instructions on the packaging say to hand wash this knife and promptly dry.This knife cuts very well, but what I really like about it is how it feels in my hand. It's simply very comfortable to cut with. When I'm cutting with this knife, I feel a lot less likely to bruise my knuckles as I often did with my old bread knife, which had a narrower wooden handle. The solid rubber grip on this handle is never going to work its way loose, even with repeated washings. This knife is excellent for bread and anything else with a soft texture that needs a sawing action to cut. For tomatoes, I would actually prefer a knife with a sharp point at the tip to remove the cores, and that's something this knife doesn't have. But if core removal isn't an issue, this knife certainly slices tomatoes well. Overall, this knife is an excellent, durable kitchen tool and my first choice for slicing bread.

This is WiFi range extender for that enables you to greatly extend the coverage of your current wireless router. In the box, you get the WiFi extender device and 3 installation guides (English, Spanish, French). The device measures approximately 2x2 inches on the face, and sticks out 1.5 from the wall when plugged in. It has swiveling antennae on both the left and right sides that are 2.5 long. There is an Ethernet port on the bottom of the device for wired connections. To install the device, you simply plug it into the wall and wait about 30 seconds for the power LED indicator light on the front to turn solid green. Then you need to connect the device to your home network. You can do this either through WPS (WiFi Protected Setup) or by first connecting to the device with a wireless computer or phone, then finishing the setup through a browser. LED indicator lights on the front of the device signal whether the device has a good connection to your home network, a good connection to a WiFi client device, and power and WPS status. To make this device work, you must already have a wireless (WiFi) router in place and working in your home; you also need to have Internet service.It took me about 15 minutes to unpack this box and get the device working extending my home network. The biggest challenge for me was making sense of the directions, which are a bit sparse. In any case, setup isn't that hard at all. Here's one way to do it:1. Plug in the network extender to an electric socket as close as possible to your home network router (in the same room is plenty close).2. Wait for the power LED on the front to turn green (10 to 30 seconds).3. On a computer or mobile device, find and join the new network. That is, join the network just as you would join any other new network in a library, cafe, or business. Depending on what you are using for a computer, you may need to go to SettingsNetwork Settings, or Control PanelNetwork Settings, or Network Connections, or... (This is where the printed instructions are a bit vague, since they are trying to use language that will work regardless of the operating system, rather than providing specific instructions for each type of operating system or computer.)4. Once you have join the extender's network, open a web browser and type in the address bar: www dot mywifiext dot net.5. This will bring up a list of nearby networks. Choose your home network from the list.  Press the continue button.6. Choose a name and security settings for the new extended network (or choose to make them the same as the home network's settings).7. Unplug the extender device and move it to where you need it, close enough to the router that you get a decent signal from the router, but also close to the area that needs coverage.8. Once the power LED turns green in the new location, you can join the extended network (the same way you did in step 3, but using SettingsNetwork Settings, Control PanelNetwork Settings, etc.). You are now good to go!Alternatively, you can set up the extender by pairing it with the router by pressing the WPS buttons on both the router and the extender and waiting for them to find each other. Then you connect with the new extended network in your usual manner (Step 3 above).Once I installed the network extender, I was quite pleased with how it works. I can now stream movies in my garage, where before I could barely get a wireless signal at all. The WiFi signal from the new extender reaches through walls and windows, and the coverage area seems larger than that of my original router. With the router and the extender working together as a team, I now have WiFi signal through every room of my house, my garage, and most of my yard as well. The Ethernet port on the bottom of the extender is also quite handy for connecting devices that require wired connections. Overall, I found this device relatively easy to set up and it performs quite well.

This is a heavy duty, bright bulb suitable for PAR30 fixtures. It is designed to run on varying voltages, from 90V to 277V, so it can be used on 220V circuit as well as on a US standard 110 circuit. It provides 1100 lumens, which is approximately equivalent to a 75 to 85W incandescent bulb. It has a plastic head and plastic side fins to shed heat. Not that there is much heat to shedthis bulb runs very cool, even compared to similar CFL PAR30 bulbs. But unlike CFL bulbs, this bulb is mercury-free. Thus, it's safer all aroundunlikely to ever shatter or explode and it won't cause a hazardous spill or toxic waste diposal problem. It is rated for 25000 hours, more than twice as long as a comparable CFL PAR30, and more than ten times as long as a comparable incandescent PAR 30. Thus, replacement costs are much lower with this bulb, especially if you factor in labor costs or the dangers involved in replacing bulbs in tricky, hard-to-reach fixtures.This bulb will save you a bundle of money in the long run:Total costs (purchase/replacement + electricity over life of the bulb, assuming $.12/kwh)--this LED bulb (1 needed for 25000 hours): $77.69--23W CFL PAR 30 (2.5 needed for 25000 hours): $98.75--100W incandescent PAR 30 (12.5 needed for 25000 hours): $409.64As soon as I opened the package, I knew I was holding quality. The bulb simply feels well constructed. Also, I really like the light color from this bulb. With a temperature of 4100K, it is whiter than a clear metal halide bulb, and nearly as white as a daylight CFL. Thus, colors under this bulb don't have that yellowish distortion that you often find under an incandescent bulb. The ability to use this bulb in 220 volt circuits is another plus. Overall, if you are in need of a heavy duty, bright PAR30 bulb, this is an excellent choice that works well and saves money.

I love this computer! I just bought a Dell Inspiron 15 #7547 several months ago and was never completely happy with it. This Dell i7559 Full HD is hands down, wonderful!!! This computer is fast, works wonderfully (despite the worries over Windows 10), and I am 100 percent blown away by the performance and graphics. I've played games for hours on this PC and have had no heating issues at all. Others have reported over heating, but I've not experienced it with this unit.I had the wifi drop off problem that many have complained about and while it was annoying before I knew what was causing it, once I read the previous reviews and realized it was a Windows problem, I went to Dell.com and downloaded the current drivers for this computer. I have had no wifi connection problems since I upgraded the system and it took only a few minutes to fix the problem.I installed my Sims 3 games and I can't believe how great the graphics are for such a hoggy game. On my last laptop much of the content was not shown due to the memory and graphics. On this computer, I can see the people drive in their cars through the town. Before, they got in the car and just arrived at their destination, now I can see everything on the game that I couldn't see before and it is very cool.My last Dell had some kind of weird keyboard issues but this computer works flawlessly and I really recommend it. This computer is a little heavy and it's plastic where the casing on my other Dell is metal. I don't really like the plastic, but in this case, I cannot complain because the computer is awesome. I am so happy with this Dell compared with my past Dell purchases.Other people have commented that this has room for easy expansion-which is a huge plus as well. I did uninstall MacAfee which I don't like and installed my Norton for which I have a subscription-I had no trouble with this. The only trouble I've had is with Windows 10-seems it wasn't quite ready for Primetime, but in time the wifi glitches and browser problems will be addressed.For laptop gaming, I find this computer perfect!! It's crisp, fast and has great graphics for a laptop-for the price, this laptop is really, really great!

I have been taking CoQ10 for quite a while for the heart healthy antioxidants it provides. I found this to be a good version of the supplement and I trust Viva Labs and only use their brand of coconut oil. I also like Jarrow, but the CoQ10 that I have already been taking is Viva Labs. I did some research and for this supplement, you want a small, dark pill which is what this CoQ10 is. Jarrow states that this is a high absorption source-many you buy are not but people take them any way. This CoQ10 is made in a way that is absorbed and not wasted. This is an important nutrient that is harder to make in your body on its on as you age-as you get older this is a good supplement to keep your heart and vascular system in good shape.I find Viva Labs to be a trusted brand and I've had no trouble taking this form of CoQ10. This product is more easily absorbed than other sources and it is a heart healthy product, especially if you take statins.

This hand cream works very well to protect hands and keep them moisturized while creating a barrier against dryness. I was expecting this to be a thick, heavy cream, but instead, it is light and moisturizes winter hands very well while keeping them nice and soft with regular use. The main ingredient in this cream is mineral oil. I was definitely expecting this to be a heavier and perhaps more greasy than it is. This is a much lighter cream than I thought it would be. This is more of an everyday moisturizer rather than a dry skin treatment. This does make skin nice and soft and provides some protection against the elements with regular use. This isn't a miracle cure but it does help for winter dryness or it works for hands that are over worked in the elements such as outside cold air or with drying chemical cleaners, etc. I have found this to be a nice, everyday hand moisturizer to help keep my hands nice and soft.

I enjoyed reading The Longest Night. For a first time novelist, Andria Williams does a great job contrasting the family life of a military family with a failing reactor the husband, Paul is assigned to work on in Idaho Falls. This book takes place in 1959 and it sums up the life of a military wife very well.Nat Collier has a lot to adjust to. She was raised in Southern California. When she marries Paul she is under the thumb of the military with him. When Paul is assigned to a nuclear reactor in Idaho, they move with their two young daughters to an isolated military town where women and children live while their husbands work on the reactors. The reactor Paul is assigned to - Cr-1 by all appearances, is failing. Due to the master sergeant not wanting to stir anything up with the upper brass, the reactor's troubles are chalked up to Cr-1 being old and the crew is forced to keep her going with band-aids.After an confrontation with the unscrupulous master sergeant, Paul is punished and sent to the Arctic for a year to work on another reactor leaving Nat alone. Befriending a local, she gets by with the help of Esrom-the scandal! When Paul comes home, he has to deal with his growing family, his wife, as well as the reactor which has grown worse in its troubles in his absence.I think Andria Williams did a great job describing the stifling surroundings Idaho Falls held for Nat and an even better job describing the work Paul did on the reactor. Even I, who knows relatively nothing about the workings of a nuclear facility, could imagine the reactor and its problems and the growing concerns regarding it. While this is a work of fiction about an actual occurrence, Andria gives further reading suggestions for those who find the topic of her story of interest.This is a well done first novel and I will happily pick up further writings from this author.

I think kids who love the movie Frozen will enjoy Disney Frozen Fever Party Book. I think some of the ideas are pretty cute. This book could use a few more recipes but I do like the invitation ideas and it has some cute templates and over all ideas. I think what this party book is lacking is more. Each section: Invitations, decorations, Cakes & Drinks, Games, Party Favors could all use a few more ideas. Each section has four or five ideas and this could have been a good book with a little more meat added to it. This book is basically floating on the Frozen franchise. Kids will love some of the ideas and of coarse, the pictures. This is a cute book but could really use a bit more substance to become a fan favorite.

This is another great study guide from Melissa Spoelstra. The last book workbook I have by her covers the book of Jeremiah and this workbook covers the story of Joseph. I highly recommend both. Spoelstra's books are relatively dense, full of stories, questions and food for thought. In this book, Joseph, we work on forgiveness and letting go of bitterness. The books that Spoelstra writes are not only food for thought, but food for the soul. The recommended reading in the back of the book is another plus and provides further reading suggestions for your studies. Forgiveness and letting go are big issues and some people hang on to resentment and bitterness forever. Joseph, Bible Study, helps to inform you on how to let go of anger, resentment and bitterness through stories, lessons and scripture. I don't just recommend it for women, or for study groups, anyone can work in these books and grow. When I finish a lesson in her books, I always feel like I've learned something important. In the hustle and bustle of daily life, we get caught up in the trivialities of life. Melissa's books really put life into perspective and teach lessons from the Bible. Whether you are fully familiar with the Bible or reading it for the first time-her study guides help you understand the messages more fully to gain great insight and become a better person.

This is a very cool cat tree. My cats in particular like the hanging ropes and the hidey holes. This is a tall unit, up to the ceiling and it's covered with soft fake furry stuff-not carpet but a little lighter than carpet. The boxes and platforms are heavy and made from particle board making it a sturdy cat tree. The ladders and scratching posts are great for playing and scratching. My cats also just like to perch on top and look down upon the dogs.I did take away one star for the directions. Granted, my husband didn't have too much trouble, but I hate to think what this would have looked like if I didn't have help putting it together. My husband builds stuff so he was really good with the instructions but for me, I found them vague. The pieces, with the exception of the scratching posts, are not marked according to the directions. We did have a couple of false starts where we had to take our beginnings apart and start over until my husband got the hang of the directions of building from the top down. Other than the instructions, I really like this cat tree and so do the cats. It took us about an hour or an hour and a half to build.This unit is large but can easily be taken from one area to another so once you build it, you can change its place and try different locations-it is not too heavy that you can't relocate it.The material covering the boards is a tad thin. I would have preferred a little heavier covering but this does look nice and it's a light beige color and kind of blends in with any color..All in all, for the price, this is a very nice cat tree with lots to do for the kitties.

My kids use ziplock bags every day for school and they like the easy open/close designed bags. The Hefty Sliders are perfect for their needs. We use them for sandwiches, chips, cookies and snacks. The slider in these bags is easy to operate-if you have little kids and they pack a lunch, these are perfect. I like the easy to use slider lock. These are sturdy enough to reuse for snacks and lunches. I dislike the bags that you have to line up the lines to close the bags. Sometimes those take forever to get just right. These are simple to use and are very reliable for dry snackings. These are perfect for dry snacks and sandwiches, and they are super easy to open and close.

When I first mixed this with my old dog's food, it looked like he was eating around it. I held my breath for a second and then he started eating this up like crazy until the bowl was completely empty. I've not tried Eukanuba pet foods before and I use a good quality dry dog food for all my dogs. I have one mid aged that likes this just fine too. I gave a couple of handfuls to the bully and he totally loves it-though he's not old enough yet. My ancient dog likes this very much. I always have reservations regarding pet foods that list meal as the first ingredient-as in this food. Then I started thinking that in the wild, animals are not always picky about what they eat. Meals, such as chicken meal use by products-things you and I won't eat and grind them up into a meal for pet foods. It surprises me the cost of foods that use by products are still really expensive-foods such as this, but they do compensate with other ingredients and nutrients such as brewers yeast and they add good vitamins.I am still not sold on by products completely. I feel they are still a cheap filler. That said, my old dog is loving this so much I may have to get some for him when this bag is finished. He is very old for a big dog and if he likes this that much and the food helps him with old age issues, this is a huge plus and is why I am giving Senior Maintenance five stars. Normally, I don't rate foods that use by products this high, but my dog loves this and I think with the added nutrients, this is a good choice for a senior dog.

The Sea Beach Line is a very well written mystery. Izzy Edel is on the hunt for his father after receiving news of his death. His father, Alojzy, has always been a bit of a mystery, popping in and out of Izzy's life. After being expelled from school and a short stint living with his Mom and Stepfather, he goes back to his roots in New York City to search for the answers regarding his father's disappearance. What follows is Izzy's journey to his father's old stomping grounds where he was a book seller. One thing leads to another and another as Izzy delves into his father's life.This is a very well written book. It explores the past and present as well as Jewish folklore and culture. This is more of a casual read through the streets and its lively characters who take Izzy by the seat of his pants on a journey of discovery.I enjoyed this book very much. It's casual, but it's also very riveting-making it a strange combination and a very good mystery.

My cats normally eat Purina Pro for Sensitive Systems since we took in a stray that seemed to do very well with this food. She's gone but our other cats like that food a lot so we just kept getting it. I was eager to try this type of Pro Plan and our cats like this very well too. They like it better than the last really 'healthy' food we tried. I have a bit of a problem with meals and this contains a meal, though the first ingredient listed is salmon. I was thinking however, meal is all kinds of stuff that isn't human grade, but in the wild, if a creature is hungry it may eat parts of an animal that humans wouldn't-with the exception of certain things that are ground up in the 'meal' for food-so my opinion is that meal is a cheap filler that may not be that healthy. That said, all three of our cats are eating this up and enjoying it. They don't seem to like the really healthy, expensive cat foods that are on the market so this one is a go for them and they are the ones eating it. I do think this is a pretty fair brand as far as healthy and likeable for cats. It's not horrible for your cats and it seems to taste pretty good.

I like to use the Lysol disposable wipes for easy clean up in the kitchen. I thought I would try these microfiber dishcloths for a change of pace. These work fine and have a nice scrubbing side for stuck on goo or dishes. I haven't had any problems with these inexpensive dishcloths. They wash up fine and work for cleaning up messes and spills. I like the scrubby side and it works great for kitchen/bathroom counters. The other side of the cloth is a soft, absorbent material. I like to try to cut down on my garbage so using less Lysol wipes or paper towels is a good thing for me.

The La Roche-Posay Pigmentclar Dark Eye Circle Cream does work to lighten up dark areas around the eyes. This has a metal tipped applicator that I really like, the cream feels good going on with the cool metal tip. I thought at first that this product was a dark circle treatment but the more I used it the more I realized this is a treatment for under make-up or when you want circles lightened up such as from a bad night's sleep. This is a light colored cream and a little bit goes a long way. The directions say to use it with the applicator above and below the eye area, and rub with the tip until it's absorbed. This is a long lasting tube that does provide results. This isn't a treatment however, but more of a cosmetic type product. You could probably get the same results using a concealer that you do with this product, although, I find this cream unique with its light color and metal applicator. This is an interesting product that does lighten under eye circles pretty well.

I bought this Tresemme hairspray because I ran out of spray but didn't have time to go to Sally's for what I normally buy, I am very surprised at how well it works. This Voluminous Hold hairspray provides a great hold but it doesn't make hair stiff. When this is on my hair, my hair still has a lot of bounce and a more natural look than with most hairsprays. It provides the perfect amount of hold without looking lacquered up and stiff. This also provides some nice shine. I thought I would try it because it's new and it wasn't expensive and I could use it for a backup for when I run out of my normal spray. This works so well, I might switch-I am not in a hurry to buy my normal brand since this is working so well.I have very straight hair that I style with a flat iron. This holds great and is easy to wash out. When I use this, it holds my style very well, adds shine and my hair looks natural and not weighed down.

The last book I read was rather depressing, so The Shrunken Head was a delight for me to read. At first glance, I was thinking, here we go again, but alas, I was enchanted by the story and found the characters and plot fresh and fun. I enjoyed how this series with orphans, takes place in the 1930s. If I am not mistaken, the 30s gave rise to yellow journalism and tabloids. The four children involved in this tale: Sam, Thomas, Pip and Max find themselves the target of such a journalist when the famed and cursed Shrunken Head that takes center stage in their show at Dumfrey's Dime Museum of Freaks goes missing. The four find themselves stars in the local paper, and not in a good way.Each child has an uncanny ability which makes them stars of the somewhat defunct museum and sideshow. The Shrunken Head seems to breathe new life into the exhibit until it is stolen and the curse causes people connected to the head to mysteriously die. Danger comes hideously close to the children and they have to solve the mystery of the missing head before any more people, especially those closest to them, die.This was a fun, fun, fun book that I really enjoyed. I hope the targeted age group loves this book. I am a bit older, and really enjoyed it. Once the story got rolling, I had a hard time putting Curiosity House down. There are good characters, plot twists and turns, plenty of suspenseful moments, humor and great artwork in the story and I look forward to many more books in this series.

My daughter loves this Artist Studio. At first, I thought the light wasn't quite bright enough, but we've actually had a lot of fun with this kit. My daughter is in advanced art classes, and really likes this! She's pretty creative and has a lot of fun putting the faces together with the transparencies included in this Light Up Trace Case Kit and drawing them on the backgrounds provided.For blank paper we used regular copy paper and can make up our own scenes with the many transparencies that come with this. The surface of the light box is sturdy and you can tuck in the background and then put the transparencies underneath. At first, I wasn't that impressed with the set up, but an artist's eyes can create from anything. Kids can really spend hours drawing and then coloring their creations.This isn't a true light box type of tracing box, but it is a lot of fun for kids.

This is a great moisturizing cream. It's rich and thick and better yet, it lasts for hours. I can put this on under make-up as well as on my neck and hours later I can still feel the softness on my skin. This is also a great nighttime moisturizer. This is a very versatile cream for day or night use. It works flawlessly under make-up and it works very well in conjunction with the Vichy Neovadiol Magistral Elixir. These two products together are wonderful and are useful in the anti-aging arena.I've had not breakouts with this product as I have experienced with other moisturizers and this really works to soften dry skin. I had a cold where around my nose, my skin got chapped and dry but this cream cleared up the dryness in no time. This is a really wonderful moisturizing cream that I can't say has had any drawbacks for me, only benefits so far.

Free Men is great historical fiction. Katy Simpson Smith has recreated a dramatic account of three very different men, and the man who hunts them through the Alabama woods. I really enjoyed reading this book. The hardships faced by all made me happy I live now and not in 1788. Each man involved in this story has his own story and history and the readings of these is almost harrowing. Bob, a slave, dreams of escape and makes a run for it. White man, Cat, has lived a difficult life from birth and Istillicha, the Indian, is recovering from trauma and betrayal which led him to take a leave from his tribe. The three join up on the road and when faced with an opportunity that could change their lives, they take it and commit a horrible crime.Investigator Le Clerc works for the Creek chief, Seloatka and he is sent to track Cat, Bob and Istillicha and punish them for their crimes. Through the dense wilderness the three men try to get to Florida with Le Clerc on their tails. In between their day to day survival, the author deftly takes the reader back through the lives of each character, including Le Clerc.This story is based on a real happening which makes this a wonderfully intriguing read if you enjoy reading historical history. Life in 1788 was pretty crazy and this book is so well done that it's like time travel. I can tell if I am really enjoying a book by the amount of time I spend telling others about it and I spent a lot of time telling my family about this book as I was reading it.

This is a good study guide for groups or for individual studies regarding many different prophets and kings of the Bible. I've enjoyed working in this workbook and find the studies to be interesting and rewarding. I've always enjoyed Solomon and really liked the study of Solomon in this book as well as many others.Jessica LaGrone has created a good study in this workbook. The lessons take about 20 minutes a day to complete. I have learned a lot and find the lessons engaging and interesting. Much of the readings are included in the book making it simple to study the sections. The questions are thought provoking.

I really love the Vichy moisturizers I've tried and was looking forward to using this corrective concealer. I think this works better on blemishes than under the eye. In order for this to correct some darkness under my eyes, I have to use several layers and even then, I can still see my darker circles. This works great as a corrector for spots or blemishes but not that great for underneath the eyes. It gets a little thick when I have to use so many layers plus foundation so I am not completely thrilled with the results of this corrective concealer stick. I do love the other products that I've tried from Vichy-including their dry oil and moisture cream. This color maybe a little light to correct my under eye circles but it's fairly close to my skin tone.

My dogs seem to enjoy this Solid Gold Wolf King food. It does have a cool name. My bully likes it the most. The pieces of dog food in this variety are larger than in the food I normally buy for them but my dogs are all large so this doesn't seem to be an issue. I like to look into the ingredients in the food. The first ingredient in this is bison and the second is fish meal. I am not a huge fan of meals because it generally means all left over parts of the said animal. Like for example chicken meal can include all parts of the chicken they don't normally use, all ground up. That sounds gross, I know but fish meal is the same, all parts they wouldn't normally use are ground up and put into dog food. That said, there are also other good ingredients in this food such as carrots and sweet potatoes. There are a lot of Omegas in this food as well which is good for skin and coat. They include probiotics and other vitamins and oils such as salmon oil, sesame oil and almond oil. These types of fats are good for your dog. The fillers in this food seem to be rice bran, potato, and oatmeal. There are some really good ingredients in this food and it's made in such a way that my dogs will eat it. They usually are not thrilled with potato but like this food just fine. In comparison with our normal, grain free dog food, this does contain a bit more vegetables and fruit.

I enjoyed reading The Curse Of Crow Hollow. While it did take me a bit longer to read than I had anticipated, I did enjoy the story: good vs. evil in a small town. Crow Hollow could be anywhere. It's nestled in a valley and up on a hill near an old abandoned mine, there lives a witch. She's lived up there for years in a tiny shack, banished from society where folks in town just as soon forget there ever was an Alveretta Graves. Things stay fairly separated and memories and secrets stay buried until a group of teens enter the forbidden zone and stir up some stuff with the witch. The girls who snuck up to the mines all suffer from strange afflictions-the result of which could only mean that Alvaretta has hexed them. When other girls begin to show strange illnesses, it's believed that Alveretta has cursed the whole town, and something must be done. Rumor has it that the witch is hiding a demon up there on the mountain.This is kind of a half Twilight Zone and half character study of folks who live in a tiny town with their children. It's about buried secrets, paranoia and the consequences of evil and guilt are heavily studied here. I hadn't read Billy Coffey in the past but I will definitely read his books in the future. I liked the atmosphere and the message of his book and I like the way the book was narrated like a story being told. I haven't read a book by Billy Coffey before, but I will definitely read his books in the future.

The Iron Shop Butterfly Kinetic Wind Spinner is an interesting piece of yard art that you set up and the wind spins the two circles of butterflies in separate directions. This is easy to set up but getting the butterflies just right takes a little time. At first I had one side spinning wonderfully while the other sat there but eventually, I got all the butterflies bent to the right angles and both sides are spinning in the wind. I was afraid with all the bending I did on the butterflies that one would come loose because they are not attached that well for a lot of tinkering, but all butterflies stayed intact. The butterflies are pretty and they sparkle in the sun as they go around and around in the wind.That said, this piece is a bit expensive. It is sturdy and will withstand rain and wind. Make sure when you set it up that you tighten the bolts that hold the spinners - they were loose so just a quick tightening is all they need. I really like the spinner. It brightens up the yard and looks very pretty in the sunshine but it seems a little costly overall.

I love Jarrow supplements and find they are always on the cutting edge for creating new products that can enhance your life. I already take Jarrow's Mag Mind and really love the product. My elderly Mom takes it too and she finds that it really makes a difference with her memory. I like the Mag Mind too as it has a magnesium that crosses the brain barrier and helps you sleep better and improves cognitive function. This supplement contains a Nootropic which is a neuro and cognitive enhancer. This supplement also helps with stress and maintains the level of cortisol your brain releases over time especially in times of stress. This is very cool stuff. I have found I am a bit more relaxed with this supplement and I sleep very well. We get a month's supply to try and sometimes it is or isn't long enough for a supplement. The time I have taken this supplement, I've noticed no adverse reactions. I am a  bit calmer and I like the idea of this working with stress and cognitive functions. You do have to take it three times a day, but I've had some benefits from twice daily. I really like Jarrow brand supplements and find that they are always coming up with interesting supplements to enhance health.

I like this cleanser. It has a soft fragrance and uses good ingredients to slough off dead skin and cleans my face very well. I have been putting a little powder on a small, wet sponge each night and I find that this cleanser rinses off easily and leaves my skin nice and smooth without drying it.The packaging can use a lot of improvement though. When I opened the bubble pack it came in, a puff of cleanser came up from inside. The lid had opened causing the contents to spill. This won't go over well with customers. The lid needs to be secure prior to shipping so it doesn't spill during the trip and lose the contents of the bottle. That's the only problem I have so far with this cleansing powder. I like the product and it works great, but the packaging needs some plastic on the top or something to secure it to keep the lid from opening. A little of this goes a long way and it works well to clean skin and has a nice scent. I've not heard of cleansing powder before and I find that I like the concept a lot. This leaves my skin clean, nice and soft.

Pet Armor keeps fleas and ticks away from your cats. Ticks especially can be awful around here, especially after it rains. We have had no problems using Pet Armor to deter fleas and ticks from our cats. I would not use this on a senior cat however. We have and old dog and an old cat that we don't put any pesticides on at all for fear of compromising their good health. For a younger, healthy cat, this works as well as Frontline for keep pets free from biting insects. I usually only use this type of product when the ticks are bad in the area and not year around to give their systems a break. The cats will often bring ticks in on their fur and they are dangerous insects that carry awful diseases. We have a lot of deer in our area that carry Deer Ticks so I like this product to keep them off the animals and out of the house.

We've tried about four of the Xen-Tan products and some are really good. This one is a good one. The last product we tried was very drying but this one contains Moroccan oil so it doesn't leave your skin so dry. This Transformation Weekly version has a nice lotion type of scent and is fairly easy to apply with the supplied mitt. The foam version of Xen-Tan has been our favorite for ease of application, but this lotion is pretty easy to put on and doesn't give you big lines around the feet and hands-it's easier to blend. The last version we tried was also very dark for pale skin-this product produces a very nice evened color tan which looks more natural.This Weekly Transformation Xen-Tan product is a good one for the smell, ease of application and it doesn't dry out your skin. It's relatively long lasting and contains good moisturizers. The tan it provides for light skin is perfect in color it's a nice, natural looking tan and doesn't turn orange.

I have done a little research on Maca Powder since trying this product. The first and foremost thing I've read is that it shouldn't be eaten raw. This can cause some stomach troubles. The best way to use this powder is to cook it first. The Maca craze reminds me of the Matcha craze where everyone began selling Matcha whether it was the real thing or not. Starbucks even calls its ground wheatgrass, Matcha, for example.This is a good product taken in small doses and cooked. I just boil mine and add it to a smoothie every now and then. It's a potent food. If you read any blog regarding this food from a Peruvian, they all say to cook it and that raw Maca isn't good for you.This product is also great to add to cookies or breads for good health benefits. I've not tried this raw but you can add a bit to foods without changing the taste too much as long as you don't use too much powder. I also boil it with almond milk and honey-tastes great.This powder is packaged very nicely with two zip lock type bags to ensure it stays fresh.

I've learned so much from reading Ocean Country. The bleaching of the coral reefs was a real eye opener as was the thought process that we do not just live alone in our homes, in our towns and in our states, we live on the earth and when you think of the outside world as well as the inside world, as We, it really changes the way you think-(I am not sure I explained that coherently, but read the book and it will make total sense).
