We use a lot of disposable nitrile gloves, typically for yard work involving soil and manure, though we have used them for household cleaning as well.  The gloves we typically use are exam gloves, which have a higher strength than these gloves.  While these gloves are weaker than our light blue exam gloves by test, they apparently have more resistance to certain chemicals, as listed on the side of the box.Generally, disposable nitrile gloves are great when working around stuff that will stain your hands, get your hands excessively dirty, or when you might be exposed to chemicals that can damage your skin or be absorbed by your skin.  Incidentally, nitrile gloves can be great for certain messy cooking tasks.It is true that nitrile gloves can split easily. There have been days when I have gone through multiple gloves when working around sharp objects.  Even though these gloves have resistance to certain types of chemicals, nitrile gloves cannot be used for protection from all chemicals.  However, note that there are no gloves that provide resistance to all chemicals. However, if you need light protection for your hands in a variety of applications, disposable nitrile gloves are affordable protections.The box includes the following list as being the chemicals that these gloves can resist:SolventsAntifreezeLacquersGasolineGreaseSilicatesBrake CleanerHand CleanerEthylene GlycolGlass CleanerPaint ThinnersHydraulic OilCarburetor CleanerTransmission FluidAdhesive RemoverAs with other Ammex gloves we have used, each glove includes a textured area around each finger tip that should provide additional grip. Of course, nitrile gloves tend to be slick when wet, so caution should always be taken when picking up fragile or heavy slick items when using these gloves.While these gloves have been great for us when working around dirt and mud, once the gloves get wet and are removed, it can be a challenge to get the gloves back on again.  We sometimes have to wait until the gloves dry out to try to put them on again, or we just, as the box says, dispose of them. Of course, once the gloves dry out, they go on again as easily as they originally did.As with other disposable gloves we have used, these disposable gloves can be used as hobby gloves (given their chemical resistance, working on cars sound good) or as protection while using chemicals to clean house.  However, these gloves are not resistance to all chemicals, so avoiding direct contact with chemicals is still preferable.  Definitely check the resistance of these gloves to the chemicals you are using before you use them.  The best thing about these gloves is that they are inexpensive, so there is minimal guilt in throwing them away once they have served their purpose.Enjoy!

On the positive side, this colorful hand puppet is soft and cute, and says some clever phrases.  On the negative side, the puppet is rather small inside, and it is challenging to get a larger hand inside the mouth.There are six, built-in phrases.  Fortunately, I found it fairly easy to avoid the button that activates the voice, so I could easily provide the voice of the puppet, so adding more dimension to the six, limited phrases built in to the electronics.  However, it is a challenge to get my hand into the puppet and to keep it there.  After five minute of playing DJ the Dinosaur, I am ready to change hands or do something else.  Try getting a child who is interested in a hand puppet to do something else after five minutes of being entertained.Typically I would describe a toy like this as being limited.  However, by being your own puppeteer and providing the voice, in a way, this toy is somewhat unlimited, except for how long you can keep your hand in a tight space.  This toy would be great for a child ages 8-16 who is interested in entertaining a younger sibling or relative.  As long as you avoid the button that activates the voice, this hand puppet can be far more than the six stock phrases.Enjoy!

I suspect babies may be more amused by toys like this one than I am.  I do love a good toy, and I have seen some really fun baby toys, but this one falls a bit flat for me.Fundamentally, this toy does not do a lot.  If you collapse the toy (there is a trick to that, which I will provide in a moment), it does stay upright, but un-collapsed the toy falls over and stays over.  The ears flip up and flip down.  There are five beads in a tube that roll around and around, making noise.  Big deal.  I am thinking that this toy is going to be one of those that has a short play life because it is just not that interesting.Collapsing this toy is a bit of a trick.  First rotate the toy about 70 degrees in the counterclockwise direction, when looking from the top.  The press down and while pressing down, rotate the toy clockwise, and release when the toy has been rotated back to about 0 degrees.  If you continue rotating in the clockwise direction, the toy disengages and pops up again.I must point out that behind the cloth in the middle of the toy is a metal spring.  Even if the cloth comes off the metal spring, it does not seem as though the toy could be a hazard, but I am not sure.  I tried pinching my finger in the spring, and could not.  Given how heavy this toy is, having it thrown at something, like a window or a television, is probably the biggest hazard.  Regardless, I am not seeing enough excitement out of this toy to make a recommendation.  If someone gives you one, use it as much as you can and then pass it on to someone else, or Goodwill.  Otherwise, consider other, more interesting toys instead of this one.Good luck!

On the one hand, I like this cutter.  On the other hand, it is limited in use to boxes, packing tape, and thin wood.  I tried cutting the packaging for the cutter, and the cutter would score the package, but not really cut it.The cutter looks relatively cheap.  It is lightweight and just does not have a quality feel to it.  The front end of the cutter is angled to help position the cutter.  The cutter has "three" positions, but one of the positions is closed, so that doesn't really count.  The other two positions are cutter tip exposed, and blade extended a half inch.  Thus, the blade on this cutter is not configured to cut anything thick.I did go to town on cardboard boxes with this cutter.  Actually, it was fun cutting cardboard boxes, even more fun than cutting with a steel box cutter because the cutter really seems to slide through a cardboard box straight, versus a box cutter, which likes to skew in different directions.  Eventually the significant other yelled at me and told me to stop cutting up cardboard boxes.  It was fun while it lasted.A couple more advantages to the cutter.  It will not rust, and the ceramic blade should stay sharp for a long time.  The ceramic blade seems as though it would not slice a finger as readily as a steel blade.I like this cutter, but it is limited in what it can cut.  Cardboard boxes are fodder for this cutter.  Everything else is hit or miss.  The thick cardboard of the packaging for the cutter was barely sliced, and it would not cut all the way through.  I tried pressed wood, and the cutter would scratch, but not really cut.  Replacement blades are really expensive, while replacement steel blades are almost literally dirt cheap.  On the balance, while I like the cutter, it is hard to recommend it because it is limited in capability.  Then again, this cutter does so well on cardboard boxes, and I like the general concept of a ceramic blade, so it gets four stars from me, even with its flaws.Enjoy!

This tripod is fantastic for still cameras, either digital or film.  The range of motion of the head and the ability to position the legs is phenomenal.  The head even includes a motion I have not previously seen in a tripod.For the most part, the movements of this camera tripod are intuitive.  The legs have four positions, according to the box.  I tried two of the four positions, and movement is relatively smooth.  The only thing that was annoying was that I thought the legs were a bit harder to move outwardly than I would have liked.  Do not try moving the legs with a camera attached to the head of the tripod until after you have practiced moving the legs in and out without the camera attached.The head has all sorts of movement.  The camera platform rotates, tilts, and raises and lowers.  Even more interestingly, by loosening the handle that grips the post that raises and lowers the camera platform, the entire post can be raised up and pulled from the central support, rotated 90 degrees, and secured sideways.  Why would you want to move a camera in that manner?  Right this moment I do not have a specific answer, but as someone who has used all the motions available in a tripod, I can vouch for the benefit of having as many ways of moving a tripod as possible.The box alleges that the right angle ability is patented, which is pretty cool.  Likely Manfrotto was trying to figure out how do something different from everyone else, and knowing how easy such innovations were to reverse engineer, they patented their invention.  Smart idea giving them a unique feature as long as the patent is in force.In addition to the ability to move a camera in a bunch of different ways, this tripod also includes a little hook to hang a bag and another hook to attach a strap.As enthusiastic as I am about this tripod, there are a couple of things that I think could have been done a little better, which is why the four-star rating instead of five stars.I have a less expensive tripod that has a rack and pinion system for raising and lowering the head of the tripod.  The motion is really smooth, and the camera stays in position when not rotating the handle, though the rack can be secured in position.  In addition, that tripod has a handle to help smoothly rotate the camera platform around the center of its axis.  Why are these features useful?  Because the ability to move the head vertically and around its axis smoothly makes that tripod much more compatible with a video camera.As a still camera platform, this tripod is excellent.  The ranges of motion are outstanding.  Indeed, the features on this tripod are phenomenal.  The only downside is that this tripod is less than ideal for a video camera because the motions of the tripod are not all that smooth.  So, for everyone interested in mounting a still camera, this tripod's for you!Enjoy!

Board games involving mythical creatures have been around for a while.  This game is an attempt to put a spin on such games, with the spin being the negotiation for the dragon's hoard at the end of a round.The real problem is that if you have a person who refuses to be flexible, the negotiations end without divvying up the dragon's hoard.  Theoretically, a more introverted person learns to be more extroverted to push for their fair share.  However, if that person does not, then one or two people always seem to get most of the hoard, or no one gets anything.  It can get quite frustrating for all involved rather quickly, the game may get back into the box, and then it may end up along with other, non-played board games, until the reasonable people get their hands on the game.On the other hand, when this game is played by the maximum number of players, which is six players, it seems like one or two players push for the less extroverted players, and the treasure hoard is divided, and divided more fairly.This game is set up for three to six players, ages 12 and up, and is estimated to take about 45 minutes to play.  The game play seems relatively quick, but only because game play is relatively simple.  Indeed, one real problem of the game, other than the "negotiation" over the dragon hoard, is that the game is not really all that interesting for an experienced board game player.  It might be fine for a game or two, but after that, most experienced players will want to move onto something more challenging.I like a good board game, and this one is fine from the perspective of simple play, but the negotiation aspect seems to take the original cooperation needed to kill a dragon and turn it into a slugfest for share of the loot.  Other games with a well-defined end that provide an element of randomness to permit anyone to win seem more fair to me.  Maybe I am playing this game with the wrong group of people.  After all, these people are highly-competitive individuals driven to win in games where it is typically each player for themselves.  The cooperation aspect is not something they are accustomed to integrating into their playing style.Good luck!

Toys seem to become more and more complex, making all sorts of noises, with lots of flashing lights, and numerous controls.  This toy is a seeming rarity in that it requires no batteries, relying instead on child, parent, or grandparent power.  Press down on the toy, the front and back legs are pushed back, and release.  On hard floors My Little Pony Pinkie Pie takes off across the floor.  We tried Pinkie Pie on carpet with no pile, and Pinkie Pie rolled only a short distance, so forget about Pinkie Pie on anything other than smooth floors.Pinkie Pie's head also moves back and forth, but rolling and moving her head back and forth are the entirety of Pinkie Pie's skills.Perhaps not-so-surprisingly, the under three-year-old set seem to like Pinkie Pie.  Perhaps the enjoyment is that Pinkie Pie is colorful and scoots along at a pretty good clip before crashing into a wall, carpet, or something else.  For older children, the enjoyment may be that they can affect the function of an object in their grasp.  Whatever the reason, it warms a parent or grandparent's heart to see a baby or grandbaby enjoy the simplicity of their young lives with a s small or laugh as Pinkie Pie does her thing.Enjoy!

We have used lighter nitrile disposable gloves in the past, and been quite happy with them.  Yes, nitrile gloves can split easily.  Yes, you may go through more than one pair is using these gloves to handle objects that have sharp edges or splinters.  Nitrile gloves cannot be used for protection from certain types of chemicals, though that is true for most gloves.  However, if you need light protection for your hands in a variety of applications, disposable nitrile gloves are affordable protections.We have used another Ammex disposable nitrile glove, in light blue.  I was surprised that these gloves seemed thicker and heavier than the light blue gloves, and they are easier to put onto my hands.  In addition, the box is thicker and longer than the box for the light blue gloves.  As with the light blue gloves, these gloves are useful in non-puncture environments.  Similar to the light blue gloves, the chemical resistance of these gloves is fine for exposure to many typical household chemicals, excluding toluene, which is used in some fingernail polish removers, and some acids.  As with any glove, before using these gloves in any location where they will be exposed to chemicals, the user should determine ability of the glove to withstand exposure to the chemical.As with the light blue disposable nitrile gloves, each glove includes a textured area around each finger tip that should provide additional grip.  Of course, nitrile gloves tend to be slick when wet, so caution should always be taken when picking up fragile or heavy slick items when using these gloves.We love using disposable nitrile gloves when working around dirt and mud.  Unfortunately, once the gloves get wet and are removed, it can be a challenge to get the gloves back on again.  Often we wait until the gloves dry out to try to put them on again, or we just, as the box says, dispose of them.  Of course, once the gloves dry out, they go on again as easily as they originally did.As with the disposable blue nitrile gloves from Ammex, these disposable gloves can be used as hobby gloves, as examination gloves, or as protection while using chemicals to clean house, though some common chemicals can eat through these gloves, so check before you use.  The nice thing about these gloves is that they are so inexpensive that there is minimal guilt in throwing them away once they have served their purpose.Enjoy!

This product is a bath gel and bubble bath in one, with pleasant scents that do not linger after use.  Thus, even if it is difficult to find time to take a bubble bath, the bottles need not sit around gaining dust because you can use them in a shower instead.This trio includes three 8 ounce bottles of bubble bath and shower gel.  The three bottles are scented with hydrating hibiscus, nourishing milk and honey, and calming lavender.  The odors are mild, even when surrounded by bubbles in a bath tub, so no need to worry about being overwhelmed by bubble bath odor.  In addition, the odor remains mild after taking a bath, so no need to be concerned about an odor that lingers for hours after a bath or shower, which is a plus when being around people who are sensitive to odors.As has been my experience with other bubble bath products, it seems like it takes a lot of bubble bath to make a lot of bubbles, which is why I usually avoid more expensive bubble bath products.  Based on my experience and usage, one bottle is likely to last for only two or three baths, which makes for a relatively expensive bubble bath.  Even when used as a bath gel, it seems like one bottle is only likely to last for 6-10 showers, which does not seem like very many to me.What about the magical dead sea "essentials"?  Based on the ingredient list, it appears that those "essentials" are sea salt.  The only thing that tells me that the salt is from the Dead Sea is the bottle, because the ingredients just say sea salt.  Some people seem to think that sea salt, particularly from one or the other particular sea, has some benefits to skin.  I will take their word for the magical benefits of salt from the Dead Sea.Other features of this product are that it is alleged to be cruelty free, meaning this product was made without harm to any animals, which I presume includes humans, and it is free of paraben, phthalate, and SLS, which I presume is a good thing for people concerned about those particular chemicals.On the other hand, as a gift, this trio could be a great upscale gift for a friend or relative for a birthday, anniversary, or other special occasion.  Put the individual bottles into a basket surrounded by a towel or other decorative item(s) to make a house-warming gift.The only real downsides I see to this product are the cost and the screw tops.  Flip tops are much more convenient for use in a shower or a bath.  Indeed, it is really easy to put too much bubble bath into the tub with the screw top open.I like the pleasant odor from these bubble baths, and that the odors are mild, both in the bath or shower and afterward.  I like that these can be used either in the bath tub or the shower.  I also like that they eliminate unnecessary chemicals.  The addition of the magical Dead Sea "essentials" is of uncertain benefit, but as long as additions are not harmful, maybe they do have some benefit.  The only negatives are the somewhat high cost by my standards, and the lack of a flip top.  I would definitely use this trio as a gift for someone special, because it is an upscale product.Enjoy!

Some toys you just love instantly, and this is one such.  It is a little messy, but it combines a art with a toy to create a toy that is fun and gives a child, or even an adult, a sense of accomplishment.Essentially, this toy creates plaster casts of various dinosaurs.  The kit comes with enough plaster for six dinosaurs, along with paint to personalize your dinosaurs.  Put the mixer together, attach a mold, mix the plaster, pour it into the mold, close the mold, and rotate the handle.  After mixing for a minute, which spreads the plaster to the surfaces of the mold and likely helps remove bubbles, wait 15 minutes and then open the mold, welcoming a plaster dinosaur into the world.Once you have your dinosaur, this kit includes a tool for smoothing the edge of the casting where the two portions of the die meet.  After smoothing the seam line, it is time to haul out the paints and be ready to decorate your dinosaur.  Create a collection of dinosaurs for a shelf, or just because you can.The great thing about this toy is that it is a great opportunity to teach a child about age 6 or above how to create slightly more complicated art projects.  It is really cool to see a child create something with their own two hands that they can see, touch, and feel, though the plaster is a bit on the fragile side and it will not tolerate being dropped.  Consider the dinosaurs either a decoration or a very fragile toy.As much fun as this product is, the one downside is refills.  As of this review, the only refill I see is a kit that includes enough plaster for six more dinosaurs, along with three more molds.  That refill kit costs as much as this product.  It would seem as though for the same price as the original kit that dinosaur making materials for twice as many dinosaurs, or more, could be provided.  There may be other plaster and paint that can be used in place of the plaster provided by RoseArt, though I am personally unfamiliar with such plaster.  Paints that work on plaster are readily available from a variety of sources.Making the six dinosaurs in this kit, including the painting, is a lot of fun.  Each dinosaur helps a child understand how castings work, and gives each child to express a bit of personal creativity.  For these reasons, this product gets 5 stars from me.  The only downside is acquiring additional plaster and paint, which I consider to be somewhat expensive.Enjoy!

Swaddling blankets need to be thin in order to wrap smoothly around an infant.  These color neutral swaddling blankets are a perfect thickness to created a perfect swaddle around your little one.  In addition to be appropriately thin, these blankets are soft and ready to secure your little angel so that he or she feels safe and warm.In addition to being soft and thin, these blankets are relatively large at 40 inches by 40 inches.  Thus, these blankets should be able to hold even the largest infants securely.  The material of these blankets is 70% viscose bamboo and 30% cotton, meaning that they are all natural and at least somewhat environmentally friendly since they are produced from a renewable resource.About the only thing that I do not know is how well these blankets will hold up under multiple washes.  The wash instructions include gentle cycle and no bleach, so I suspect the material is likely somewhat fragile.In addition to swaddling, these blankets are large enough to provide a light covering during breast feeding.  Further, once baby is grown, assuming these blankets have survived numerous washings, these blankets can be used for all sorts of other things, though durability may come into play.Light multiuse blankets for swaddling can be a challenge to find sometimes, particularly when the primary purpose of swaddling is to make baby feel safe rather than for warmth.  These blankets are perfect for swaddling, including summer time when excessive warmth can be a concern.  Because of their large size, they can be used for other purposes.  The only issue is whether they will survive multiple washings, even on gentle cycle.Enjoy!

Unfortunately, I received this seed as a review product from Amazon Vine.  I say unfortunate because a requirement of the program is to review received products in 30 days, and these seeds should be planted next spring, which is long after 30 days, because we are at the end of the growing season and grass will soon be dormant.  So, I have a product I need to review without actually trying the product.Given that I am in this situation, I can tell you that I have purchased Scott's Turf Builder Grass Seed in the past.  The seed has germinated readily, but the challenge is getting the grass to establish in the spring before the weather gets dry.  As a practical matter, it is really challenging to establish new grass.  If spring is dry, it is unlikely that the grass will germinate, and if it does, it will not establish a good root system and by July all the new grass will be gone.  Even with a wet spring, watering between rains can be important, along with proper fertilization.Well, until next spring, the verdict is out on this particular bag of grass seed.Good luck!

It seems rare to me when the advertising for a product almost exactly matches the product.  However, that is the case with this doll; everything on Amazon's product page is (currently) on point.  Except for gaining a customer perspective, reviews are nearly superfluous.This doll is soft and cuddly, and while being a baby, is perfect for babies ages 12 and up.  Baby Stella includes a dress, bloomers, diaper, and a pacifier that stays in place on Baby Stella's mouth with a magnet internal to Baby Stella.  I love the magnetic pacifier, but I am a bit of a geek about stuff like that.The doll itself includes lots of fun little touches, including an appropriately rounded tummy, stylized facial features and belly button, and cute little toes, though not individual toes.  Little cloth tufts and a pink ribbon top off this cute little doll that avoids the stereotypical look of many competing dolls.One of the most important features is the softness of the all-cloth doll.  Babies and toddlers can be challenged with eye-hand coordination, and hard-faced or hard-headed dolls can end up colliding with a head, or something else, causing injury, albeit minor, or damage.  The softness of the doll makes it a perfect first doll for any child.I notice that one of the current lines on the Amazon page is that this doll is a great gift for a grandparent to give.  Speaking from experience, I must say that is true.  Of course, it could also be a great doll for a parent to give.  Additionally, it could be a great gift for any doll lover.Enjoy!

The relatively plain surface of a car seat has to be one of the most boring places on earth for a rear-facing baby.  Looking at the seat for hours has to be monotonous.  This image gallery addresses that issue by providing four panels for four different images, tailored for the visual acuity of babies as they develop.Recalling that babies initially have poor eyesight, four images are large, basic patterns in black and white that provide baby without something other than the back seat to see for about the first two months.  While an adult would quickly become bored with the images, babies seem to enjoy familiarity, and seeing these patterns again and again can help baby feel comfortable with a stable environment, even while travelling.  While a parent might be tempted to change images frequently, they should do so with great caution, because babies like seeing the same patterns again and again.As baby's eyesight develops, six additional patterns are available for babies above the age of two months.  While four of the patterns are just that, patterns, two of the patterns show a stylized baby and a house, which can provide some early teaching moments.Six more patterns are provided for babies three months and older.  These patterns include a stylized car, a sailboat, a fish, and a butterfly, and two patterns.  Lots of bright colors are added to the images, taking advantages of baby's improving eyesight and ability to discern colors.Likely the most difficult thing for most parents and grandparents to remember will be to change patterns, as well as not changing them too often.Eventually baby will outgrow the images, and it will be time to provide home-grown images, such as pictures of family members, pets, etc., to gift the travel activity car seat to someone else, or perhaps to repurpose the travel activity gallery as a wall hanging.There are so many aids to help parents and grandparents appropriately stimulate babies that it is difficult to determine which aids are the best.  Some parents have defaulted to electronic aids, including tablets.  However, babies live in a world that is far simpler than ours, and they like simple things.  Most babies will love the simple patterns included in this travel activity, at least for the first few months after birth.  Changing the patterns at appropriate times should fascinate baby and provide a baby, initially rear-facing, and later forward-facing, with something to see while riding in a vehicle other than a field of cloth.Enjoy!

This toy is cool with lots of fun features.The front portion of the Gup-S detaches from the main vehicle portion.  The back cover flips up to reveal a large storage area to contain all the extras that come with the Gup-S.  A holding tank inside the back lights up by pressing a button on the side of the Gup-S.  Note that Gup-S only has two phrases until you pull the tab on the bottom of the Gup-S, which can be done only after un-packaging the Gup-S.  The toy includes a single character (and you need more!), a rotating drill on the front of the vehicle, a couple of mini-sleds with an ice breaking tool and a claw, and a piece that mounts on top of the vehicle - a light, I think.  The treads on the underside do "retract" so that the back portion can be a stationary laboratory or base.I enjoy all the features in this toy, but the two that I prefer the most are the light up tank, which is a cool blue, and the lift up cover that allows access to position all the accessories in the interior.Does this toy have any negative issues?  Just one that I can see.  Forget about putting this toy in a bathtub.  Yes, it is tempting, but water, batteries, and electronic devices generally do not mix.  Indeed, avoid submersing this toy.Beyond the one minor negative, this toy seems to be a winner, and perfect for nearly any child ages 3-6, or older, like a grandparent.  Yeah, grandparents really like this one.  A lot.  Trust me, I know!Enjoy!

Frankly, I think parents and grandparents get as much fun from some toys as babies or children do.  I must admit to playing with this soft book for a while to match up the sounds and to learn the scope of fun.This activity book includes four two-sided "pages."  Some of the pages contain images of musical instruments that match sounds provided by a hanging portion decorated with a musical note.  The musical instruments include a saxophone, a cloth vinyl record, a flute, drums (of course), and maracas.  Beyond the five page sides that contain images of sound-making devices, one page includes an unbreakable mirror, and two outer page for covers for the cloth book, one of which includes the question, "What do you hear?"  The saxophone and flute pages include covers for the instruments, and the covers contain some kind of paper or plastic that makes a crinkle noise.One nice feature of this cloth book is that the electronic noise maker is connected to the main part of the book by a ribbon.  Once the battery dies, the noise maker can be separated from the book for disposal.  Alternatively, you could attempt to cut the seams to remove the electronic noise maker to see if the battery is replaceable.This cloth activity book from Baby Genius is a great versatile toy to expose a baby approximately 6 months to a year old to many concepts.  Included amongst the concepts are that fixed images remain constant, seeing oneself in a mirror, matching sounds to images, and the ability to manipulate an environment.  Because the activity book is cloth, it would be difficult for a baby to hurt himself or herself while manipulating the book.  This toy is a perfect toy for most babies in the target age range, and could be a great purchase by a parent or as a gift for a baby.Enjoy!

I read this book weeks ago, and have been meaning to review it for some time, but I was not sure precisely what I wanted to say.  The conflict I have is what I expected of Koontz, and what I actually got.  I expected a thriller or horror story.  Instead, I got a character study with underpinnings of the supernatural.  Was the book worth reading?  I will say yes, with a caveat.Our protagonist is Jonah Kirk, which is assuredly an auspicious name.  Jonah lives in a big city in the tumultuous 1960's.  Jonah meets a woman who tells Jonah that she is the city.  Initially, I wondered whether this woman was a nut, or whether she was something more.  Also, I was hoping for more interaction throughout the book with this woman, but we see her very little.  This woman also tells Jonah that everything will turn out all right.  That assurance is not precisely true, as the reader will learn.Quite often a novel will tell the story of characters central to "big events," such as crimes, solving crimes, etc.  In this particular case, Jonah and people Jonah knows are peripheral to the "big events."  However, it is the intersection of Jonah and the "big events" that provide moments of intensity in the story.  Much of the rest of the novel is about Jonah, his family, and friends.  Indeed, this novel is character driven rather than plot driven.  There is a climax, in the traditional Dean Koontz style, but the climax is not the end of the story, because Koontz deals with the aftermath rather than glossing over how people deal with tragedy.  Of course, he does not wallow in tragedy, but neither does he overlook it.Koontz fans are reacting to this story in many different ways, which is my caveat about this book.  If you expect lots of tension, chase scenes, and things that go bump in the night, you will be mostly disappointed.  This book is about the characters, and most characters, both in real life and in this book, try to avoid tension, chase scenes, and things that go bump in the night.  On the other hand, if you want to read a story about life, albeit a life that intersects with some very interesting events, and even supernatural events, then this could be the story for you.  I am certainly glad I read this story, which is the first time I have said that about a Koontz book in a while (except the Odd Thomas books, all of which I like).But, remember that I struggled with expectation versus reality for a while before I reviewed this book.  I pondered everything from three stars to five stars, before ignoring my expectations and accepting that the book I read was a well-written character study from an author who does not normally write such books.  How you react to this book will likely be how you manage your expectations.Enjoy!

These cross-training shoes are lightweight and comfortable while providing great support.  The mesh design provides lots of airflow to keep feet cool and dryer than leather shoes.  The colors will likely appeal to many people, particularly younger people.One theme that seems to be a constant with many reviews of these shoes is the difficulty of getting a foot into them.  Unfortunately, my significant other's feet went into the size 6.5 easily, so we are unable to comment on this issue encountered by others.  Another theme is the expected size of these shoes.  With respect to this observation, our observation is that this shoe runs about a half size smaller than other shoes we have purchased in the past.  My significant other typically wears a size 6, and the size 6.5 fit nearly perfectly.My significant other informed me that she would definitely buy these shoes, because she likes the weight and comfort of the shoes.  The only concern she had, which is a minor concern, is that the top of the shoe is very light weight, and she is slightly concerned that these shoes offer very little protection from injury.These lightweight, comfortable shoes are great for walking.  They can be readily washed in a washing machine.  While the sizing tends to run on the small side, by compensating for the size difference, it should be easy to buy a pair of shoes that fit perfectly.  Even better, these shoes are on our list to purchase again.Enjoy!

People have swaddled their babies for about as long as there have been babies.  Babies seem to love the security of being swaddled, and it seems to help them sleep.These particular swaddles are small swaddles for babies 0-3 months, or 7-14 pounds in weight, or up to 26 inches in length.  The 100% cotton is washable.  The material is not as soft as the material in some baby clothes we have, but these are swaddles, which can readily go over other clothing, so softness is a bit less important.  The swaddles are secured with hook and loop fasteners, which are easy to adjust to fit perfectly to any baby within the recommended size ranges.  The colors are neutral, so the swaddles can be used for girls or boys.One surprise, to me, is that babies seem to need to be held less often or for shorter times with swaddles.Swaddles are a great thing to help babies feel secure for sleeping.  The swaddles reduce the chance for baby to startle itself awake, leading to longer, more secure, sleep.  Swaddles can also reduce the need to hold baby, leaving mom and dad valuable time to perform chores.  These swaddles are color neutral, and washable 100% cotton, perfect for many newborns.Enjoy!

This tote is insulated to keep bottles cool or warm, as needed.  The tote includes pockets for all sorts of stuff, including powder, wipes, snacks, etc.  Of course, this tote will easily handle a few diapers, a small blanket, and even a change of clothes.  The plastic can be wiped for cleaning.  This tote also includes a separate pouch for a tablet, and another pocket for a cell phone, with plastic covers to protect both.This tote includes two hook and loop straps for suspending the tote from the handles or frame of a stroller, either for transport or so the a cell phone or table can be viewed by an infant or toddler for entertainment.  On a negative note, this tote is configured to attach to a stroller, and does not include a handle or strap, which would increase its usefulness.This tote is most useful as an add-on to a stroller.  As such, it has lots of competition from totes of various types that are larger, and often come with a strap.  This tote is smaller than many totes, which does provide an advantage for placing it where it can be suspended for viewing of a cell phone or tablet, but a disadvantage in situations where storage volume is important.  Before you purchase any tote, it is important to understand where the tote will be used and how much you hope to carry in the tote.  The primary value of this tote is short trips in a stroller.Enjoy!

What a great product for babies.  Snugapuppy is soft, plays music, hums, and vibrates.  He's cute and his electronics can be removed to wash him.  His facial expression is a little strange, at least on the one we got.  The one we got kind of looks like he has a beard, and his mouth looks like part of it is missing.  Regardless, we still like him, and babies are not particularly choosy about that sort of thingEnjoy!

This activity gym is the second or third one we have owned, and it is the best.  As with our others, it can be folded to take on the road, and the cloth portions can be wiped clean or removed to be washed.  The "three stages" are okay, but it is more the colors, toys, portability, and washability that make this activity gym useful and fun.Among the toys, all of which can be attached to the arches, is a mirror, which babies seem to love, an acorn with rattles, a soft cloth owl, a butterfly, some leaves, and a musical fox that provides up to ten minutes of music, sure to provide some entertainment for baby.  The musical fox can be removed to be used separately from the activity gym.  Babies love to reach for the toys to make them move and make noise.Some baby items need not be complicated or expensive to be useful.  Such is the case with this activity gym.  Its value lies more in its simplicity, ease of maintenance, and the enjoyment babies seem to get from the toys and the arches.Enjoy!

I will have to use this for longer to give a more comprehensive evaluation, but after my initial use, wow, I love this stuff!  I absolutely hate the feel of foundation on my face, but this "cushion" is the closest I've ever come to feeling like I'm not wearing makeup at all.  The only feel is that my skin feels softer where I put it on, not at all sticky or greasy or filmy.  I can't believe how much I like this.  I rarely wear foundation, but this is something I could see swiping on a bit of across my too-red cheeks each morning.I love the little sponge that is included (which has its own recess within the container).  Now I can put on makeup without getting my fingers makeupy.  I know I could have used a sponge with other products, but having the sponge right in the compact is so cool.  And it actually feels good against my sensitive skin.The color I got, W2, Light Ivory, blended well on my face, but it went on a bit darker than I would have expected, given the name.  I can wear it, but if they had a lighter shade, I would get it.As I'm reviewing this, the product is not yet available for sale, so I'm not sure what the price will be, but looking at similar products, I'm guessing around $25-$30, which is higher than I would like to pay for foundation, but depending on how long this lasts (I'll update), it might be worth it, even for a cheapskate like me.  I'm just really excited about being able to even out my blotchy skin so easily and without making my face feel filmy.Again, I'll have to try this longer to see if my initial enthrallment lasts, but right now, I'm hooked.

First, let me make it clear that I am reviewing this wig based on it being a COSTUME wig (the description does say cosplay), not as a real wig that you would wear day-to-day.  The matting at the top, as other reviewers have noted, makes it obviously a wig (it resembles a cheap stuffed toy at the top; it's all kinked up and coarse).  I think they do this to provide better coverage at the top, so your head doesn't show through, because this is not a dense-coverage wig with a lot of hair.Okay, so as a wig to wear with a costume or for your daughter to play with, it's GREAT.  The hair (except at the top) is very silky and beautiful with multiple tones and lengths, giving it (except at the top) a realistic look.  Holding the wig in my hand, I kept thinking, "I wish my hair looked like that (except at the top)!"  But once I put it on, I just looked silly.  It made my head look gigantic.  The color is absolutely gorgeous, but it totally doesn't work with my pale, rosy skin.  My daughter tried it on, and with her medium olive-tone, it still didn't look right.  I'm not sure who this color would work for (it looks great on the mannequin, though, doesn't it?).  If nothing else, these wigs could give you a preview of what you might look like if you dyed your hair (or bought a more expensive wig) in that color.I know wigs need to be snug so that they don't slip off, and, to be fair, I have a big head, but yeah, this wig felt a little too snug on me.  And I wish that the included hair cap was a blonde one (rather than dark brown/black).  But I like how the wig comes packaged, and I like that I could repackage it easily for safe storage.Wearing a hat or scarf to conceal the top, you could wear this wig as a real wig.  At this price point (currently $24), it's not fair to expect more.  But as a costume wig (maybe I'll donate mine to the high-school drama club), it's pretty nice.

I wish fish oil products were more stringently regulated.  It's so hard to tell if what the manufacturer claims is true or not.  But sometimes it's obvious when something isn't quite right.  In this case, Zenwise claims that these capsules have 2400mg of Omega-3 fatty acids (but keep in mind that this is *per serving*, which consists of two capsules).  But then here is their breakdown of that:EPA: 880mgDHA: 660mgOther Omega-3 fatty acids: 200mgOkay, I come up with 1740mg total.  How are they coming up with 2400mg?  Did they count the DHA twice?  I have to wonder if they really even understand what Omega-3 fatty acids are.  On the product page, they brag that these capsules have "2400mg of pure Omega-3 fatty acids, as well as 880mg EPA and 660mg DHA."  Um, what do they think EPA and DHA are?  They're Omega-3 fatty acids!  So they should have said "including" not "as well as."  They lose some credibility there.I looked up Zenwise, and it appears that they are a new company, started in the last couple of years.  On their website, the founder is identified only as "Kyle M.," which seems a little odd.  Why wouldn't the founder of a company want his last name known?Despite these inconsistencies and oddities, I think it's probably a pretty decent product, and it probably does have around the stated amount of EPA and DHA (but not really 2400mg Omega-3), so factor that in when comparing prices.The claim of "no fish burps" is tossed around by a lot of fish-oil packagers today, but I've yet to find one that lives up to it, including this one.  The bottle does smell okay upon opening, though (always a good sign), and the capsules themselves have a very light lemon taste on the outside, which many people will find helpful in getting them down.  I find it useful to take my fish oil at bedtime.Overall, this isn't a bad fish oil.  The company needs to grow up a bit and fix its claims (including learning how to add), but I think they have potential.

I love silicone spatulas, and this particular set has just become the favorite in my drawer.  I love the blue color and the translucent handles.  The handles are round, growing thicker towards the base (see the picture I uploaded), so they are very comfortable in your hand and easy to keep a good grip on.  This is an important consideration if you make something that requires a lot of stirring or folding.  I have a bit of trouble with my hands, so I especially appreciate how nice these feel to hold.  These would make an EXCELLENT gift for anyone with mild or moderate arthritis or similar issues.The silicone scraper part is removable from the handle if you need to get into the crevice to clean, but they are firmly seated, so they are unlikely to come off accidentally.  The whole things are dishwasher safe.The manufacturer doesn't state what temperature they are safe to, but they do say you can use them for scrambling eggs, so I would think that you could use these, as with most silicone spatulas, in a hot pan.  Be aware, however, that the handle is plastic and probably not nearly as heat resistant, so if you leave the spatula resting in a pan, you might get little dents in the handle from the pan softening it.Overall, this is just a lovely set that I can recommend without hesitation.Note:  The manufacturer sent this set to me at no cost for review purposes.

This is an average-quality set of soft, silky, and very pretty washcloths that are perfect for use on babies and anyone else with delicate/sensitive skin.  I like the set a lot, though there seem to be some consistency issues in color and sizing.I tried a bamboo towel for the first time only a few months ago, and I absolutely loved how it felt.  Then I got the chance to try a set of all-white baby washcloths, and I loved those, too.  So I was really excited to try this six-pack of colorful washcloths.  The colors I got are different from the photos shown on the product page, as other reviewers have noted, but the colors of mine don't exactly match the colors I see uploaded, either, so there appears to be some variance and uncertainty of what you'll actually get.  I know that some of this is just due to different cameras and different lighting, but the description (currently) says you'll get two each of yellow, green, and pink, but my set doesn't have two of any color, and it doesn't have yellow at all.  My set consists of three cloths in very pale blue, pink, and green; white; medium-shade lavender, and a medium pink with a slightly coral tone (see the picture I uploaded, but it doesn't quite capture that coral tone).  I love the colors, but the differences from the description, the manufacturers current pictures, and the pictures of other reviewers is a bit puzzling.There are also differences in size from one washcloth to another (see the photo I uploaded; some are significantly longer than others).  I don't think this is a big deal, but you wouldn't think it would be that hard for the manufacturer to get them all consistent.  Also, one of the washcloths had a loop that had been snagged and pulled out a few inches, resulting in a visible flaw in the washcloth (see photo).  There were a few other minor pulls in other washcloths, but I think that's to be expected here and there.The fabric is on the thin side, but I think that's a good quality in washcloths.  It makes it easier to get into nooks and crannies (a baby's ear, for example, or your lower lashline), and they're easier to rinse and ring out.The cloth content is 70% bamboo and 30% cotton.  The stitching isn't perfect, but it's not bad.  The current price, $15 for six, is comparable to other bamboo washcloths.Overall, I like this set a lot, especially the silky feel and the pretty colors, but if there is a specific color combination you have your heart set on, be aware that what you get may differ from that pictured.Note:  The manufacturer sent me a set of these washcloths at no cost for review purposes.Update 11-16-2015:  The manufacturer contacted me to say that they are no longer selling the six-color set I got; they now are only selling the three-color (two of each) set as currently pictured at the top of the product page.

I was surprised how vividly yellow and beautiful these bulbs are.  I have had other colored CFLs before, but the colors are often kind of washed out.  If you want a LOT of true color, these bulbs are the way to go, and you won't be disappointed.  Keep in mind, though, that all that color causes the bulb to put out less light than it would otherwise, so if you are going to use these to see by, you might want to go with the 23-watt version or plan to have multiple bulbs.I have not used these for a non-bug-attracting purposes yet because I prefer the look of a regular light on my porch, but we got so spidery on our porch at our new house this summer (the spiders come to eat the moths that are drawn to the light) that I might try it next year.  I've heard good things about these working very well for that purpose!  But these bulbs are not just warm; they are YELLOW.  I wish there was a holiday for which yellow was the dominant color.I do consider the extreme coloring to be a big advantage to SleekLighting's bulbs.  I've never seen bulbs put out so much color.Note:  The manufacturer sent me these bulbs at no cost for review purposes.

I was surprised how deep red and beautiful these bulbs are.  I have had other colored CFLs before, but the colors are often kind of washed out.  If you want a LOT of true color, these bulbs are the way to go, and you won't be disappointed.  Keep in mind, though, that all that color causes the bulb to put out less light than it would otherwise, so if you are going to use these to see by, you might want to go with the 23-watt version or plan to have multiple bulbs.I can't wait to use these at Christmas time!Note:  The manufacturer sent me these bulbs at no cost for review purposes.

I've had these bulbs for a while (sent to me at no cost by the manufacturer to review), but I didn't really have a good opportunity to use them until just recently for lighting our porch at Halloween.  I put the bulb in the clear fixture of my porch light, and it looked so cool!  It looks purple, which was a neat effect in itself.  It's not bright (so the porch stayed dark), but it made all of the white surfaces on our decorations really pop, and trick-or-treaters absolutely loved it (especially teenagers) as they looked at each other and realized they were glowing ("Dude!  Look at your shirt!").  It really gave our porch that creepy, yet cool, something I was going for.But do be aware, as I already mentioned, that this will not put out a lot of visible light, and the glowing-white effect is most pronounced within several feet.  If you want to make things glow beyond that, you'll need additional fixtures.For our purposes, these worked great, and I'm extremely happy with them.

This is a good jump rope.  The handles feel really comfortable and cushy, with recesses for your fingers to give you a better grip and to make it even more comfortable to hold.  The "rope" itself is heavy enough to make it easy to swing, but not so heavy as to make it heavy overall.When I was a kid in gym, the teacher said that the right length of rope is one that comes up just to your underarms when you stand on it and pull it taut.  The lengthy is pretty easy to adjust.  Pop off the caps on the ends of the handles (easy), feed the rope through till you can reach it and pull it out (difficult...it gets caught on something inside), use a pair a pliers to unpinch the metal clip (easy), adjust to your preferred length, repinch the clip (easy), poke the whole thing back into the handle (little difficult...I had a lot of slack), then finally replace the caps.  I shortened the rope to accommodate my daughter, who is about 5'5" (as noted on both the product page and the box, this rope is recommended for people up to about 5'9").  I was able to get all the extra rope into the handle, but if you won't need to lengthen the rope again, you might be better off cutting off most of the slack.  I noticed that after shortening, the rope no longer pivots in the handle because it is stuffed in there so tight.  But I didn't check it BEFORE I stuffed the rope in there, so I can't say for certain how easily it pivoted prior to shortening.  I went to pull it out again, but it's REALLY wedged in there, and I couldn't get it out (I'll probably have to take needle-nose pliers to reach it), but the pivoting aspect isn't a big deal (we all just jumped with plain old ropes when we were kids, right?).The box says to use the jump rope on grass or a "soft floor."  That's probably not realistic.  I don't want my lawn torn up, and I don't want anyone jumping rope in the house.  My daughter took it out and jumped in the driveway.  She'd forgotten how fun jumping rope can be because she hadn't done it in years, but it's like riding a bicycle.  The rope showed no wear from being used on a hard, scratchy surface, though it probably would eventually.  Fortunately, this rope is cheap enough (currently $8, regularly $11) that even if/when it wears out, it's practical to replace it regularly if you're a heavy user (but I think it would take a LOT of use to wear it out).Other than the rope being difficult to poke out the handle, I don't have any complaints.  This is a solid piece of equipment.Note:  The manufacturer sent this jump rope to me at no cost for review purposes.

I got this hat because I burn like butter, so I need protection all around, and I wanted a red hat.  It's not bad, but I guess I got spoiled by my Sunday Afternoons hat.  I didn't like this one as much because the brim is floppier, and thus kind of rumpled and untidy-looking, and the back flap just didn't seem to hang right.  And it wasn't as good of a fit for my big head (especially when I'm wearing my hair pinned with a big clip into a pony bun, which my other hat can handle).Overall, this isn't a bad hat, and I loved the bright red, but I just prefer the other style.

Things I liked:  The scent is very, very light (so I'm puzzled how some other reviewers thought it had a strong smell).  I can barely smell it, but the tiny bit of scent that is there is quite pleasant; it doesn't smell at all like makeup or sunscreen.  It didn't irritate my skin.  My face is very, very sensitive, and a lot of products make it sting.  But I tried this out on different days under different conditions, including when my skin was painfully sunburned and during a bad rosacea flair, and this actually felt soothing.  I am very, very pale (if "vampire" were a makeup shade, I'd have been the inspiration), but I thought this formula blended really well with my skin.  I was amazed by that, actually.  The coverage was surprisingly good.  As I mentioned, I have rosacea, and this really went a long ways towards toning down the red and making my skin look normal.  Anything more opaque would look artificial.  I thought this gave me a nice, lightly "air-brushed" look, not perfect, but like a real-life version of the "beauty shot" setting on my camera phone.  It just seems to soften and blur.  A lot of foundations make my skin look older, but this stuff makes me look younger (well, I think so, anyway).Things I didn't like:  As I was applying the cream, holding it upright, it just kept oozing and oozing out until there was a giant blob running down the side.  This might have something to do with my living at high altitude (almost 7,000 feet).  You might want to store it cap-side-up, especially before the initial opening, to encourage the air bubble to rise to the top.  As with most makeup, this stuff made my skin feel filmy.  Most people probably wouldn't be bothered by it, but I rarely wear foundation (and I'm VERY particular about face cream) because I just can't stand the feel of something on my face.  (So it says a lot about how much I otherwise like it that I've put it on several days in a row now.)  My biggest complaint:  It ran into and stung my eyes like a cheap sunscreen!  I couldn't believe it did this. I didn't even apply it all that close to my eyes, but somehow it migrated in.  Since then, I no longer put it on my eyelids at all.  That solved the problem, but I typically don't have this issue with foundations.  The price, currently $30, seems high to me.Overall, I like this BB cream, and I'm very impressed with how it looks on me, but due to the eye-stinging and sticky feel (and, yeah, the price), this probably isn't something I would get again.  However, if I were going to start wearing makeup every day for some reason (which I'm not), I would keep it under consideration.

I've had this step-stool for over ten years, and it's still going strong.  It's very lightweight and easy to carry and store, and I feel REALLY secure and stable climbing up on it.  Over the years, I've used it for countless things.  Every time someone needs to reach something, they say, "Where's the little white step-stool?" because it is THE preferred device around here, and it's constantly being moved around.  I used to keep it in my kitchen for reaching top shelves, then it was used long-term by my daughter to climb into a low loft bed, then my husband cabbaged onto it and started using it every time he needed a little extra height.  I've always been nervous about that because he way exceeds the duty rating (which is 300 pounds, and he's about 400), but it's never shown any sign of stress or wear from it (don't take that as a recommendation to do that; you might not be so fortunate).Folding it can be tricky.  I find that it helps to hold it by the top step on the back side, and then whump the feet of the front side on the ground.  This always makes the top step slide up like it's supposed to (you probably won't have an issue with it; the way it gets "stuck" for me sometimes is probably caused by the excessive weight that was put on it).  The biggest problem is that the steps are a bit hard to clean, but that's because the tread is very textured, which is a good thing (you'll never slip on this ladder, even if it's wet).  I wouldn't change that even if I could.There aren't many things I've had for so long that are still working so well and haven't given me any trouble.  Every household should have (at least) one of these.

It sounds like a good idea in concept...a glasses frame with interchangeable lenses...but in practice, it's kind of a hassle.  I'm sure I'll get better at it, but I found it kind of difficult to snap the lenses in, and once I did, I'd gotten fingerprints all over the lenses.  The frames themselves are okay, and are reasonably comfortable, but they come with a clear frame attached beneath the lenses, which reflects light and is kind of annoying.  I snapped that off, and that helped things, but is it a safety hazard without it?  There are no directions.The frames sit too high on my face, the top edge well above my eyebrows, which gives them kind of a medical look, like I just had cataract surgery or something (and the bottom edge is really too high).While I was wrestling with putting in a lens, one of the rubber nose pads came off.  It went back on, but it slides off so easily, I can imagine losing it.The glasses come with a little cloth pouch, but the case for carrying the whole set is enormous (about 7"x4"x2.5").  I would never carry this around in my purse, so, so much for being able to change my lenses on the fly.The clarity of the lenses is good, and I do like the variety that comes with the set.  But I don't think this is something I'm going to use much.

This is a neat little battery pack.  I have a lot of battery packs (I'm kind of known for always carrying at least one or two), and one of my favorites was an old, old (in tech years) model that had its own little cable built in.  I've gotten bigger and better batteries since then, but this is the first one I've come across that also has a built-in cable.  This is especially exciting for me because my daughter is always borrowing my battery packs and misplacing the cables.The plug is a little different than it appears in the picture (there's just one plug, with the Apple and Android connectors sticking out at a right angle from each other).  Once plugged into your phone, you need to push the power button to initiate charging.  The battery arrived 3/4 full, but the instruction pamphlet says charging from drained will take about 4 hours.The unit only weighs about 2 ounces, which I think is GREAT (the brick I currently carry most often has a lot more capacity, but it sure is heavy).  This is a reasonable compromise between capacity and size.  And with the built-in cable, you're always golden (and good for sharing if your friend has a different OS than you).  The only thing that would make this better is if the USB cable for charging the battery pack itself were built in (but it is included).  And maybe if it had a built-in flashlight.  But at this price point (currently $10), I think it's a fantastic deal, and I absolutely love the size and weight.Note:  The manufacturer sent this battery pack to me at no cost for review purposes.

This is a cool little bowl set.  My husband is always eating cherries and other things with pits, so I thought this would be perfect for that.  Unfortunately, the serving bowl is smaller than the debris bowl, only holding maybe a cup or so, much smaller than my husband would take for fruit (he gets a big bowlful to eat over the course of a football game, for example), but on the other hand...portion control.This set could also be used separated, with the bigger bowl being used for something like chips, and the smaller bowl for dip.Aside from being on the small side, I really like it.  It feels solidly made, and it's really cute.  It's not microwavable.  It's made in China (says the box), but this is not stamped on the bottom of the bowls, nor is even the manufacturer's name (Kody), so I worry a little bit about accountability and the possibilities of lead-containing paint and all that.  I probably wouldn't feed a young child out of it for that reason, but I'm not worried enough to keep my husband or me from using it.  It would also be great for using on a desk for office supplies.Note:  The manufacturer sent me this product at no cost for review purposes

I have a free-standing cabinet I love except that the sides are open, so the contents make it look cluttered when viewed from the side, plus (worst of all) everything in it gets dusty. I've known for a long time that I wanted to close up the sides somehow, but I still wanted light to come in, and I wanted the cabinet to retain the "airy" look it had. I came across a lacy-patterned contact film that I thought would look good in the opening and block dust, but it was not quite as obscuring as I wanted, plus how would I keep the sticky side from sticking to things and gathering debris?  Cover it with this matte film!I applied the patterned film against slightly larger pieces of this matte-finish film (sticky sides facing together), and then covered the cabinet openings, with the patterned side facing out. The overlapping film sealed the whole thing in place. I found the guide marks on the backing paper to be absolutely indispensable in measuring and cutting, making the project easier than I expected, neat, and stressless. This was the first time I'd used this type of product, but the learning curve was pretty short. The most important thing I discovered about joining the two sides was to let the film just fall into place. I pulled back the top edge of each backing, stuck the lace down where I wanted it, then grabbed hold of both of the liners and pulled them out simultaneously.I'm thrilled with how my project turned out, and I've gotten so many compliments on it, including from my husband, who is notoriously indifferent. I would definitely buy Con-Tact film again.

This is a well-constructed, practical product, beautifully packaged for gift-giving or treating yourself.With boiling water inside, the outside only reaches a pleasant level of warmth (nothing feels quite as good as a warm cup in your hands on a cold morning).  The lid is flat on top and is stable enough to securely hold the tea basket after steeping if you choose, but I prefer to continue using it as a lid to help keep my tea hot while I drink it.  I wish the lid were double-walled as well, because it gets quite hot, and I hate seeing all that heat dissipating when it could be keeping my tea hot for a prolonged sipping.  But at least it does have a lid, which is especially indispensable while steeping, but, to me, also while sitting.As is typical with glass tea baskets, the little slits allow a bit of the finer particulates to get into your tea, more than you would experience with a metal  basket (see the picture I uploaded of the dregs in my cup after steeping with this basket).  My favorite metal sieve basket fits quite handily, and though it won't look as elegant as the glass basket included with this cup, it won't let nearly as much particulate get through (even the best leaves have some); and, with its handle, it will be much easier to remove.  I found it kind of difficult to remove this glass basket without getting an uncomfortable amount of steam rising up on my fingers, plus the glass was just kind of hot.  So even though watching "the agony of the leaves" (a real term!) is an appreciated part of a modern tea ceremony, this glass basket, like all I've tried, just isn't that practical.The cup itself is beautiful.  A cup of tea almost looks like artwork sitting in it.  And, as I mentioned, it does a good job of insulating (pre-warm the cup by rinsing it with a bit of boiling water from the kettle if making black tea).  The thickness of the cup tapers near the rim, which is good, but it's still much thicker than I'd like, because tea is best drunk from a delicately rimmed cup.  I used to drink tea from a tea mug (I liked how the mug held the heat) until an Indian friend (who was raised in Kenya and the UK, so tea was prominent in his upbringing) snobbishly told me that we are not animals, and tea can only be properly drunk from a good china teacup.  Despite his airs (he did have his tongue in cheek, but only a bit), I discovered that there is some validity to what he said.  In a large, thick-walled cup, your lips are open much more as you drink, preventing you from properly aerating the tea (thus maximizing the flavor) against your tongue.  Drinking tea from a thick-walled cup is like drinking wine from a mug.  I don't even drink, but I get that.Nevertheless, unconventional vessels may be appropriate on occasion.  This will not be my everyday teacup, but I will definitely use it from time to time, such as sitting outside with my husband on a cool evening, or any other time when I won't have easy access to my teapot hot plate.  I've been sipping a cup of tea while writing this review, and I'm pleased with how warm (and for how long) this insulated cup kept my tea.  I write slowly (like I drink my tea), and it would have been stone-dead cold by now if it had been sitting on the desk in a regular teacup.Note:  The manufacturer sent me this teacup at no cost for review purposes.Update 11-19-15:  I've found that I use this cup more than I expected.  I've been drinking more single cups (as opposed to steeping a whole pot) lately, and when I do that, the long-sipping properties of this one just call out to me.  I have a lot of very pretty teacups to choose from, but I keep using this one because HOT tea is so important to me.  I also really appreciated the clear basket recently when I acquired a bag of very fine jasmine tea pearls, which would create a crime against humanity to not steep in a clear basket.  I've also recently gotten comments from others along the lines of, "Oh, I NEED a cup like that!"  So you probably do, too.

I like our porch light fixture and did not want to replace it to gain a dusk-to-dawn function, but I had a tough time remembering to turn it off and on each day.  I had looked at light-sensing devices you can screw in, but they tend to be bulky and unattractive.  So I was delighted when I found this bulb (I didn't even know a bulb with a built-in sensor was a thing!).  The current price ($7.50; I think I paid a little over $8) seems pretty decent for the added functionality.At times, we have thought it was malfunctioning.  It might not come on until later (darker) than you'd expect, and in the morning it might stay on a little later (brighter) than you'd expect.  And it seems to vary how much light it takes to activate/deactivate it.  But by the time it's fully dark, it is reliably on, and by the time it's fully light, it has reliably gone off.  I have never found it on during the day (even though our porch is on the north side and shaded), and I have never found it off during the night.The nearby streetlight does not seem to interfere with it, but opening the front door when the foyer light is on seems to confuse the sensor, and the bulb starts slowly blinking off and on.  But once we close the door, it snaps out of it and comes on immediately.  It's not perfect, but it does work, and I feel so much better knowing that my porch light is going to come on every night without my having to think about it, especially when I'm not home.  Now that's it's fall, it's always dark when my husband gets home from work, and sometimes even when my daughter gets home from after-school activities.  I love knowing that the porch will always be lit up and welcoming them.

I have a free-standing cabinet I love except that the sides are open, so the contents make it look cluttered when viewed from the side, plus (worst of all) everything in it gets dusty.  I've known for a long time that I wanted to close up the sides somehow, but I still wanted light to come in, and I wanted the cabinet to retain the "airy" look it had.  So when I came across this lacy-patterned contact film, I knew I had my answer.I applied this patterned film against slightly larger pieces of clear, matte-finish contact film (sticky sides facing together), and then covered the cabinet openings, with the patterned side facing out.  The overlapping clear film sealed the whole thing in place.  I found the guide marks on the backing paper to be absolutely indispensable in measuring and cutting, making the project easier than I expected, neat, and stressless.  This was the first time I'd used this type of product, but the learning curve was pretty short.  The most important thing I discovered about joining the two sides was to let the film just fall into place.  I pulled back the top edge of each backing, stuck the lace down where I wanted it, then grabbed hold of both of the liners and pulled them out simultaneously.I'm thrilled with how my project turned out, and I've gotten so many compliments on it, including from my husband, who is notoriously indifferent.  I would definitely buy this again.

I love both eucalyptus and peppermint, and those are the dominant notes in this essential-oil blend.  It doesn't dramatically clear congestion (I've been suffering from terrible seasonal allergies this year), but it does make my nasal passages and sinuses feel less tight.  I think the manufacturer's claims on it are a bit over the top, but who doesn't enjoy eucalyptus and peppermint when they have a cold?I keep the bottle sitting on my desk.  I wouldn't want to have my room scented with it, but I do really enjoy having a sniff of it every now and then.  It kind of clears my head mentally in addition to physically.  It would be good to use when you find yourself dwelling on something, and you want to snap yourself out of it.  Plus I just really like the smell.  If you don't like eucalyptus and peppermint, you probably wouldn't feel so positive about it, but I love this stuff.Note:  The manufacturer provided me with a bottle at no cost for review purposes.

These arent really that hard to use but there is a process. There are detailed instruction on how to use the tests. Be sure and wait at least 15 minutes after you have ate or drunk before you use them. The best time to test is first thing in the morning before youve even brushed your teeth.The process takes at least 3 minutes. The process takes a minutes and then you wait on results for 2 more minutes.Im cant be for certain how accurate these are. Ive ate extremely low carb for years so you would think I would have been in ketosis at least some of the time but these always came out negative for me. I dont have any other tests to compare it to. Maybe I just never was in ketosis.

I really like using self tanner in mousse form. To me, it much easier to apply it. If you are a little scared of using a lotion or cream, you may like using a mousse. Ive used creams, lotions, mousses, and sprays and prefer a mousse probably the best.With this product and this brand in general, there is no stinky tanner smell. Ive used tanners so long that I remember the days of having to shower to get the horrible smell off. This is absent of that scent plus has added good smelling scent too.The color is a nice and more natural look with less orange tint than you see from other brands.

I love this brand of self tanner. It has a cooler tone to it than other brands that Ive tried so it is much less orange. The easiest way to apply it is with a tanning mitt. I like to apply it with a tanning mitt and then go back over my whole body once more with the mitt to make sure its all even. Tanning mitts can be purchased separately, I use the one sold by the same brand.Besides the tone and coloring being so nice, it fades so evenly. I think that is such a stand out feature about this tanner. I dont get those unsightly, patchy spots. It just fades away evenly. It stays on for a good week and then I notice that Im just lighter again. No rough orange patches left like many other tanners.There is also no stinky tanner smell.3 standout features:no orange shadefades evenlyno stink

My 8 year old son loved this book. He was interested in it as soon as he seen the cover. It is a hardback book with lots of illustrations scattered throughout. The illustrations kept my son interested and entertained. He sat and read the book, retelling the book to me and showing me all the illustrations. He laughed and laughed throughout the book.My son isnt the most interested in reading so I am thrilled when I find a book that keeps him interested enough to read it cover to cover.

I love packing cubes. After the first time that we traveled with packing cubes, Ive been hooked. They are very convenient. You can separate and organize your items in your luggage either by items or by person. My favorite way to pack now is for each person to have a different color of packing cube so everyone can grab their items at a glance.This set includes 3 different sized packing cubes. The cubes are in a small, medium, and large. The are a very good size. One side is the colored nylon side, the other side is clear plastic. Each one has a handle.Many packing cubes are mesh at least on one side so wet or sweaty items can breathe. These have no mesh and arent ventilated. That isnt a bad thing, I like that they are solid in construction. It makes a good packing cube for toiletry items.I received a free sample product for review and evaluation purposes.

This is a very unique and pretty necklace. It was kind of hard to tell from the pictures on the Amazon product page what the necklace is really like. It looks like a mesh cord filled with rhinestones. It gives it a very lovely look.I like it and think it looks very fancy. It doesnt feel heavy to wear and is comfortable.I received a free sample product for review and evaluation purposes.I received a free sample product for review and evaluation purposes.

These knives are super sharp. They look like and are sharp like a ceramic knife but being of stainless steel construction, they are much more durable than a ceramic knife. I love ceramic knives because they stay sharp but I end up breaking them, usually on something like frozen chicken. These stainless steel knives are really sharp and have sliced through frozen chicken without breaking.The set is a 3-piece set which includes a 6.5" blue Santoku Knife, 3.5" green Paring Knife and a 6" purple Multi-Use Knife with a partially serrated edge.All the knives come with protective sheaths. The handles are soft grip which also keeps them from slipping in my hands.I received a free sample product for review and evaluation purposes.

My boys love wearing this type of athletic clothes. We are fairly new to the STX brand but the boys love all the brand.The shorts are a mesh on the outside and are lined on the inside. The outside stripe running down the leg makes them sporty looking. We found that they are a little big which is okay. The boys grow so fast that Id rather clothes be a little big than too small.The quality is very good and equal with brands much more expensive.100% PolyesterMachine wash coldTumble Dry LowMade in Egypt

I'm not sure why the cartoon characters are on the front. I would prefer if it was plain but the case itself is very nice. The case is neoprene with a soft inside. The zippers are very good quality. It has a double zipper on the case with a zippered outside pocket. The handles Velcro together.I received a free sample product for review and evaluation purposes.

There are more and more tablets in the market. There are quite a few in this price range. The tablets in this price range are great for casual use or for kids who want to get online and play some games. That's where we are at. My 10 year old is really wanting an iPad like all his friends have but we didn't think he was ready for something in that price range right now. He just wanted a tablet so he could get on and play games.I love the size of this tablet. It's huge and isn't overly heavy. It works well for the price range.The camera is just right for my son to take a casual picture. He loves having his own tablet and getting to play games.I received a free sample for review and evaluation purposes.

Why are Mr. Potato Heads so fun? I don't know but they've really stood the test of time. I remember having a Mr. Potato Head when I was little. Now, Mr. Potato Head has really stepped up his game and entered into the Star Wars arena.
