The artificial plants are individually detachable if you don't like that look, so you have some choices.

This is an amazing collection of music.  A value at any price, this album is certainly worth the money.  This music would make excellent background music during an intimate dinner party or even a casual gathering of friends.  Want to add some class and sophistication to your function's atmosphere?  This album might be the way to go.

To help give you a well rounded view of what kinds of Zoo Med bulbs are out there, I'm going to reference three Zoo Med bulbs I've purchased here on Amazon.  I chose to work with the growth enhancing bulbs after we decided to add live plants to our aquarium.With regard to this light, the spectrum of colors are definitely in the range of pinks.  My experience was that plant growth accelerated very well.  Over a period of just over two weeks, there were some noticeable growth benefits. However, the pink hues seemed oddly unnatural and my family and I found that to be unappealing.  On a positive color enhancing note, fish with red colors or red accents became more vibrantly red.Since we weren't wild about the pinkish hues given off by this light, we decided to try Zoo Med Ultra Sun Trichromatic Super Daylight 6500K Fluorescent Bulb T8 15 Watt, 18-Inch - This light is more in line with natural sunlight and the color spectrum is in the "yellow" range.  In the case of this light, plant growth was also accelerated.  However, I noticed that algae growth was stimulated as well.  With the Ultra Sun, to use the colors of our fish seemed to wash out; they appeared duller.  Of course, this light is the most natural in appearance.  I think we are just spoiled by the color effects of the other lights.Lastly, I've worked with Zoo Med Reef Sun 50and50 Fluorescent T8 Bulb 15 Watts, 18-Inch.  This is actually the first light we tried (before we began using real plants).  This light really isn't geared toward plant growth.  It provides light in the short wavelength blue region (more essential for photosynthetic corals and invertebrates).  While I found that plant growth was not really accelerated so much, the 50/50 light still acceptably maintained plant life.  My family and I felt that fish color enhancement was best with this Zoo Med light.  In my wife's words, our aquarium "looks like a tropical jewel" with this light.  Because of the blue hues of this light, the colors of blue fish are particularly stunning.FINAL THOUGHTS: Ultimately, despite the color enhancement properties of the 50/50, we mostly use the Coral Flora Sun  We alternate every other week or so with the 50/50 (when plants look sickly, we switch back to the Coral Flora Sun for extended periods).  While we love he color enhancing effects of the 50/50, we are obliged to use the pink hued Coral Flora Sun to maintain plant health.Of course, all the color effects are subjective when it comes to personal taste.  I just want to give you a general idea of what your options are based on my experience.  If possible, see if your local pet shop carries and uses one or more of these lights.  That way you can get a true idea of the lighting effects.One last thing:  You might want to price shop.  I've noticed Amazon prices for these lights fluctuate greatly.  Sometimes the prices are much better than pet shops and sometimes they are much worse.  If this is important to you, you might want to do a little homework before you buy.  I wish you much success with your fish keeping hobby!

I planted these last season (2014) and I had good results with germination.  I had some fungus problems with my tomatoes in 2014, so these did not have ideal conditions.  Despite the fungus, these plants did a fair job at continuing to produce despite yellowing and withered leaves.While the color and shape are beautiful, our family found this tomato to be lacking in flavor.  They are beautiful in salads or as a garnish.The dish of tomatoes I posted is mainly the pear tomatoes.  These were harvested just before the first frost, so my plants produced right up until the end of the season.

I bought this case for my daughter and she absolutely loves it.  She gets many, many compliments about it.  It goes especially well with a blue iPod.  The pattern is distinctive and elegant, but it's still fun.I bought this through Amazon from Importer520.  I ordered it on December 4th and got it on December 15th.  It went from California to Georgia.  I thought that was a reasonable amount of time for shipping and it was well worth the wait.  It was a surprise for my daughter and she was thrilled by how it looks.UPDATE 02/19/2015:I'm noticing that some folks are not very happy with their purchase of this case.Let me outline my specific experience with this case:1.  I paid 1.88 for this case with 3.49 shipping from Importer520 (which was listed as a USA Seller)2.  I got the case 9 days after I ordered it.3.  The case looked exactly like the one shown on the description page. It has all the correct cutouts (not just one big open space like at least one reviewer noted).4.  My daughter has had this case for 2 months and the corners of the right side are chipping a little bit. Honestly, it looks like normal wear (my daughter is VERY hard on her devices).  All other parts are still vibrant.  She still gets compliments on it.If you are finding that your are having a bad experience with this case, please take advantage of Amazon's A to Z guarantee.  If you happen to get this case through "Prime," you will probably have quicker recourse with any problems you might have.

When these finally mature, they make for excellent disease resistant plants.  Last season, about 50% of my seeds germinated (under ideal conditions where other seeds had 100% germination).  I was not happy about that.  However, of the plants that went on to mature (four of them), I had extremely disease resistant results.  I kept two plants and I gave away the other two plants. The friends I gave them to had very good results as well.I was struck with tomato fungus in my garden this last season.  Only this variety from Organic Seed Supply and Sungold (from another Amazon vendor) continued to produce non-stop after other varieties withered away.I disagree with some of the other reviewers with regard to the flavor of this tomato.  If these are vine ripened, they taste delicious.  They are perfect in salads or even just to pop in your mouth as you pass a vine.  Yes, there are other varieties that might have more flavor, but these are quite decent.  If you want extra sweet disease resistant tomatoes, I recommend Sungold.I had to knock off a star for rate of germination.  With so few seeds in my shipment I expected more.  Regardless, despite the germination issue, they make for a variety that is easier to grow once they get going.I just bought more of these for next season.  As of today (01/10/2014), they are a buck cheaper than last year (2.99 instead of 3.99).UPDATE 3/18/2015:  This year's batch of seeds was excellent.  Every single seed I planted germinated and has produced very strong seedlings.  I will try to update this again to let you know their progress.

This is a beautiful set of potholders.  The fact that they come in many colors makes them particularly attractive.  They have a nice terry cloth texture and they are adequately thick.  We bought these in blue.  We actually liked the generic color because it goes well with existing blue patterns in our kitchen.  Keep in mind that, as the description says, these are "basic."  However, they do not have a cheap feel. Our family is very happy with these.UPDATE 01-11-2015:  One thing I want to add is that you need to keep in mind that these potholders are smaller than the average size you typically come across.  However, for me this turns out to be a positive.  You see, when I pickup pot lids, I'm notorious for accidentally getting the potholder into the stove flame.  They often drape over the pot, and I fail to notice that they are draping into the fire too!  With these potholders, it very easy for me to pick up pot lids without having to worry about setting the house on fire.  :)

Nice, sturdy trash bags. They're strong and especially good for tossing the kitty litter. I was afraid there would be a scent associated with them but they're fine. They're typical garbage bags with ties that hold up well.

I was interested in this book because the author is a fellow alum from Barnard, and I'm interested in life changing transitions. Chaya is a terrific writer; her command of the language is strong and rare in a younger writer. She does a good job of explaining the different types of religious communities.  To an outsider, these differences can be baffling.Chaya led a happy life in the Orthodox community, where she always felt loved. She enjoyed a happy childhood. She also enjoyed some lucky breaks. A high school teacher encouraged Chaya to do solid academic work and apply to colleges outside the community. Chaya's family didn't block her, although she had to do some negotiation. She was lucky with her roommates and friends at Barnard, too.Chaya also manages to  humanize the community members.  Unlike the movie Fill The Void, this movie doesn't show the community as stifling. Chaya shows that women in her community could be stylish, smart and fun. They are, she says, like everybody else. The community members weren't villains. She loved them.Ultimately Chaya's positive relationship with her religion leads to my biggest concern with the book. There just wasn't a lot of conflict. Chaya didn't seem to need a lot of soul-searching. She didn't have to sneak around or sacrifice her life. She excelled in college.and even after college, she still remained in touch with her family. As she said, they guessed she had fallen away from the religion. The book forced her to bring her new life out in the open.Still, readers will gain insight into a world most of us will never know about. It's a good read.

I've never used this kind of product before. However, the directions were clear and I tried it with an ordinary load. To my surprise, some old t-shirts I'd given up on turned out looking almost new! This stuff really works and I'll be using it again.
Ordered from Amazon Fresh - delicious! Even better than the bread.

Not as good as Suzy's Case - the first Tug Wyler mystery - but not bad either. Held my interest due to good writing and complex but not overwhelming plot.Tug, the hero and POV character, is mostly likeable but can be annoying. He's quick to cut a deal: he's always in trouble with the Bar Association.  He comes across as dominated by his wife, who's definitely manipulative and close to abusive. In this book he reveals she's a lawyer (I may have missed it earlier) which makes her even more dangerous. I just wish he'd get some backbone.The other characters are practically caricatures. Cookie the dancer has been sidelined with a horrible brain injury that's hard to read about. (It looks like this series should come with a warning, Not For The Squeamish.) The subplot - or side plot - of the pro bono case is more realistic than the main story, although the solution seems a little too pat.The plot in Suzy's Case was somewhat more plausible; we were taken into issues of medical cover-ups and left to question the notions of fault and blame. The plot here comes with a far more mundane foundation, just barely believable. I was repelled by Cookie's doctor friend almost immediately. His treatments are so obviously unethical and bizarre that they're more of a turn-off than a source of curiosity.Still, I found myself caught up and reading (which is more than I can say about many mysteries these days). And I'll look for Tug's next case and hope he begins to take charge of his personal and professional life.

While some reviewers found the characters "unlikeable but fascinating," I just found them unlikeable, bordering on bizarre. Henry Hayden claims to be the author of novels written by his wife who seems fine with the program. They've done well and in some weird way it makes sense - she's the creative and he's the marketer.But he's got a pregnant mistress and some kind of strange past.  The mistress can best be described by words I can't use here.  Henry seems to be a little compulsive about all women, although he does love his wife.This is the kind of situation you see on Judge Judy, where you sense the characters are sabotaging their own happiness. I wasn't able to get past their flaws to appreciate the plot or writing. I just didn't want to spend time with them. Some readers, of course, will feel differently.

As expected! I rarely buy cosmetics like this for myself so I was happy to try.  I won't say my under-eye bags disappeared, but they were much less noticeable. People kept saying, "You look really good today!"Easy to apply, lasted all day and was fine with my skin (which is not especially sensitive).  I work at home but I'll be using it when I go out to meetings and social events. Good stuff.

For most of the book, I was enchanted! I loved Jessica's sardonic style as she described her introverted childhood, vet school experience, and her luck in landing a job in the same city where her husband works. Her stories about her patients and colleagues are delightful, without being disrespectful.Jessica tells us about her personal life too. Her wedding had to be planned around her new job - she got a musician from Craigslist! - and her experience with puppies and kittens didn't prepare her for welcoming a human baby. She's very open about the challenges of having a baby and juggling a professional life ... even with the help of the dog!Jessica's a good writer. At times I laughed out loud as I was reading.But few if any clients seem to have adopted mixed-breed dogs. They're all mentioned by breed. It's better to adopt and then use the extra money to pay for flea treatment, vaccinations and more. And there was a reference to her husband buying a dog from a breeder. I've volunteered with rescue groups. A responsible breeder is far superior to a pet shop (these days many pet shops have started sponsoring rescues, not selling their own). But why not go to a shelter or rescue group? If you're nervous, find a dog who's been in foster care. You'll find puppies of all breeds in rescue. With so many dogs who are homeless and so many shelters filled to capacity, she had a good opportunity to reinforce "adopt, don't shop." And many adopted dogs live long, healthy lives.

I used it to charge up my iPad from a wall outlet. The cord is very short so it is really designed more for using on a desk with a computer. It seemed to charge a little faster than the cord that came with the iPad but I didn't time it carefully. No problems with wear and tear!

Recently, a friend said, "At some point I'd like to go work for a non-profit. I'd like to do some good at work."As a consultant to career changers, I shuddered. I warned her that non-profits have totally different work environments than for-profits, and the career path goes one way. Instead, I suggested, why not work for a fun organization and donate the difference in salary?I didn't know this option had a name: "earn to give." But it's an option MadAskill explains in this book.The author presents five questions to help us assess how best to spend our charitable dollars, then illustrates each with a chapter. It's hard to argue with the questions. But coming up with data to answer them will be harder than the author suggests.For example, the author suggests that a small cutback in meat or egg consumption can have a meaningful outcome - a reduction in supermarket orders, ultimately leading to production decreases. But I've read elsewhere that faced with reductions in sales, cattle raisers will kill off some stock and produce less. They won't change their methods of raising the animals. It might be better to donate to organizations that lobby for humane production methods and support farmers markets that provide humanely raised meat, poultry and eggs.Another chapter suggests that voting is like donating thousands of dollars. I do vote and believe votes count - up to a point. The author illustrates with someone who's thinking of a career in politics. In the US, many of our social problems derive directly from lobbyists. In fact, it's been argued that legislators and even the president can't do much because the lobbying groups are so powerful. Obamacare was heavily supported by insurance companies who stood to profit. We haven't outlawed sugary soft drinks, which have been associated with many forms of poor health. I wish the author had talked more about the value of communicating with legislator; he does mention a demonstration that had an impact.Other data is even harder to come by. For instance, the author points out that the acclaimed "Scared Straight" program actually seems to increase teenage crime. The average person doesn't have access to this research and has trouble judging specific charities.The author concludes with specific suggestions for giving money, both causes and organizations. But what's missing is that, when it comes to giving money and setting up bequests in a will, we often donate when we feel a personal connection. We don't run the numbers.Although I appreciate the values assigned, I must admit I'll continue contributing both time and money to small, low-overhead dog and cat rescue organizations, where 90% or more goes to the animals. I do have other charities, but I believe animals affect quality of life, and animal cruelty has wider repercussions.

I got through a lot of paper towels with pets and more. I tend to buy what's on sale and they're usually okay. These paper towels seemed fine! I was surprised to see other reviewers describe them as thin or crinkly. I used them to wipe up grease in the kitchen and other liquids on the floor. I didn't have to double them up. They're textured which gives some traction. They seem as absorbent as most I've used and better than some. I don't understand what someone meant by holes between the sheets. Mine were pretty solid.

Five paws and whiskers from me, too!I've never had a cat tunnel before and didn't really "get it." When I got these tunnels as a reviewer, I was surprised. My cats are  approaching senior status (one is at least 15 and the other probably 11 or 12)  and they both loved the tunnels. Even my plump tabby crawled into the long one and peeked out through the hole on top, very pleased with herself!Both cats especially liked the string attachments at the end. They favored the longer tunnel but I've seen them try the shorter one too.The tunnels are easy to open (the button attachments that hold them together are  especially convenient) . They flatten for storage but I leave mine out. The cats tend to curl up near them, even when they're not inside.These tunnels would make excellent gifts if you know volunteers who are fostering cats and kittens through animal rescue. The cats would stay busy for hours!

It may be my imagination but I think my skin looks younger after I applied this Treatment Catalyst! I have combination skin and used in around my eyes and mouth.It's pleasant to use; I didn't find it sticky. The packaging works because you just use a drop or two at a time. It's expensive but should last for quite a while. I've been using it with moisturizer, as suggested.  I didn't notice a flush after using it; my skin my not be that sensitive. And, like other reviewers, I liked the vaguely citrus scent.Now, if other people start noticing a difference, I'm in!

I chose this book because I'm fascinated by identity changes. Heidi Neumark's daughter discovers that Heidi's father was Jewish. That's a shock to Heidi, who's happy in her career as a Lutheran pastor.Heidi digs into the family background. She discovers that some of her relatives had sought baptism as a way to escape the Nazi persecution, although at one time, the Nazis nullified these conversions. In a moving sentence, she points out that the faith she loved also was the means for her family's loss of their religion. She doesn't tell the story in a purely linear fashion, which will delight some readers and annoy others. And the book, while classified as Christian, doesn't get into belief, prayer or devotion; it could be read easily by an atheist.This book would be stronger with more of a storytelling orientation. I came away with a lot of questions. I'd have liked to learn more of Heidi's background. Perhaps readers of Heidi's earlier books know her background, but I was curious to know more about Heidi's background and what led her to become a pastor.While Heidi's search for her roots held my interest, the real story seems to be about Heidi's new identity and how she responds to her new self-perception.  She briefly mentions that she gets moments when she feels she is part of the Jewish community, yet she remains firm in her faith and vocation. Her response reminds me of Madeline Albright, who wrote simply that she had not been raised Jewish and would not be changing at this point in her life.This book also leads to the question, "Just what is a religion?" If Heidi had discovered her parents had been Roman Catholic or fundamentalist Baptist, would the emotional impact be equally strong? If ties to Judaism go deeper, then the question of something deeper than religion or nationality gets raised, with even more controversial implications.As a divinity school graduate, Heidi is more than qualified to explore these issues. Maybe she will in a future date.

I've been using a Yeti microphone and wondered if this one would be easier. The Yeti tended to give me low volume. So I was very happy when this microphone gave me nice, loud recordings. They're loud enough for me to edit out the background noise and set the gain to a level that excludes some random noise.It IS true that this microphone picks up everything, so you have to play with the settings and edit. However, I don't have to get up close to the mike to be heard. I can speak more naturally.I'm not testing the mike's capability to the max. I make videos for promotion on YouTube and Udemy. As other reviewers noted, the Razer works well for these purposes.

Sumner stacks the deck against her self with the prologue and opening. She warns that readers might think the heroine is older than 12.5 years, and indeed much of the time the heroine seems ageless. Aris (short for Aristotle) lives in a very small Georgia town with her mother and younger brother, who's also precocious. Her mom, Diane, has a New Age orientation to life and the family just doesn't fit into the town. However, despite living on an adjunct professor's salary, the kids go to a private school, The Labs. They're lucky: they'd be eaten alive in a public school.The book is framed as the novel Aris is writing, using her 30-day novel writing guide. There's not much going on, aside from comings and goings of this very strange family. We learn that Diane had married Aris's father, Joe, and they were living in Alaska when Joe was killed in a car accident. Diane's family moved them to Georgia and they remain, mainly because Diane can't figure out where to go or how to get there.This book practically begs to be discussed in a female-dominated book club. I can just hear people talking about Diane. It's hard not to be judgmental: she's just coping, not taking charge of her life. Yet she's kind and responsible. She treats the kids like adults, almost as if they were her siblings.We learn the dark side of the family background when Aris snoops through her mother's journals. Diane has conveniently recorded her own feelings, including her reaction to elements of her husband's past. The previews hint at a secret that will change their world, but in fact only Aris is changed, because she doesn't share her discovery. And she's not changed by much. What was more shocking to me was the way Aris dealt with her mom's journals. It's the kind of thing that only a child would do without really thinking about why she was doing it or understanding what might happen.The ending of the book seemed a little forced, in at least one part.The writing is so good that I had no trouble staying focused instead of sneaking peeks at the end. It seemed way too good for a twelve-year-old, and I'd be curious to hear from readers with kids that age. Definitely recommended for book clubs and people who wish they had book clubs to share their reactions.

I chose this book because I like basketball, but in fact it's not really about basketball at all. It's one of those one-year quests to achieve a goal; we're seeing a lot of those one-year diary style memoirs and this one's better than average.Dunking in basketball isn't easy, even if you're tall and fit. Asher Price starts out the year with some skepticism. Like Morgan Spurlock in Supersize Me, he begins with a nod to mainstream medicine. He gets basic measures taken, meets with specialists and creates a regimen of exercise and nutrition. He talks to his friends who went into fitness regimens.Asher soon sees results; in a pickup game, he's surprised how easily he moves. His whole life gets changed by the experience.Along the way, the book detours into basketball history. Some of this detail was more than I wanted, but I appreciated the author's effort to take the focus away from himself at least part of the time.There's one scene where he drives to Baylor University to meet Brittney Griner, in her senior year. She doesn't dunk and he doesn't get to interview her, but he's impressed by her athleticism. I'm impressed that he mentioned the women's game, which has been vastly underrated and generally ignored.As always, I can't help wondering what happened after that year. Was Asher changed for the long term? Did he modify his diet?And I came away thinking it's time to pay more attention to my own nutrition. I already work out but I need to start thinking a small salad should be enough for lunch. If these guys can do it...

These are great! They're good for taking to the gym or anywhere a quick swipe is needed. They're thicker and softer than many products promoted as skin swipes and they really work. They also work well at home if you're feeling lazy or tired. I didn't test them with heavy make-up.  I found they're easy to use and feel good on my face. I have fairly dry skin and they were just fine for me.

This rug is beautiful! The photo doesn't do it justice. It's high quality and designed to lie smoothy. The design is nicer than a rug I saw at a furniture store for three times the price.  The colors are bright. I am using it in my living room and it wakes up the whole room.I'm not sure if it is meant to go on top of carpet; I think it would be even smoother on a hardwood floor. But it's wonderful and the cats love it too!Disclaimer: I am not a decorator and not an expert on home decor! I just go with what I like.

I haven't read the earlier books in this series but I've been looking for a new mystery series to follow. This one seemed promising, with quirky characters and a  setting in Montana, one of the few states I've never visited. A body is found in the chimney of a visiting writer. It turns out to be a young woman named (improbably but aptly) Cinderella. Sheriff Ettinger enlists her old friend (who apparently has been more than a friend) to help find the killer. The plot takes some twists and we never forget we've got snow, snow and more snow.Overall, the book held my interest. The characters of the female sheriff (Martha Ettinger) and the male detective (Sean Stranahan) were intriguing. The storyline was intriguing, although the pace was slow and thoughtful. I liked the way the sheriff is presented as a complex person in a difficult situation - small town sheriff *and* female - without glossing over the challenges or creating an easy romance. Although the book is listed as a Sean Stranahan mystery, the sheriff steals the show.The most frustrating part of the book was the author's naming conventions. We have Ettinger and Etta, the mother of the dead girl. A lot of characters have similar names beginning with the same letter. The sheriff is identified as "Ettinger" sometimes and "Martha" in other places. I had trouble keeping the characters apart, especially in the beginning.Additionally, the characters weren't especially likeable. I admired the sheriff but she's not someone I'd want to meet for coffee. Sean seems warmer but he's defined by his actions. The book moves from one viewpoint to another so it's hard to get inside someone's head. On the other hand, these characters fit the cold, spare landscape, where survival takes a lot of energy. I lived in Alaska and there's some similarity.Overall, though, it's quite a good read. It passes the airplane test: would keep me going through a long trip. I'm now inspired to track down the earlier volumes, and suspect this book is not the best to begin the series.

After just 3 days, my teeth did appear whiter, although I have to make a disclaimer: there's no objective way to tell. I didn't do before-and-after photos. It's got a nice flavor and leaves my teeth feeling smooth and good. I got this from Vine but would consider buying in future. The product claims it's safe for enamel and twice-daily use. I'm not a dental expert so I can't evaluate or wonder what happens if you brush after all meals. I just know I liked it.

The Ice Twins begins with an English family recovering from a horrible tragedy. Lydia, one of a pair of identical twins, was killed in a fall. The remaining twin, Kirstie, announces one day that she is Lydia. She begins to act like Lydia. The parents, understandably, get worried: what if they buried their child under the wrong name? Adding to the mix are the family's financial difficulties - caused by the father's emotional reaction to Lydia's death - as well as marital tension between the parents and a move to the middle of nowhere. The family's emotional isolation seems mirrored by their geographic setting.Tremayne creates horror and suspense extremely well. She evokes a strong sense of place.  However, the novel  was hard to get into. Sarah, the twins' mother, was not a likeable character from the beginning. She came across as whiny and needy, not heroic. Angus, the father was not especially strong and just somewhat more likeable than Sarah.The story is more of a thriller than a mystery. There's not a lot of insight into the psychology of the characters. I didn't see it as a psychological thriller because the story was more event-driven. The ending was disappointing. It didn't grow organically from the story and left a bad taste.However, I went with four stars because it's the kind of book some people will really love. For me it was a little claustrophobic to be caught up in the dynamics of this grieving, totally dysfunctional family.

Choosing this book from the Vine list was a gamble. On the one hand, I was concerned that it would be a series of pious homilies. On the other, I've read books by Benedictines - View From A Monastery, Ear of the Heart - and I loved the movie The Cheese Nun. These Benedictines are down to earth, gutsy and funny. I like reading murder mysteries featuring nuns and enjoyed the TV series The Sisterhood.There haven't been any reviews. So I took a chance.The premise is that John Schlimm, age 31, finds himself living in his isolated home town, doing some substitute teaching, getting his life together after a series of disappointments. We aren't told much about his former life, including a stint working with Nashville recording artists. Perhaps Schlimm wants to dismiss his "sinful past," but the few tidbits we get don't sound that horrible. I'd like to have gotten much more background to create a context for this five-year period.Schlimm comes across as an enthusiastic, somewhat naive young man. He writes about the difficulty of getting a new job, but he's single and well-educated: why didn't he widen his options? Why did he see "coming home" as the only choice?An old friend introduces him to the ceramic shop where he meets the delightful, diminutive Sister Augustine. He returns for more conversation and even helps with some of the ceramics. Although he's got a problematic job situation, he finds a way to purchase some of her items. Ultimately he applies his not inconsiderable PR skills to help Sister Augustine sell more of her products.Schlimm reports his visits to the ceramic shop in simple, straightforward fashion. He doesn't ponder what he finds so appealing. I've taken ceramics classes and the impact of a first-time studio visit can be powerful. We don't get a great deal of insight into Schlimm's reactions and feelings. Sister Augustine's actual advice isn't especially unusual, new or startling. Forgive yourself. Take time to be in nature. Not really answers to life's greatest questions.At one point he writes about how much he enjoys getting access to someone who seems to have answers to all his questions. He doesn't compare this experience to others that he might have experienced or heard about, such as a close friendship, mentorship or even psychotherapy. After all, a lot of people are willing to give you answers to everything you ask!I can see why this time was so special to Schlimm and I wish he'd focused more on the "why." Feeling accepted? Talking to someone who wasn't connected with his world? It also would help to have the book divided into stages of his journey so we'd clearly get a sense of his new life emerging as he visited the nun.Ultimately, I have to admit I was somewhat disappointed. Mostly, the writing was not as strong as expected and even somewhat awkward. The author keeps referring to the nun as "my friend."  I love cats but ... "Sister softly petted Blitzen, who responded in purring whispers from her lap." And "she looked down at Blitzen, petting his thick calico fur." And more. A lot more.I wish the author had stepped away from his experienced and considered another angle. We learn little of what goes on in his life outside his visits, except what he shares with Sister Augustine. Did he have moments when he thought, "I'd better not tell her this!" or, "What would Sister A think?" And I wish he'd created more of an authorial tone as a framework so we'd get a sense of his personality. Peter Grethers did this really well, writing about - of all things - a cat.Five years is a long time for a young man in his thirties. Most people change over that time, with or without special friendships.The book is congenial and pleasant to read. Ultimately, it could have been much more.

Like other  reviewers, I thought the book would be a light-hearted book about a dog. I expecteda straightforward story of a woman who wasn't used to dogs who learned to love the dog. Alas, like life itself, the story gets more complicated.Mia falls in love with a terrific man whose situation presents challenges: different religions, different backgrounds, different prior marital statuses. So Mia has to adjust to new kids and a dog, Eddie.But the situation is far from straightforward. The dog isn't exactly cute and loveable. He doesn't like Mia. And in turn she's protective of her furniture  the sure sign of someone who's not a dog owner.Jim isn't exactly a responsible dog owner. There's no excuse for a badly behaved dog. And Mia  seemed a little anal about her furniture. Just get a few throws, for heaven's sake. Dogs matter more!What makes the book interesting isn't so much the dog as Mia's career as a New York Times reporter. I'd have liked to learn more, as she's succeeded in a super-competitive world.  I was also intrigued by Mia's Puerto Rican background and her interfaith, cross-cultural marriage.These elements make the book stand out from the usual "bad dog" genre.

I would agree with other reviews: the jar is really large! It's hard to tell the size from the photo. Other skin products I've reviewed tend to come in tiny jars. This one will last a long time.I don't have especially sensitive skin. I've been using it for a few nights and noticed a difference already. Definitely smooths and tones the skin. I didn't have any adverse reactions.I didn't notice a particular fragrance. And I agree with other reviewers that it doesn't feel like a typical mask - more like a very strong night cream. It's thick and creamy when it goes on; it's a gel rather than a paste, so it gives a cool feeling.Regardless, I liked it and plan to keep using this product.

This is one of the most frustrating books I've reviewed in a long time. With books like Singled Out and Going Solo, the choice to live alone and be single shouldn't be puzzling, especially to the kind of readers this book will attract.That said, the most difficult parts of singlehood aren't related to loneliness or existential angst or feelings of missing something. The challenges of being single arise from infrastructures and institutions that assume people live in families and come in pairs. Vacation packages, especially cruise ships. Health care. Restaurant reservations.  Bella DePaulo's book, Singled Out, captures the reality.So my first quibble is that a lot of this book just seems irrelevant. Women may be defined by their marital status in some situations but a lot of women don't define themselves this way.Second, the book really doesn't explore the spinster role. Bolick spends a lot of pages explaining her social life, which morphs from serial monogamy to what she defines as the dating norm: going to bed with a lot of people she doesn't know very well. That's a life choice.Third, Bolick identifies five women who function as virtual role models. As she points out, they're unconventional but not all spinsters. I enjoyed reading about them but kept wondering why we were getting off topic.In fact, I'm not sure Bolick really "gets" singleness, whether we call it spinsterhood or something else. At the end of Chapter 9, she concludes a very interesting write-up of Maeve Brennan by noting that Maeve had moved around frequently among hotels, writers' colonies, and  friends' cottages. She felt "asphyxiated" by closeness. "Had she stayed in one place and set down roots," writes Bolick, "we think to ourselves she wouldn't have ended up alone in a nursing home."Anyone, rooted or rootless, can end up alone in a nursing home. Unless you have not just family, but the right sort of family who will visit frequently and take advocacy roles, you stand a good chance of an abusive old age with the special curse of being isolated and alone without the joys of solitude and privacy.Finally, Bolick refers to her male partners by a single initial only. It's somewhat disconcerting. Why not just invent pseudonyms with an introductory note that names have been changed? Even if she used their real first names, all but a tiny number of readers would know who they are. It's hard to keep track of R, S, and W and this style is a little quaint.

This would be great for a book club, as others suggested. It's got a lot of angles that would lead to discussion and disagreement. As other reviews explain, TifAni FaNelli ends up at snobby prep school after being expelled from her plebeian Catholic high school. Like any teen, she's eager to conform and fit in. And since this is a novel with sinister overtones, you can bet she'll work her way into the most difficult, troublesome clique in the school. Naturally they're not what they appear to be.The novel opens when our heroine - now morphed from wrong side of the tracks TifAni to suave head-turning New Yorker Ani - gets ready for her wedding to the perfect guy. He's rich, good-looking, well-established and kind. OK, the sparks aren't flying, but she's getting what she wants.We soon realize Ani (Ah-nee, not Annie) has never fully recovered from some traumatic experiences in high school. And she's asked to participate in a documentary that will force her to revisit her memories just before the wedding.There's s lot to question in this novel. Who names their daughter TifAni? The kind of parents who seem distanced from their own daughter. The mother is a piece of work who blasts her credit cards to buy her daughter the right clothes and accessories. The father is a shadowy figure.Why hasn't Ani gotten some kind of help to deal with these experiences? She goes to a progressive college and in New York half the people are seeing shrinks. Surely someone would have made a suggestion.Then again, Ani's done well for herself career-wise. She's got a magazine job that's not exactly journalism, but she's paying dues and getting noticed.And yes, Ani's mean. Maybe it would be no accident that she'd be drawn to other mean types. Ultimately she's self-centered and vengeful.The plot gave me a sense of deja vue, except that Ani's edgier than most heroines in her situation. I didn't really "get" the significance of the action that led to Ani's final decision; I went back and read to see if I missed something. If I didn't, the final twist seems anticlimactic and over the top. A spoiler alert would be welcome.  However, I bet a lot of readers will predict the final, final outcome well before getting there.The writing and pacing are good, though.  It's a good book to take on  long airplane ride and I have hopes for the author's future novels.

Loved this bath mat! It's got a plushy feel that's kind to your feet. It's BIG: measure your space if you have a small bathroom. And check the colors. Through Vine I got one that was a tan and brown pattern. I can't imagine many bathrooms that use those colors. It looks okay in mine but doesn't really "pop."  I didn't think I'd like the pattern but it's much more interesting than the usual solids.

My 35-lb dog couldn't wait. I had the bag of dog food, still sealed in its box, on the floor. When I went out, I came home to find she'd chewed all he way through the box AND the bag. She's never done that before so there's the review: 5 very loud woofs.Luckily she'd eaten only a small amount. Her digestive system was ... um, slightly off ... but nothing to worry about. I've been mixing this product in with her regular food and she absolutely loves it.  They work especially well as treats for a larger dog.I've served Avoderm to my cats for years. One had a skin allergy that only Avoderm cured. Nice to know the dog products are good too.

The plot reminds me of movies like Harold and Maude or Harry and Tonto, where a person wed label as elderly defies convention and goes outside the boundaries. Ella, aged 82 or 83, wants to walk across Canada before she dies. She just leaves one day, taking the basic supplies with her.  Etta is the books central figure and become to learn how she came to be the way she is. Shes followed by ghosts from World War II and accompanied by a coyote she names James. Is the coyote real? Is he real but his special powers are imaginary? It doesnt matter. It works.Etta is beginning to experience what seems to be early dementia. Luckily she hasnt been locked away and (like many people with early dementia) shes functioning adequately.The books style will baffle or even annoy some readers. Theres no punctuation. The topics move back and forth in a dreamlike way. I was deterred at first but then came to appreciate what was happening.The ending was excellent. All older people deserve to go on an adventure and to experience, or even create, their own magic and mystery.

This is an unusual little film starring George Arliss as master concert musician Monty Royale whose young pupil Grace (Bette Davis) confesses her love to him. He's of course flattered but unsure of what the coming years will bring considering their age difference. He agrees to marry her if she feels the same in six months. However, near the beginning of the six month period something happens that leaves Monty unable to enjoy his own music - he is left completely deaf from an explosion. He becomes a bitter man who shuts himself away from everyone. He does take some training in learning to read lips so that he can deal with the world in his new condition, and this training leads him to realize that he now has the means to bring happiness to people in a different and more individualized way than he could as a musician. With the aid of some powerful binoculars left behind by Grace, he can read the lips of the people in the park across the street, learn their troubles, and with his large family fortune and influence, save lives or maybe just bring someone some welcome happiness.Soon the joy of living has reentered Monty's life, and he is happy that the six month waiting period is soon to end and Grace will be returning from California - they can be wed. He's people watching at his window when Grace suddenly appears in the park across the street. She sits down with someone and begins to have a conversation. Monty "listens in". What will he discover and how will he react? Watch and find out.In addition to the fine work of George Arliss and Bette Davis, the supporting roles are well played here too. Ivan Simpson is great as Monty's gentleman's gentleman who has no trouble sternly lecturing his master when he needs it, yet is such a formal person that he cannot leave the house -even on an urgent errand - without his hat, and there is even a very small part played by a very young Ray Milland. Highly recommended for fans of early 30's films. It has some precode elements in it, particularly the part where Monty is wrestling with God and his loss of belief, but I would not call it a precode at all.

Today, most women initiate divorces. But there was a time when it was the other way around since women had few options outside of the home. If you were a woman, you'd just better hope that as the bloom fell off of your rose that your husband did not get the 7, 17, or 27 year itch. This is about the impact of one of those marriages with an itchy husband, an unlikely cad, Lewis Stone as Marlett.I like how this movie takes the time to build up the characters, always a trademark of screenwriter Frances Marion. A great deal of time is spent in the beginning to show the respect and friendship wealthy author Marlett has with his only child, Lally (Norma Shearer). Then a tell - she asks her dad as they walk up the drive, what book he is working on. He says it is a romance involving a 45 year old man. She, about 20, laughs at the idea. Marlett says that the middle aged are made of flesh and bone too. That life is not over at 30 as youngsters think, and that they thirst for romance, that "last" romance, indicating that dad might be thirsty. When they get to the top of the drive, the slender and glamorous Mrs. Chevers is talking to Lally's mom about her son, Doug, who is away at Princeton. Lally's mom is graying, a bit overweight, a bit sedentary, and Marlett calls her affectionately "mama". Indicating that he thinks of her as first Lally's mom - and a good one - and then a wife.A year passes and Marlett and his wife are planning to divorce, as is Mrs. Chevers from her husband, but Lally yet knows none of this. She walks into her dad's study and catches Mrs. Chevers and her father in a passionate embrace, talking of marriage. Then her dad tries to justify it. He says that he and her mother are not the same boy and girl who made all of those promises 23 years before. I like Lally's translations - that perhaps he sees her mom as a fat and a bit boring "unlike the slick Mrs. Chevers". He says he intends to keep the house. She reminds him that doesn't matter to her since her mom is being bundled out of that house and Mrs. Cheever is being brought in to replace her. Lally says her final goodbye to him and plans to never marry because she will not be made a fool of as her mother has been, and the male sex has fallen mightily in her esteem because of her father's fall, which he won't even acknowledge as a misdeed.So off go mother and daughter for a summer vacation before mom goes to France for a divorce, which was the custom in that day. When Lally reiterates her vow to never marry, her mom is happy, which seems odd. Meanwhile, back at the ranch, Marlett is not succeeding at hanging out at his old haunts with his new mistress. They both get the cold shoulder from everyone. I'm not sure why this scene was in here other than to show that people did pass moral judgment on affairs and homewreckers at that time, and that a smooth transition did not await them both if they proceed.On vacation, Lally meets a guy (Robert Montgomery) who really fancies her. They dance, they enjoy each other's company, and maybe Lally is softening on men just a bit until she discovers his full name - Jack "Doug" Chevers - son of the woman who has ousted her mother, a symbol of why she decided to not take men seriously in the first place.So Lally is one confused girl. She has a mom who encourages her to play the field due to her own bad experience with marriage. She has a dad who thinks "until death to we part" is just a phrase people like to kick around at weddings, and she has a beau who is insisting on marriage now - as in right this minute. How will this all work out? Watch and find out.This is very good writing by Frances Marion who had already had a couple of short lived marriages that did not work out and one that did that ended in her husband's sudden death just the year before. Thus she could approach this subject of love from the viewpoint of someone who had seen all of the angles. I'd highly recommend it.

The amazing piece of timing here is when Warner Bros. began work on this biography of entertainer George M. Cohan, WWII had not yet broken out. The attack on Pearl Harbor occurred the day before shooting began. When the film opened people on the home front badly needed some morale boosting, and this film gave it to them. It's just a joyous musical costume piece from start to finish with nice comic touches balanced with some sentimental moments (supposedly Walter Huston's deathbed scene had even taskmaster director Michael Curtiz crying). There's nothing in the way of real conflict or even much heavy in the way of romance between Cohan and his fictitious film wife "Mary", who was modeled after Cohan's actual second wife in some ways. Cohan was actually married twice. Oddly enough, it was Cohan who said he wanted as little romance in the film as possible.The more I learn about Cohan the more I realize that Cagney was perfect to play him - both Irish Americans, both about the same size and build, and George Cohan's style of dancing and singing were about the same as Cagney's. It's hard to believe that Fred Astaire was Cohan's first choice to play himself. Astaire was a great talent, but I don't think he could have conveyed the combination of mischief, optimism and energy that was Cohan the way that Cagney ultimately did. Several people criticize Cagney's dancing here, but that eccentric style was Cohan's, who always considered himself more of an overall entertainer than a dancer in the first place.If you're "date conscious" as I am, there are some matters of plot that might bother you. Cohan was born on July 2 or 3, not July 4. Cohan's mother outlived his father by eleven years and Cohan's father was not "very old" when he died as is said in the film - at least by today's standards. When Cohan's father died in 1917, he was only 69. Cohan's sister did die young - she was only 39, dying in 1916, plus she was not his little sister. Instead Josie was a year older than George. The film has Josie marrying when she would have been close to forty, when she actually married at the beginning of the 20th century and thus was the one to break up the four Cohans, not George. Also, Cohan received his Congressional Medal in 1936, not as WWII began as shown in the film. However the plot device of having George M. recount his life story to FDR, receiving his Congressional medal in the Oval Office, and then dance joyously down the White House stairs and into the streets joining a group of marching soldiers in a chorus of "Over There" was probably a great way to bridge Cohan's patriotic past with what was then an uncertain time that certainly needed a dose of his optimism.The one thing that I did find a little odd - and one thing isn't much in a two plus hour long movie - is that it is hard to spot the actual point in the film where Mary becomes George's wife. There is quite a bit of domesticity shown before the two were married. Mary is cooking for George, staying in his apartment alone waiting for him to come home from the show, and acting very much like they are already married. The only way you know they are not is that George very subtly pops the question to the point that I'm surprised even Mary knew what he was asking! I know this doesn't seem like much in today's world, but considering that they were trying to paint Cohan in the most positive light possible and that the living arrangements might be misunderstood, I am surprised that the censors of that time never raised the issue.At any rate, I highly recommend this one. You'll have a great time, at least in part because you can see that Cagney is having a great time. He always said this film was his favorite, and it shows in his performance.

... you should at least allow people to see the table of contents!PrefacePt. 1 Instrumentation1 The Orchestra - Yesterday and Today 32 Bowed String Instruments 73 Individual Bowed String Instruments 514 Plucked String Instruments 895 Scoring for Strings 1116 The Woodwind Choir (Reed Aerophones) 1647 Individual Woodwinds 1808 Scoring for Woodwinds and Woodwind-String Combinations 2299 Introduction to Brass Instruments 29510 Individual Brass Instruments 31211 Scoring for Brass, and Brass Combined with Strings and Winds 35712 The Percussion Ensemble 43113 Keyboard Instruments 46814 Scoring for Percussion with Keyboard Alone or in Combination 486Pt. 2 Orchestration15 Scoring for Orchestra 54716 The Orchestra as Accompanist 61117 Transcribing for Orchestra 66618 The Preparation of Score and Parts 75719 Scoring for Band or Wind Ensemble 772 App. A: Quick Reference Guides 785 App. B: Select Bibliography 797 Acknowledgments 807 Index 815

...the cost of which ironically drove the Laemmles into bankruptcy and caused them to lose the studio after 25 years. Of the three versions this is the version that splits the difference of being truest to the novel, truest to the original musical produced by showman Ziegfeld, and the most entertaining unless you are one of those millenials who just cannot stomach anything not in color, in which case, I pity you.Irene Dunne plays the role of Magnolia Hawks, daughter of the captain of a Missisippi showboat and his hatchet faced shrew of a wife., When we are first introduced to Magnolia she is a teenager. This is probably the strangest part of the film - watching 37 year old Irene Dunne parade around as a wide eyed 17 year old. Irene Dunne was always a beautiful lady, but it is a stretch to believe her as a naive teenager at this point in her life.The cast here is just wonderful. There is the tragic Helen Morgan as the equally tragic Julie who is hiding what in that time would be a terrible secret. Alan Jones plays Gaylord Ravenal, who is as pretensive as his name and a coward in the face of tough times to boot - Magnolia makes the mistake of loving AND marrying AND having a child with the weasel. He is off winning a big gambling pot when Magnolia is giving birth, and when Magnolia's mother complains about his absence he takes wife and infant off of the boat, just assuming that the good gambling times will continue to roll. They do not. Here Jones is just right for the part for completely unflattering reasons. He LOOKS like a man who'd get going when the going gets tough, leaving wife and daughter penniless and estranged from her parents.Then there is Hattie McDaniel as Queenie and Paul Robeson as her husband Joe, both workers on the showboat. Paul Robeson gives an unforgettable rendition of "Old Man River". Nobody else who ever sang the song could even begin to measure up to his voice and to his impassioned delivery.The end was just a little too much for me to take, having read the book. Now I realize that just about everybody dying, as happened in the novel, is just not going to work on film, but I would have handled the return of Ravenal the Rat after some 20 years of complete abandonment of wife and daughter somewhat differently than Magnolia.Magnolia is at the end of a successful singing career that she was forced to cultivate after her husband deserted her, and her daughter Kim is just launching hers. It is a big affair, and time has not been kind to Gaylord Ravenal. Long having given up gambling as a profession he is now a lowly theatre watchman in ragged clothes looking much older than his age. He has the nerve to show up at Magnolia's box - where her entire family is - and turn into a duet a song that Magnolia is singing to the audience as one last performance in her career. I would have thrown that cowardly rat husband of hers right off the balcony, my foot firmly planted into his bony behind. This is one place where having a little bit of her mother in her might have helped Magnolia. The only change I'd make to a near perfect film. Highly recommended.

... or at least that seems to be the case for Daniel Pardway (Lionel Barrymore) as he comes to Chicago with his new bride shortly after the great fire of 1871. Daniel sees in this fire opportunity, and he builds a great department store "The Bazaar" in its aftermath. In the meantime, on the personal front, he and his wife have four children. Daniel's wife dies due to complications of the birth of the fourth, Freddie. With his wife dead, Daniel pours all of his energy into both his store and his children, with the hope, rather the expectation, that the children will have as much enthusiasm for the store as he does.In the meantime, Daniel overlooks loyal employee Abe Ullman (Gregory Ratoff), who has been with him since his first sale, first as a customer arguing that the price is too high, and five seconds later as an employee telling the throngs of customers that this is a great deal. Ultimately he becomes the general manager of the store for decades.I'll stop describing the plot right here, because it would be too easy to give it away by saying anymore. Let me just say this is a great tribute to the acting of everyone involved. Lionel Barrymore was 55 years old when he made this film, and at the beginning he seems every inch an energetic 25 year old for which the sky is the limit. During the film he realistically ages from 25 to a decade past his actual age. Gregory Ratoff was really a revelation here. I'm accustomed to seeing him play hypertensive bosses with few brains, but here he shows a great deal of range and mystery. Is he just a hired man for an unappreciative boss who often makes him a verbal punching bag for life's frustrations, or is he perhaps actually looking out for himself? Watch and find out whether and how.Of the four Pardway children, I thought Eric Linden was the standout. Over at Warner Brothers he was usually given "Gee Whiz" Jimmy Olsen like parts. Here he gets to play a real rotten apple with no gratitude and seemingly no conscience.Good acting, good camera-work, good direction, and for a plot that seems to be going by the numbers, a couple of surprises at the end - I'd recommend it.

... but there is a tenth edition coming out in less than four months, so you might want to hold off and purchase that one. My opinion as a Java programmer since Java 2 came out in 1998 - The Core Java series is the best way to learn Java. I've been updating my editions over the years and it has been worth it. The new version is here - [[ 0134177304: Core Java Fundamentals 10th Edition]].

...or at least the end of television as we once knew it. It was all such a simple yet diabolical plan. Get a group of random people together, divide them into two "tribes" and pit each of them against each other, collectively and individually for a great sum of money. Maybe they were eccentric and weird before, maybe not. But tell them one hundred million people are watching and they WILL become eccentric and weird so they can claim their 15 minutes of fame as well as all of the money.The awful truth is people will lie, cheat, and steal when you give them a great enough reward (the cash) with great enough hardships - no shelter, not enough food, harsh weather. This ain't Gilligan's Island my friends.I've told you how this was such a simple plan. Now I will tell you how it was diabolical. It destroyed television as we had known it since its inception. It got huge ratings, partly because of the spectacle, partly because the audience became attached to "the islanders", and partly because people could feel better about themselves because each of us felt we would never sink so low.Networks figured out that no longer do you need paid actors or writers or art design. Just find some random group of awful people in normal situations or normal people in awful situations and watch the feeding frenzy. And then it spread from the networks to cable. A&E, which once aired "Breakfast with the Arts" now shows stuff like Duck Dynasty, Dog The Bounty Hunter, and Hoarders. The Discovery Channel? Gone was investigative reporter Bill Kurtis and Walking With Dinosaurs, in with "Naked and Afraid" and "Moonshiners".As for soap operas? Not exactly the apex of quality television, yet a guilty pleasure for quite a few, even myself in my college years. But it was scripted and required paid actors. Why pay Susan Lucci to act awful into her 60's on "All My Children" when you can get some Bridezilla to act like a rutting pig for free? So one by one the soap operas fell, until only a handful still exist.Why my rating of 2? I'd give it a 5 for being a milestone in television history, although it's a bad milestone. I give it a zero for having any redeeming value whatsoever and for  influencing television for the worse - it's an absolute miracle that something as good and as original as Big Bang Theory could take root and thrive in this environment. 5/2 = 2.5. Rounding down it gets a 2.Coming soon - my review of "Walking Dead", where Survivor finally becomes scripted.

Gun Crazy was an independent production made without any big name stars, yet it fascinates me and I pull it out every now and then for a repeat viewing. The script when laid out blow by blow seems almost pedestrian - a Bonnie and Clyde story with no real surprises but without the Depression as a backdrop as a possible motivation for all of this mayhem.Unlike Bonnie and Clyde, though, this story is set in booming post-war America. Bart is a guy who loves guns but cannot kill. He killed a chick once as a child and as a result of the overwhelming remorse he felt cannot even bring himself to shoot a menacing animal with a bounty on it years later. Bart has good friends, a sister who seems to be well grounded and has been taking care of Bart since their parents' death, yet he commits a crime to get a gun when he's about fourteen when he's got to know this seemingly impulsive act will mean he's caught almost immediately - he is. He's sent to reform school for the theft, goes into the Army for four years but does not see combat, and here it is the present - 1950 - and he's returned home for a visit.So here Bart is an adult, he has good support from family and friends but he's still gun crazy and has the misfortune of running into sure shot Annie Laurie (Peggy Cummins), a little lady who has big dreams without the problem of a pesky conscience. So Bart's dilemma is that of so many in film noir - a bad set of coincidences coupled with a fundamental character flaw - he just can't say no to Annie Laurie. If he hadn't gone to the carnival that night and done trick shooting against Annie Laurie in a scene that sure looks like foreplay with guns, he probably would have gotten that job with Remington for forty bucks a week and been happy with that. But here he is, in the sexual clutches of a femme fatale who is "dead behind these eyes" - to quote another movie entirely.Initially, Annie seems to pick Bart because he is a straight arrow, someone who genuinely cares for her, and right before they marry she even vows to "try to be good". Bart goes for Annie Laurie because he can't believe that a girl so pretty and so exciting seems to "get" him and actually wants an ordinary working stiff like himself - but isn't this how so many guys feel on their wedding day?Ultimately their curse is their first impressions of each other were correct - Bart is basically a straight arrow, and Annie Laurie is exciting and craves a constant high level of excitement - and danger - in her life. So to keep Annie, Bart has to feed her with big wads of cash and even bigger wads of excitement that can only come from robbery, and with armed robbery there's always the chance of murder, and we all know what happens to murderers in the age of the production code.This film is so visually interesting. One reason I think I like it so much is I like to look around in a scene and just not at the players. Also it has that great and powerful score going for it and Bart and Annie's song "Mad About You" which is so true of both of them but in very different ways. Plus you never get "inside" the characters to find out why they might have turned out this way. Why is Bart so weak? Why is Annie so bad? Remember, this may be 1950, but these two grew up in the Depression and who knows what they saw as kids. It's all left for you to fill in the blanks. Highly recommended.

The author did a great job of outlining topics of interest in image processing for cinema, and then proceeded to describe everything in the most confusing manner possible.. When he describes algorithms he will say something like "Step 1 - remove high frequency components from image". Well, that's great, but how exactly do you do that?  He never shows example image matrices or example convolutions with actual numbers in them to convey his point, and there are very few illustrations of what exactly you are doing. For example, it is not difficult to understand deinterlacing from an image of multiple frames and some equations, but instead the author mainly just talks about the concept. I already know about these concepts, SHOW ME HOW.  And show me how in algorithms with concise steps and DESCRIBE the actual steps with equations. There are plenty of images in the book, but they are mainly before and after images. Thanks  but no thanks, because I already know what the image should look like if the artifact is gone!I really wanted to like this book. Too bad. Especially too bad because the author has a background in electrical engineering and computer science, so I would expect a book that speaks to the algorithm writing audience.

Many of these films are already on DVD. Let me go through my collection and see what I have as far as Universal-owned Paramounts:The Bing Crosby Collection (College Humor / We're Not Dressing / Here Is My Heart / Mississippi / Sing You Sinners / Welcome Stranger)Birth of the Blues/Blue SkiesConnecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court/Emperor WaltzOn the Road With Bob Hope and Bing Crosby Collection (Road to Singapore/Road to Zanzibar/Road to Morocco/Road to Utopia)Holiday InnGoing my WayBing Crosby: Screen Legend Collection (Double or Nothing / East Side of Heaven / Here Come the Waves / If I Had My Way / Waikiki Wedding)What is in this collection:College HumorWe're Not Dressing:Here is My Heart MississippiRhythm on the Range:Waikiki WeddingDouble or Nothing Sing You Sinners:East Side of Heaven American Masters: Bing Crosby Rediscovered  If I Had My Way Rhythm on the River:Birth of the Blues: Holiday Inn:Going My Way:Here Come the Waves Blue SkiesWelcome Stranger: Variety Girl The Emperor WaltzA Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court:Road to Singapore:Road to ZanzibarRoad to Morocco: Road to Utopia:What is missing: Rhythm on the Range/Rhythm on the River which has been available for a long time on a double feature DVD.  Variety Girl (overpriced Universal Vault DVD-R just recently released  American Masters - Bing Crosby  - available on DVD  just recently released.So I can get everything I'm missing on Amazon for MUCH less than the sale price of this set. The only thing I can't get is a pressed version of Variety Girl, which is in this set.  Bottom line - putting out the cinematic works of major popular stars in drips and drabs over the years and then FINALLY putting everything you ever had into one giant set is very annoying. Universal - do you think Bing fans have just been sitting and waiting for you to put all of this stuff out in one big box or, like me, wouldn't you realize they were afraid that the sets might go out of print and get into the hands of scalpers where we would never see them at a reasonable prices again? As Exhibit A I give you 1980's "Fatso" which is not that great of a movie, originally retailed on DVD at ten bucks but is now being held for ransom by scalpers at 150 bucks.The cinematic works of Bing Crosby on DVD = 5 starsThis bait and switch sales tactic  = 1 starI average this together to get three stars.

This is the view of speech and audio signal processing from 10000 feet. There really aren't enough details here to learn any new mathematical techniques. Don't pay these high prices for this book, it really is not worth it. Get a good book on signal processing and then I'd pick the book on Speech and Language processing by Jurafsky. This combo is more expensive than this book, but at least you will know enough to design something when you are finished reading them. Just my two cents.
So just take two of these if you can't find the extra strength formula, which has been hard to find as of late. They are exactly the same.

If you buy only one of these overpriced Universal MODs, buy this one! If you buy two buy "If I Were King", but that is another story. I'd like to think that Dick Powell was wealthy enough by 1951 that he could largely pick his projects, because this one is a gem of Dick Powell parodying the Dick Powell private investigators  of the noirs. He plays a German Shepherd dog who inherits a large fortune from an eccentric owner and then is murdered by poison. When he arrives in Animal Heaven he says he knows who the murderer is and wants time back on earth to bring the murderer to justice. It's nor juar his untimely death that requires justice, though, because his kindly keeper was next in line for the estate, and down on earth she is suspect number one, so he also wants to clear her name in the process. He is given that chance, but he must return to Animal Heaven by the new moon or forever remain a "Humanimal" - human in form, animal in nature. To become a humanimal and return to earth not knowing that you are one is the punishment of bad animals. Rex will return knowing his state and his mission. He is given a deceased Kentucky race horse as his companion and helper on his mission.It's just hilarious seeing Dick Powell sitting in a PI office as Rex Shepherd, talking like Philip Marlowe and nibbling on dog kibble instead of peanuts. Goldie, his human-horse companion, has hat styles that are pure palomino. The murderer is no mystery - you learn the identity pretty much up front. The trick is catching the perpetrator. Also, as a human, Rex finds he is having new rather confusing feelings for the woman who was his keeper during his life as a dog. How can this all work out and not bust the production code? Watch and find out.Let me also say that the transfer is outstanding. All I have seen in the past are poor VHS transfers from TV airings. This one is worth going back to again and again for the hilarity and the magic of it all.

I just bought volumes one and and two through the Warner Archives for forty bucks each. You can also order through the TCM shop, but shipping cost  is outrageous over at TCM, so I recommend the Warner Archive. Don't let these scalpers get away with ripping you off. Scalpers your day is done when it comes to this product. I'll be back when my order reaches me to review the product I received from Warners. I don't know if it is pressed or burned, and I am assuming the transfers are the same, because with other Paramount titles I've received from the Warner Archive the transfers looked no better than what I have seen on TCM in the past.UPDATE: Both volumes arrived pressed from the Warner Archive. Transfers are outstanding.

I just finished reading the book. The crime against the author happened in 1981, before DNA evidence made such stranger rape convictions slam dunk. I was 23 in 1981 - these were MODERN times - and yet she was treated monstrously by people - like some kind of freak. Rape was more common in 1981 than it is today, yet the things people said to her! . Two things stuck out. WHY, since her family was a secular rather than a religious church going family, would her parents tell her pastor who then announces it to the entire congregation???? Second, WHY would her mom's therapist, when Alice went to her first session start out by saying "I guess you won't be so hung up by sex from now on will you?". That was Alice's first and last session with that creep who was, by the way ANOTHER WOMAN in her 30s who should know better and knew that  Alice was a virgin before her rape. This is highly powerful writing and I strongly recommend the book.

This new Brewer's yeast has only a fraction of the nutrition that the old formula had in almost every category. Most importantly, the old version had 190mcg of chromium per serving. This version has only 7% of that per serving. I used the old formula for at least ten years and loved it. I guess, being a diabetic and needing the chromium, I'll have to find a replacement. Too bad.

I like how O'Reilly breaks out its PERL books. There is "Learning PERL" for beginners, "Programming PERL" as a reference, and "PERL Cookbook" for solutions. Alas, this book, a weighty tome that makes the dictionary look skinny, should really be renamed "Programming Python". It's a great reference, but good luck trying to learn Python succinctly and from scratch. It's like trying to learn English by reading the dictionary. I'll give it 3 out of 5 on correctness and completeness, but like trying to buy a pair of shoes at a giant Megamart with no department signs, you'll eventually just get frustrated and leave.

... because in spite of being released on DVD via Sony's MOD program, hardly anyone ever reviews the film and I've never seen it on TV, not even on Turner Classic Movies.This was a blind buy for me, and it is among the best of the early production code films, which often got ridiculously sentimental in attempts to not violate the code. This one is a little sentimental, but it's interesting and a bit different too. In spite of having everything going for it - good quality script, acting, and production values, it does have a near anonymous cast, even for classic film fans, and that may be the reason it is overlooked.A 65 year old woman (Henrietta Crosman as Martha Abbott) walks out on her family after basically being made to feel old and unwanted. She leaves a home she owns outright and shares with her difficult nephew and nephew's wife. We never see the argument that drove her out, but we do get to meet the nephew and his wife when they go to the police in a panic about missing aunt Martha. You see, it turns out they probably don't want Aunt Martha back as much as they need her to close on the house - after all she holds title, and they can't sell without her.Meanwhile a trio of jewel thieves are about to get pinched for their latest robbery. The youngest among them walks into the park where he sees Martha, sitting there looking lost and forlorn He starts a conversation, and stuffs the stolen jewels into her things. The police come up and question them, search the boy, and eventually figure these are not the thieves and leave. The jewel thieves take Martha home with them, at first planning to turn her out the next day. But then a cop sees the back door open, starts wandering around, and is instantly disarmed by Martha's demeanor since she seems like everyone's grandmother. The thieves now see the usefulness of Martha as an apparently harmless front to their operations, and they hire her as a cook and housekeeper.Martha is not as clueless as you'd think though, and she soon figures out what the three are up to. But she also figures out that Tommy is not a hardened criminal like the other two, although outwardly he is very gruff and pretty disrespectful of Martha. She can see that the other two thieves plan to use Tommy to take the real risks in their operation, all the while acting like they are teaching him some kind of trade. She hangs around to try to make Tommy see the error of his ways and to act as a bit of a matchmaker between Tommy and "the girl next door" - literally - Judy.Ivan F. Simpson plays Smeed, the most outwardly tough of the two hardened thieves, and that's an interesting bit of casting since I'm used to seeing him play gentleman's gentleman types. Arthur Hoyl plays the other thief, which is not an unusual turn for him since he usually played back-stabbing underhanded types. Of the three thieves he is the most slippery and very good at controlling Tommy, making him think he is always thinking of him.I'd recommend it to anybody who likes films from the 1930's. Plus the audio and video quality of the DVD itself is wonderful. There are no extra features.Summary:Film itself: 4/5DVD quality (audio, video) : 5/5I round up to a combined score of 5/5.

... and that's the case here. The story is told mainly in flashback as The Durango Kid (Charles Starrett) recounts the tale of a stolen stash of gold known only to blind outlaw Bill Donner and a child in which Donner confided, but is desired by outlaw Frank Fenton. The "ghost town" was once a thriving place, but Fenton ran everyone out of town by terrorizing the settlers, all so he could have the place to himself and eventually find the gold. There are lots of good action shots in this film mainly because about two thirds of the film is stock footage from past Durango Kid westerns. Only the ending shots and the scenes where Durango is recounting the tale are new footage. There are some macabre elements here you don't normally see in these westerns, such as outlaw Bill Donner locking his partners in the hidden vault with the gold and leaving them, now two of the richest men in the world, to die in a grave of gold. In another scene Donner is captured by Fenton's gang and then returns blinded. It is not clear whether Donner blinded himself so he could not be forced to divulge the location of the loot, or if Fenton did it out of meanness, and in this case, stupidity.If you haven't seen the past Durango Kid westerns and therefore recognize all of the stock footage, and you like westerns in general, you should like this one.

This is a tale of a prosperous Hungarian farming family that takes in a gypsy girl (Myrna Loy as Nubi) who says she has run away from her tribe and will be beaten by her gypsy husband if reclaimed. They hide her, take her into their home as a servant, and come to regret that decision.Although directed by the renowned Alexander Korda, he did a poor job here, possibly not having veto power over the diction coaches in this very early talkie. This is Loretta Young's first talkie and it shows. She is very good at conveying emotion, but she probably is the most wooden member of the cast in speaking her lines.
