And unlike some of the earlier generations, it's MUCH easier to remove now.This case clips into a matching belt holster with a large clip, which is made of equally solid plastic and a felt lined interior to protect the screen. But more to make you feel better, really. The latch at the top makes for very simple use as I can insert and remove one-handed all day long.There is a metal kick-stand on the back, which is held closed via magnet. I don't use this too often. But it is very nice to have. I do wish they'd redesign it for the big ones. The weight distribution of the large phones, especially the Nexus 6, means it's not super stable. It still works. Minor issue.Overall, I highly recommend these cases for anybody looking for a good combination of protection, portability, and functionality. Plus, it looks nice.

I decided to use my 09 GMC Sierra Denali truck as a good test subject. I'm very picky when it comes to cleaners for my truck. But this looked harmless enough. And given it's relative age and the life it's led partially exposed to the Texas heat, the rubber seals definitely needed a good protectant. It's also got a fiberglass toneau cover with rubber seals which are likely exposed to even more of the hot stuff.First, I just went over all of the rubber with a natural cleaner. Ensuring to get all sides of the seals, including the back. Then simply shake and apply the 303 protectant via the included applicator, which is part of the bottle. Due to it's design, it won't get into tight spots. So I just used a blue shop towel to both get in those crevices as well as go over everything again. It's easy enough to apply directly to the towel, as needed. This helped provide an even and thorough coating.Then that's it. No mess, easy to apply, no artificial shine, very simple. It's not meant to repair or add shine. Just a seal/protectant. Which is exactly what it does. It's even got a nice smell to it. What's not to like? I consider this item highly recommended.

First, I should note these are review units. But they appears to be used/returns as one was kind of moving around freely in the packaging and not much documentation. I'd assume they were testing first, so I'll also conclude that any issues are "normal," unless told otherwise. :)This kit basically includes two separate lights. One plugs into AC power, it's a little brighter, and is activated via motion sensing. The other isn't quite as bright, but is battery powered via 6 AA batteries (included), and is touch activated. This one is meant to be hung or stuck to something. Both have adjustable slider to control brightness, and that's about it.The plug-in version will take up the entire wall plug. Depending on where it's going, could be an issue. When the brightness level is anything less than max, there is a slightly audible high-pitch noise. In a quiet room, it was easily noticeable. There is a light sensor on top, but with no way to adjust it. So it requires a bit of light to prevent the LED from turning on. In the morning, it'll still turn on. The motion sensor is very sensitive, easily able to detect movement several feet away. If approaching from the side, less than 2-3 feet or so.The battery powered version, while not quite as bright, still provides enough light to see what's going on in the room. It too is very basic. Just tap to turn on/off, adjust brightness level, and that's it. No issues with noises on this model. And since it's LED, the batteries should last quite awhile.Overall these lights are quite handy to keep around the house. I've got one in the hallway (which the toddler has been quite fascinated with) so you've automatically got light when walking the house at night. And the battery powered one is under my computer desk. Infinitely helpful for working on the PC or digging through cables and such. Or just to provide some back lighting.I'll give these a reserved recommendation as they are a little buggy and no adjustments on the light sensor, motion detector, light duration, etc. So just be aware of the features and limitations and grab 'em on sale.

I absolutely love butter on my popcorn. How people eat plain popcorn is beyond me. In either case, I must add my own butter. At the theater, you have to "layer the butter" yourself these days. Which is somewhat annoying as they don't do it for you anymore. I'm already paying over $6 for popcorn, and you can't even add butter the way I want?Fortunately, that complaint is no longer an issue. Since I got a basic popper, this movie theater button, and seasoning. Just look around this listing, they're usually all purchased together. And they make an excellent tub of popcorn together.Just pop the popcorn, sprinkle it around, add seasoning, and you've got something that is as good if not BETTER than movie theater popcorn.  Yes, better. You can layer it, toss it around, whatever works. The only problem now is keeping this stuff stocked in the pantry and figuring out what to do with all the money you saved by not wasting it at the concession stands.

The SoundLogic Charger is basically a charging station for your smart phone and tablets. It has an AC wall plug and 3 slots to hold your devices, whatever it might be. Then take your USB cable and connect it to the charger, which will be on the top, on the inside. For this reason, you may want to consider purchasing shorting USB cables or maybe stuff them in the back. Unfortunately there is no real cable management included here.You also aren't able to adjust the spacing for the slots that hold your gadgets. The one at the back is large enough for just about any tablet I could throw at it. From the Venue 10 7000 to a Nexus 7, they all fit fine, even with a case. The middle/front slots are a bit tighter. A smaller phone like a Galaxy S4 fit comfortably. But my Nexus 6 with a Seidio case was very snug.Then you've got the infamous blue LED that hides next to the USB ports. Yes, it's very bright, and you can't turn it off. You can put some tape over it, however. If you don't, it'll certainly light up the room at night as its directed upward.Back to the 3 USB ports. Only one is a full 2.1A, the other two are 1A. So if your device is sitting on here overnight, not a big deal. If you're looking for a quick charge, you'll need to decide which device is more important. Since that's how I'm using it, it was able to charge my Nexus 7, Nexus 6, and Venue 10 7000 overnight just fine. Although once again, due to the limited spacing, the 10" tablet ended up sitting on the table.Which somewhat defeats the purpose of this item. I can live with the bright blue LED and slightly low charging speed for some of the ports. But non-adjustable slots really does limit it's usefulness for now. If you're devices happen to fit, won't be a problem. Or if you just want to use it as a 3-port station, that's fine. I set it up at a recent part and let folks "dock" in for a quick charge.Overall, I'll give it a reserved recommendation, depending on your needs.

I come to this machine from a bit of a unique standpoint: I've been sewing for over two decades now, and while I imagine the machines in the class where I learned to sew were fairly basic, I have primarily used my mom's higher-end sewing machines for the majority of the time I've been sewing, and especially in the past decade-plus. So coming to this machine (my very first machine that is truly MINE) was something of a step back for me, but I tried to not let my experience with high-end machines color my review of this product.If you have experience with sewing machines already, you could probably open the box, get the machine hooked up (there is one cord that connects the machine to power, and also connects the foot pedal to the machine, so it's a quick-and-easy setup), and start powering away. If this is your very first machine, I would recommend reading the enclosed manual first (of course, I'm generally of the opinion to always read the manual, anyway). The machine comes with a small bag of accessories neatly tucked away into the accessory tray compartment (that little box at the front of the machine that you remove to access the bobbin compartment). There's one bobbin already in the bobbin compartment, plus an additional 3 bobbins (4 total). Also included are 3 extra needles (in addition to the one already installed), 3 total feet (the "all-purpose" foot is already attached, plus there is a buttonhole foot and a zipper foot), a darning plate, 2 spool pin felts, a needle plate screwdriver, and a small lint brush with a mini seam ripper hidden inside the handle. All of the accessories fit neatly into the compartment with room to spare.The first thing I did was wind a bobbin. There are diagrams on the top of the machine that show you how to run the thread from the spool to the bobbin winder. The bobbin wound quickly, and the winder simply stopped winding once it was full, even if I kept my foot on the pedal. More diagrams on the top and front of the machine walk you through threading it, and the process is similar to every other sewing machine I've used. It lacks a needle threader, which is handy to have, but I suppose not necessary. If you have issues with threading the needle, a hand-held needle threader (http://www.amazon.com/CottageCutz-CNT1-2-in-1-Needle-Threader/dp/B000YZ462E/ for example) can still be used to help get the thread through the eye.Lead-footed drivers beware: the machine goes FAST. I'm accustomed to the speed control on my mom's machines, where you can set a top speed and, no matter how much you put the pedal to the metal (or carpet, wood, tile, whatever your flooring is), it won't exceed it. The only speed control on this machine comes from how much pressure you apply to the foot pedal, so definitely take it easy! I'm not deducting any stars from the machine for the lack of speed control, because it's not a "missing feature," since nowhere does the information on the machine suggest it has this feature, it's simply something I'm used to from higher-end machines. If this is an issue for you, you may want to consider looking at a different machine.Another feature from higher-end machines that I noticed was not included on this machine was a button to set the needle so that it stops either down or up. Of course, there's a knob on the right side of the machine that raises and lowers the needle, but it can sometimes be handy to have the needle stop down, without trying to time taking your foot off the pedal just right. Again, not worthy of a star deduction, because this is a basic machine, but something to consider. After all, if the needle stops in a position different than what you need (up, down, or anywhere in between), you can simply turn the knob and put the needle where you need it.The lever to raise & lower the presser foot is easy to manage with just a finger, and it can lift the presser foot a fairly decent height, beyond the raised "resting" position. There is a thread-cutter located on the left side of the machine. A lever on the front right of the machine allows for easy back-stitching. The big round dial at the top front of the machine (with the blue S in the center) is your stitch-selector: line up the stitch you want with the little marking at the top center, and you're good to go. It includes 3 lengths of straight stitch, 3 zig-zag widths, satin-stitch, blind hem, scallop, and the three parts to the four-step buttonhole stitch (steps 2 & 4 use the same part). There is also a dial a bit to the left of the stitch selector where you can adjust the tension of the stitching, but you'll probably want to leave it on "4" for a good majority of your straight stitching, and the manual succinctly covers how to check if the tension is "good" for what you're doing, as well as how to adjust it.Overall, it is a nice little machine, great for beginners and those who don't really need all the bells and whistles that come with higher-end machines. I tested it out on both muslin and flannel (the fabrics I had available scraps of), and it held up well on both. If you want to work on heavy-duty fabrics (corduroy, denim, upholstery fabric, etc), you will need to buy the appropriate needles, likewise for the "wispier" fabrics such as chiffon. When buying the fabric, an employee should be able to help you find the appropriate needles for your machine and fabric. I give this machine 5 stars because it does what it says it does: it gives beginners a nice little launching pad without overwhelming them with extra features.

PROS:+ Good Build Quality+ eSATA & USB 3 Ports+ 4 Gigabit Ports+ Fast dual core CPU+ Descent range for only 2 antenna+ Smart Wi-Fi Setup for console access virtually anywhere+ Easy to use interface+ Lots of extra features & customization+ OpenWRT compatible+ Dual Band (2.4Ghz & 5Ghz)CONS:- Expensive for what it does- Bridge or "Access Point" mode removes all extra features- Not as fast as cheaper routers which have more antennas- USB Drive speeds not very fast (i.e. NAS)Like many of us, I've owned countless access points over the years. Including the original Linksys WRT54 series that came out back in early 2000.  I'm currently using a TP-Link C5 AC1200 Wireless Router, which has has comparable specs, except it has 6 antenna instead of the two here. Oh, and it costs about $100 less.OUT OF THE BOX & SETUPAs is typical these days for access points, you don't get a whole lot. Just throw the antennas on the box and follow the quick setup guide. Which in this case, is pretty straight forward. You can either connect via LAN or Wireless and are given the option of using the Wizard or manual configuration. For most folks connecting to your modem, the wizard is the way to go.It's able to quickly identify your internet connection and help setup your Access Point names, passwords, etc. From there you, you call it a day and enjoy the internet. Although if you're buying this access point, you're interested in more than this.ADVANCED FEATURESIf there's a feature that Access Points are pushing these days, this router has it all. You've got guess access points modes, tons of parental controls, FTP server, auto-update, etc. The two worth special mention here is the NAS (Network Area Storage) and Smart Wi-Fi. The NAS is very simple to setup.Simply connected my Seagate USB 3.0 drive to the USB port and you're done. Go to the NAS section in the setup interface to get the IP and connect from any system. You have other options such as setting permissions and such. Otherwise, it's ready to go. My main issue here was that it wasn't very fast. Speeds were limited to around 10Mb/s, give or two a few Mb. It didn't matter if I was on 2.4, 5Ghz, or connected via LAN. It just didn't want to go very fast.If speed isn't an issue, Smart Wi-Fi brings some nice added functionality. You basically create an account with Linksys and it allows you to remotely manage your device from anywhere with internet connectivity. This is particular useful if you want to access the files stored on your drive elsewhere. Quite handy.ACCESS POINT / BRIDGE MODEIf you use the wizard, it'll actually automatically detect that you have an existing internet and set itself up so you've got internet. Although it's using DHCP, switches to a whole different subnet, etc. In other words, this isn't ideal. You can try to manually configure some settings to work around this, but it never worked right. You pretty much have to set it to Bridge mode.Which does work. I configured a static IP and my own DHCP/DNS servers took over. Everything good to go. However, it disables every single advanced features. No guest mode, USB storage, Smart Wi-Fi, all gone. For those of us doing this, jumping over to OpenWRT is clearly the best option.PERFORMANCESo how fast did it go. The best AC speeds on 5Ghz were around 35Mb/s average, with a few peaking at about 40Mb/s. And that's only a couple feet away. If I switched back to my TP-Link C5, it was easily about 5Mb/s faster, on average. And it was able to maintain a slightly better signal at further distances. Nothing drastic, but it was noticeable, and expected. There are quite a few more antenna's.Gigabit LAN speeds were right as expected, up to and right around 100MB/s, so nothing out of the ordinary there. Although that is with transferring files over the LAN. As previously noted, using the USB storage was considerably slower.CONCLUSIONOverall, it's really not a bad access point. If you want a lot of features, functionality, and the ability to use OpenWRT, there aren't a lot of options. But if wireless speed is your top priority, there are other access points that cost considerably less, while still providing most of the important features folks are looking for.

PROS:+ Pancake compressor has small footprint for it's capacity+ Two connectors for two different tools used as the same time+ Handle for easy transport+ Relatively light weight+ Covered motor to prevent burning+ Oil-Free & Maintenance Free Design+ Easy to read gauges+ Quickly fills up from empty+ Minimal vibration (it won't run away)+ High quality 25" PVC hose with fittings included+ 16 & 18 GA Nailers includedCONS:- Somewhat noisy- Bit pricey- Only includes 1 hose- Other air tools would be niceOut of the box, you've got the compressor itself, a 25' PVC hose (with fittings), 18 GA nailer, and 16 GA finisher. That's about it, and is really all you need for to get nailing. Although including a 2nd hose would have been nice, as it does support the use of two tools at the same time.Compared to my existing Craftsman 3 Gal compressor, the specifications are very similar with regards to PSI and SCFM. The real difference is that this has a larger capacity and it's oil-free. While this does mean you don't need to ever change the oil or do any maintenance, the motor is a bit louder than I'd like. More so if used in an enclosed garage or house. Outdoors, it's not that big of an issue, and all somewhat common for this design.I ran it through several tests by nailing any piece of wood lying around the garage repeatedly to see how the nailers handled a "stress test" as well as the compressor itself. Although I don't recall doing this for actual "work" being this entertaining in the past. :) The nailers themselves are fairly basic and of the 'made in china" variety. The quality feels descent, if not exactly "expensive" feeling. They seem to get the job done and don't show any signs poor quality that might cause an early failure. All of the nails went all the way in and looked great.Otherwise you can get a respectable amount of nailing done with a 6 GAL compressor. In particular one that can fill itself up in about 2-3 minutes, depending on how high you have the pressure set to. I suspect using two tools at once will keep it running more frequent, in which case you may want longer hoses to keep it outside.I do wish it came with other air tools, although I already have a few others laying around. Such as an air blowing tool and tire air chuck with gauge. Once again thanks to a good amount of air pressure and capacity, it had no issue quickly airing up the tires in our vehicles. Just as good as the Craftsman, except it didn't need to run quite as much.Overall, if you're looking for a solid compressor and have a need for the nailers, this is an excellent bundle. Just keep an eye out for sales as it's list price is clearly far more than it should be. And additional air tools aren't too much these days either. Highly recommended.

I prefer using a large mouse pad for both gaming and office related tasks. It's nice having plenty of room to move around. Whether you're selecting a bunch of rows in excel or sniping away in Battlefield. As is the case with many gamer's, we probably have quite a few mouse pads laying around. It's hard to find one that works for everything. But I think this Turtle Beach premium mouse pad gets it done.It has a rubber back so it doesn't slide around on my wooden desk. And the cloth-like texture is quite nice. You can feel it as you move your hand across the surface, but it's not so rough that you'll even notice with the mouse. My Logitech G9X Gaming Laser mouse works perfectly. It's smooth, accurate, and I love it. Another bonus, is they won't get dirt build up like hard mouse pads do, which is quite annoying.Overall, if you're looking for a nice large textured gaming mouse pad that works for everything, look no further. I consider it highly recommended

I purchased this for use in my '09 GMC Sierra Denali truck along with my Galaxy Tab S 10.5 LTE tablet. The idea being that I could use this large tablet as my main navigation and music device, instead of the out-dated unit that came with the truck. Basically, it really doesn't work all that well on the go. Even on smooth roads, there is just too much movement allowed by it's cheap plastic construction. For some, they may not notice or care, but it really bothers me.I'm using the thickest pad so it stays in the cd-tray rather securely. It could be tighter, but it's the assembly itself that has a hard time staying still with a ~1lb tablet. The naturally firm ride of a full size truck doesn't help, but even on smooth roads, I expected better. However, I do like the vertical adjustments and it does put the tablet at a great viewing position. Even though it does block the vents in my vehicle.I plan on keeping it for use when I'm parked and want to watch a movie or something. Otherwise, it wobbles around far too much for my personal preferences. I wouldn't buy it again.

It's fairly common these days to have multiple pairs of sunglasses for different occasions. I note this first as it's important to realize these aren't likely going to be worn 100% of the time. I've yet to come across a pair that work for everything, no would I want them to. These are meant for outdoor activity use. Which is exactly where I've been using them, and they work great.Doing yard work, outdoor shooting, or just going for a walk. As they are polarized, they do an excellent job at blocking the harsh rays and glare of the sun. I can have the sun right in my peripheral vision and it doesn't even bother me a bit.They are a mostly plastic construction, somewhat flexible, and are extremely light. I can barely even notice I'm wearing them most of the time.While you can use them for driving, the only issue is the obvious fact that they are polarized. Many displays and screens will become invisible at an angle. No surprises there.Otherwise these are my new go-to shades for my many outdoor activities.

The housing is rather compact and sits nicely on top of the Xbox One. It basically draws hot air up and out towards the back. It uses a single USB port for power, and provides another single USB port to replace the one it used. My headset worked just fine in this port. The top of the surface is rubberized so it's a safe place to put a headset or controllers without risk of scratching the console.It also has a small LED display on the front, facing upward. This shows ambient and supposedly internal temperatures. Once the temp gets below 86 degrees, it'll automatically turn off. Although it's so quiet, you'll never know if it's on or off unless you look at the display on top. Which yes, really should be on the front.But how does it actually work? To confirm it's claims of lowing temps "up to 30%," I grabbed my trusty infrared thermometer. The ambient temperature reading is pretty much dead on. Great. The internal, or even external temp of the housing, is on the low side, by at least 10 degrees. It's most likely not reading the hot spot towards the front/middle area.Without the X-1 Cooler, My Xbox One was hitting around 110 - 115 degrees at peak gaming while playing Destiny for awhile, as indicated by the infrared thermometer. Ambient temps were 78 Degrees. After the cooler had been on for awhile, temps dropped by about 5 degrees. They advertised "up to" 30% lower temps, which we're clearly nowhere near.Perhaps if you have a really tight space with ventilation out the back, it could be a bit more effective. But in my A/V rack, there is already descent air-flow. But I'm always all for a drop in temps, since as we know, heat is a big electronics killer. I'm not going to turn down even a couple degree drop. And if you do in fact have your console in an enclosed area, you need to work out ventilation there first. Cut some holes in the back or something. This does no good if it doesn't have both cool air at the intake and a place to exhaust the hot air.Overall, I have reserved recommendations for the X-1 Cooler. In most cases, you're probably better off doing as noted above to help reduce internal temps vs hoping something like this is going to save the day. It'll help, just not quite as much as you might like.

We have Bermuda grass in Central Texas and it goes dormant over the winter time. Every year, the weeds take the opportunity to take over the lawn. And every year I try different chemicals, but ultimately end up having to crawl around pulling them up. And we're good for the rest of the year when the grass takes over again.In either case, I decided to try out the Ortho Weed B Gon Max Weed Killer on all of the weeds. There were so many, it used up the entire gallon. Which by the way, didn't ship with a sprayer. So I used one of my automatic sprayers from another product.I made sure to follow the directions, used a good amount on each weed. Checked back within 24 hours, and results were somewhat as expected. The crab grass and broadleaf weeds showed signs of being unhealthy, and the rest, were looking as healthy as ever.A week later, and they were still a dark shade of green. Hardly dead. I imagine if I waited long enough, they might eventually die off. But this is one slow acting chemical. Perhaps not concentrated enough? Either way I ended up having to pull them up by hand. Which was even more annoying since the top of the weed just popped off, leaving the root in place.Bottom line, it does technically work, if you are really patient, and only have a few types of weeds it covers. Otherwise I'd suggest just going another route, or simply pulling them up yourself. Then follow up with some entire-lawn chemicals to keep it in check. That's always worked best for me.

During this review, I'm going to focus on the important questions I had with regards to how it compares to my corded vacuum cleaners. More specifically, my current Dyson DC33 corded model that does a fairly good job with our moderately thick carpet. But first, the Pros's & Con's we'll be talking about.PROS:+ Light weight (12.7 lbs)+ Compact design+ Detachable canister unit for extra portability & functionality+ Long lasting Lithium Ion batteries (2 included)+ Bright LED light+ Relatively quiet in "normal mode"+ Compact swivel floor roller very maneuverable in tight spaces+ Easy setup, operation, and cleaning+ Roller on/off switch+ Effective boost mode great for thick carpet+ Functional dusting attachments+ No cords!CONS:- Gets noisy in "boost" mode- No wide angle attachment for stairs or upholstery- Small canister needs more frequent emptying- Small floor surface area may require a few more passes- Must remove battery to see charge status- Bit PriceyOUT OF THE BOX & SETUPSometimes vacuum cleaners get a little over complicated in their attempt to do everything. And as such, setup and operation can become rather cumbersome. So it was a nice surprise being able to get the Hoover all unboxed and setup within a few minutes. All without even touching the instruction manual. Which by the way, is short, to the point, and well written.After the few separate components are put together, just install the batteries and off you go. The batteries already shipped with a mostly full charge and ready to go. There is a stand-alone charger provider, and is the only way to charge them. You've got 3 LED's on the battery itself to see how charged it is. You can only check this after removed from the vacuum cleaner.You'll also note it's equally easy to remove the canister for assembly and cleaning. However, it's obviously quite a bit smaller than a full size vacuum cleaner, and as such, will require more frequent emptying. Even removing the rollers to remove hair is simply, requiring removal of only two tabs.DAILY CARPET CLEANINGWe've got a 2-story house that's about 2,700 sq/ft with a whole lot of carpet and a bit of tile. The carpet is moderately thick and needs a good vacuum cleaner to really pull all of the dirt and dust out of it. I started with a fully charged battery and just ran it until the battery died. The battery lasted roughly 35-40 min or so until it died. It was also rather abrupt, and short of the 50 minutes advertised run-time, but that may be achievable if you turn off the brushes.The LED light on the canister is very bright. So bright, I was even able to vacuum the house as night with most of the lights turn off. Why? No practical reason other than to try it out. :) But even in a normal lit house, it's nice to have that extra light to see what you may run over.Speaking of which, I noticed this thing loves to eat cords. Most vacuum cleaners I've used in the past tend to push them out of the way, but this one is very eager to eat 'em up. Fortunately, if it gets stuck, the brushes turn off because causing any damage to the cables (or vacuum cleaner).Also a big fan of the maneuverability of the floor unit. While it's smaller size can be a negative in that it technically requires more passes in large areas, it also means you can squeeze into, around, and under far more objects around the house. It happily pivots and slides around like they aren't even there. Where as in the past, this would require breaking out a separate attachment or moving things around.STAIRS, DUSTING, & TILEThe stairs are also carpeted as is most of the house. So I found it rather nice to be able to remove the canister for this task. It's even lighter without the rest of the system. However, it's missing a very important accessory. The wide angle tool. It just has the crevice/brush attachment and an angled dusting attachment. The crevice tool is really impracticle for cleaning stairs. Even though the picture shows this being done, that person can't be happy about it.That alone is it's #1 biggest negative for me. The brush slides down on the crevice tool if needed and there is a nifty angled brush tool. It has an extension and it's adjustable to allow easy dusting in hard to reach areas, such as the top of cabinets, refrigerator, ceiling fans, etc. Very handy.And thanks to the easy-to-turn-off brushes, it'll happily glide over title and such up anything in it's path. No need to worry about dirty flying around.VS CORDED VAC (Dyson DC33)The big question and concern I had was whether or not it could replace my larger, more powerful Dyson DC33 vacuum cleaner. Our downstairs part of the house hadn't been vacuum in quite awhile. It was long over due, but would be a good testing surface. First, I started with one section and did a normal pass with the Hoover Air Cordless and noted it picked up a lot of dirt. Then followed up with the DC33. Unfortunately the Dyson did pickup some dust the cordless model missed.But wait, there's more. The Hoover has a "Boost" mode which in addition to becoming more noisy (louder than the DC33 at this setting), it sucks in way more dirt. I went to another near-by room and performed the same test. Except this time, the corded vac was unable to find any more dust. Excellent.The battery will take a bit of a hit running in Boost mode, but there's still plenty of power with 2 fully charged batteries for my house.CONCLUSIONTo answer the big question we started off with: Yes, this corded vacuum CAN replace a full size high-end corded vacuum cleaner. They're comparably priced and offer most of the same features and functionality. The benefits of it's smaller size and heft easily "outweigh" any con's with regards to a little less cleaning surface area. Two batteries was just enough to clean the entire house with a little juice left over.In either case, I certainly didn't miss the cords getting in the way. I was still able to clean the house in about the same amount of time, but with less fatigue and stress. What I did miss was the wide attachment for the stairs. This should be included in the box. And well, it could always be a little cheaper.Overall I'll give this a solid 4.5 stars and consider it highly recommended.

From working in the IT Support industry for nearly 20 years, I've spent a considerable amount of time working with network gear. Along with many other computer stuff, of course. Let's jump in and take a look at the Netgear ProSAFE 16-Port "Click Switch."DESIGNWe have to start with this first, as it is somewhat unique in the networking world. I've never seen a 16-port switch with this design. Most are compact or rack mounted designs that don't really change much in shape, just size. As you can see from the pictures this switch has a long narrow design, that's mean to be easily mounted under a desk, on a wall, post, etc. Given it's compact profile, it'll go just about anywhere.The power cord is angled and can go in either direction, depending on how you have it installed. So it can go straight down, or to the front. Then you've got your basic link and connectivity lights. And at that point, you're dealing with a normal switch.INSTALLThere is an optional bracket that allows easy removal. I simply used the two included screws to attach to the wall behind the small entertainment center in the media room / office. This room has about a dozen computers, large TV, media center, etc. So a 16 port switch is actually the minimum needed to ensure full network connectivity.Once the bracket was screwed in, the switch clicked right in. There is a tab on the top you push down to release. I did note that sometimes you have to push down on the tab for it to snap into place. Not a big deal. After all, you're not going to be removing it very often.There are also included straps that attach to the switch to assist with cable management. You can use them separately, but they are meant to be used with the switch since there are loops to run it through.SETUP & CONFIGThis switch is a "managed" switch, which certainly explains the cost. In other words, it has built-in software to provide many advanced features. In most home environments, they will probably never get used. But when you get into more complex home offices and small businesses, it starts to make a lot more sense. You can access these features via the included software (yes, there is a "CD") or via the website. Either way, the experience is comparable.The first thing you'll want to do is basic stuff you might do with a router. Setup the password, give it an IP address, and check out the advanced features to see what you might want to use. I won't go into how these features work, as that gets a bit more technical, but you've got VLAN, loop detection, QoS, Cable Testing, and much more. You can even check out "port statistics" to see how many bandwidth has gone through each port and how many CRC errors have occurred. Very handy.PERFORMANCEBut does it work fast enough? It sure does. For my "stress test" I fired up 6 computers and had them transferring files between each other. All while playing around with the management interface. Bottom line, it had no problem holding at 100-105MB/s transfer rates for all 3 sessions that were running simultaneously. That tells me we've got full gigabit and a back plane that can handle some serious bandwidth.CONCLUSIONIt's important to realize that once you get it managed switches, that you are getting into pricier territory. So if you don't think you'll ever use these features, there are cheaper options. But for those wanting advanced options for current needs or even some "future proofing," this is the way to go. Add in it's unique form factor and flexible installation options and you've got what I consider, a highly recommended switch.

As somebody with allergies, I try to keep a dust-free house. While that's virtually impossible, frequent dusting is a must. I normally use swiffer combined with a hand-held unit that makes things far easier to quickly and effectively dust a room. The issue with the "dust wipes" is that you have to use your hand and essentially "touch" everything you want to dust.On their own, they do technically work better than swiffer when it comes to collecting dust. One swipe is all I needed and no more sign of dust. Everything from furniture to electronics, it does quite well. Although the surface isn't quite smooth enough that I'd trust it on the screens of your gadgets. Try it at your own risk! I also tried "cleaning" some surfaces, such as dirty keyboard. That didn't work well at all. Stick to dusting. :)Overall, it works well on it's own, for it's intended purpose. I like being able to grab one when some quick dusting is needed. For example, my shiny Xbox One needed dusting. I'm done in a second. No need to go grab the swiffer. But when I need to dust the whole room/house, there are more efficient ways to go.

I've used countless mounts over the year. In fact, I have a drawer full of them. Mostly because they don't work, break, or I find something slightly better. I was previously using the 2 part Pro-Clip mount solution, which includes a dash mount + device holder. In my case, that is currently the Galaxy Note 3. The holder was universal so it would work with the case on my phone. It worked alright, but inserting and removing was a little annoying at times.Plus, I wanted to buy a larger extended battery, which had a larger case, and simply wasn't going to work well in that holder. So along comes the iOauto Pro mount.First, the suction cup mount works about as well as can be expected. It has a latch that helps it really stick to the windshield and it's certainly not going anywhere. Although for my primary use, it's going to be used with ProClip dash mount in my 09 GMC Sierra Denali truck. The ProClip mount just clips onto the dash. It's quite secure on it's own.Then the iOauto quite literally screws right in like it was meant to work with it, just like the ProClip device holder. You can toss any extra adapters it includes. That part is done. Next you'll have to stick a metal plate to your phone or case. This is so the magnet can do it's job. My case is plastic, so I was hoping it would stick perfectly. It did not. Even after cleaning the surface and allowing to sit for awhile, it fell off on the first use.This magnet is very, very strong. iOAuto knows this. So I'm not sure why the adhesive is so weak. Not a big deal. Nothing a little super glue couldn't fix. Once again, don't recommend applying this directly to a phone. A cheap case? No problem. That metal plate is going nowhere now.This silver part you see is basically a metal "dome" that the round black thing (magnet) sticks to. This allows the magnet to slide just about anywhere you'd like, in any position along the sphere. So once your phone is attached, it's easy to move around, yet stays put the rest of the time.I drive a fairly powerful truck, and, well, it drives like a truck. So I need something that can stay in place regardless of how I'm driving. Mounts that bounce around or vibrate are unacceptable. Rough roads, hard turns, fast stops, starts, etc. Doesn't matter. This phone is rock solid in this mount.TIP: If you want to remove the phone, just tilt it sideways. Just like you would for any magnet. If you pull it off directly, the magnet itself may decide to stick to the phone.Overall, I consider this highly recommended. Easily the best mount I've ever purchased. I just wish it came with better adhesive and was a bit cheaper. And if you don't like things stuck to the windshield, which I hate, grab a Pro-Clip dash mount.

Allow me to preface this review by saying that I am very much not a "beauty is pain" type  I like my beauty to be as unpainful as possible. I've never had anything waxed, preferring to shave to remove body hair, so that's all I have to compare the experience of this hair removal product to.So far as hair removal goes, this product performs decently. It does take a few sweeps of the same area to remove all the hair, and I even discovered several days later that I had missed a few spots, but it does provide excellent long-term hair removal: as I write this review, it's been 6 days since I used it on my legs, and aside from the spots I'd missed, there's no sign yet of regrowth. Definitely handy if you're going to be traveling and don't want to bother with lugging shaving accoutrements with you. Or if you're lazy like me (or, also like me, have tiny children and have to work in showering/shaving time around their naps) and live somewhere with warm weather and don't want to have to shave several times a week in order to keep smooth legs while wearing shorts (I am definitely looking forward to wearing shorts more often this summer).Now, the downside. This thing HURTS (on both the speeds available). Like I prefaced, I'm not big on the whole pain for beauty thing, so I was gritting my teeth the whole time I was giving this thing a whirl. Of course, it's yanking your hair out at the roots, so of course it hurts. If you're a regular waxer, you probably wouldn't mind it nearly as much. If you're a regular shaver, it'll take some getting used to, so whether the payoff of longer-term smooth legs is worth the pain is entirely up to you. Personally, I'll probably stick with shaving unless I'm planning on traveling and/or planning on wearing shorts/skirts/dresses for several days.The epilator comes with two heads: one for legs/arms/any other large space, and a smaller one for underarms/bikini line/other small space. I have not worked up the nerve to try the smaller one on the underarms or bikini line, but I suspect it works just the same as the larger one, which I have used on my legs. It also comes with a "gentle cap" that it recommends for beginners, but I hadn't figured out how to use it when I was testing it out. Now that I've more closely read the book, I will give it another try (once I have hair to try it on again) and possibly update my review. There is also a "sonic exfoliation head" that is basically the most fantastic thing EVER. I am horrible on my feet, but using the exfoliation head in conjunction with my body scrub on my feet made that skin feel all soft and like new. Even if I never again used this to remove hair, I would continue to use the exfoliation head. We're BFFs now.Where stars are lost:1 star is lost due to the fact that I do have to make several sweeps of an area to remove all hair, regardless of what speed I have it on. Even the first few sweeps, before hair could potentially be causing a clog, don't clear the area well.1 star is lost due to the fact that my shower gel does not "lather" as the product materials suggest it should: both the box and the book recommend adding just a small drop of liquid shower gel to the epilation head after getting it wet, then running it to create a lather. This never happened with mine, and if I turned it off after trying to work up a lather, I could clearly see that the gel stayed entirely within the lines of the one blade area where it was initially applied. I eventually found that slathering my legs with shower gel first was the only way to get the epilation head to work up a lather.

PACKAGINGFirst, I should note the fact that the package has a shipping weight of 140lbs. UPS only dropped off at the front porch, so keep that in mind for moving it around. It's not light weight at all! Stork Craft did a good job packaging everything into a neat and tight box. Almost too good, actually. It was nearly impossible to get the inner box, out of the larger box it shipped it. It required basically tearing the whole thing apart.Which is what you'll probably end up doing if you don't have enough help to carry the box up stairs or into the room that it'll go into. Just open it up and take it in piece by piece! Otherwise, packaging was good.ASSEMBLYI've assembled many things over the years, but was a little surprised when we started working on this one. I had 2 other folks helping throughout the process, and we all agreed. This was probably a bit more difficult than necessary. For example, there are several points where you must use the included angled Allen wrench to tighten down screws. Most of them are in recessed cut-outs of the wood. Meaning, those nifty power tools probably aren't going to help much!This also means after you get them finger tight, you'll have to do the rest a quarter turn at a time. This gets quite tiresome after a while. The normal Phillips screws were much easier as they were out in the open and were easily accessible with my 20v B&D Driver. Most of the wood pieces even have a wooden peg to help align everything during installation.Which is quite helpful until you got the drawer assembly, which only has a single peg in the middle when attaching the sides, then you add two screws. Two pegs would have made this considerably easier to align and put together. Once again, little things like this made it harder than necessary.Bottom line, I'd highly recommend at least two people when assembly this unit.OVERALLBut let's face it, assembly and packaging are really minor things. Once you put it all together, what's important is how it looks and feels. We're working with good quality materials here. You've got a nice fresh varnish smell, the Espresso color looks great, and the drawers function smoothly. It even matches the crib quite nicely. The wood feels heavy and solid. So naturally, the whole dresser feels solid.It's only upon closer inspection that you see signs of "customer assembly" versus being assembled by the manufacture. There's a slight gap and at the top corner, where two wood pieces just aren't quite perfect. Step back and you won't even notice them. So considering the price and final construction, I think you'll be quite pleased with the dresser unit.

I frequently wear briefs and boxers, but never at the same time! I'd just wear whatever was needed for the occasion, such as when more support is required. I'd go with briefs. Or just a leisurely weekend, I'd go with boxers. So I was intrigued at the idea of having two-in-one. Not to mention the performance aspirations of the X-Temp material.At first, I actually found them to be a little awkward and uncomfortable. They are somewhat form fitting around the thighs and buttocks area. Almost like a spandex type material, so that you are quite aware of them. I mean, it is 100% polyester, not cotton. But they do leave some room around the crotch area, while still providing support. Very similar to your typical briefs in that regard.I went through various activities as I tested them out. Everything from extensive yard work, running, to another busy day in the office. At first, once again, I was quite aware of them and kept noticing minor movement around my legs/crotch. But after the 3 days and 3 pairs, I actually became quite accustomed to them. I hardly notice them any more and I like the added comfort.I really can't say that I noticed any extra heat dissipation, but they do dry rather quickly. Although expect that sweat will still gather in open areas where the material isn't making direct contact. So make sure these do fit securely. They aren't supposed to be loose and baggy. I wear size 34 and medium was perfect (see size chart).While I'm not quite seeing much in the way of boxer replacements in the Ultimate X-Temp garment, they are more of a long-leg pair of briefs with a bit more crotch space. Overall, I consider these recommended for just about any person or occasion. And as an added bonus, my wife likes the feel and form fitting nature of them. :) Just give yourself time to adjust and I think most folks will like them.

Out of the box, it ships as an OEM drive. So you just get the HD in a plastic casing and static bag. No cables or documentation. Which makes perfect sense as most DVR's are already going to provide power and SATA cables. All you'll need to do is screw it in with the provided screws and you're good to go. It also arrived unformatted, which is nice.The first thing to note is that not all hard drives are the same. They may have the same basic size and specs, but there's a lot more going on with the controller and internal components. Which is why larger servers and high-end workstations will frequently use much beefier hard drives that are meant to be more reliable and last longer.This new hard drive from Seagate appears to use a few terms commonly referenced on those drives, although it's clearly leaning closer to the consumer space than Enterprise. This drive is meant to be used in Surveillance DVR systems where it will run 24/7 and need to be accessed immediately for on-demand needs.Before installation, I did plug it into my custom workstation via the 6GB SATA port for some CrystalDIskMark benchmarks. It managed right about 160MB/s Sequential Read/Write and for the Random 4K tests, Read/Write were 0.58 / 1.44 MB/s. Sequential is what's mostly being used and is plenty fast for what it will be used for.I've installed it with my Q-See 8-Channel QC308 DVR unit. I chose this unit in particular unit since it ships without a drive and is meant for you to provide your own. As this is a standard 3.5" SATA drive, it installed and worked perfectly. It's been running for about a week, testing with scheduled and motion activated recording. So far, it's worked as well as you can expect.The long-term reliability claims are just one of those things you won't know for quite awhile. But I'll certainly update should anything change in the future. Even though this technically worked just as well as the old off-the-shelf 2TB drive that was previously in the DVR, it's still price reasonably and it's always nice to have some extra reliability features thrown in. Either way, for what it is, I consider it recommended!

This pillow has a rather dense and heavy feel to it. It's firmer than most memory foam pillows I've used in the past. But it's still soft enough to provide some give when pressure is applied. The "cool gel" blue pad you see in the pictures can barely be felt through the two layers of cloth as it comes out of the packaging. Add on your own pillow case and you'll likely forget about it a few seconds later.You do notice the cooling effect though. I have another ISO Cool pillow and found this one to last longer and doesn't get warm after a while. Most cooling pillows/sheets are only cool at first, then get warm once your body heat gets into the mix. But I found the gel to get the job done much better.The pillow does have a noticeable synthetic odor, which is noted on a card that ships with the pillow. It says to air out for 24 hours. I have a rather sensitive nose, and I could still notice the odor 2 weeks later. I'm hoping it goes away. Fortunately it's not repulsive or anything; I'd just rather not smell it.The real reason for 5 stars? The first night I used the pillow I slept better than I have all week. I don't like super soft pillows that go flat immediately. And I don't want to lay down on a rock. This pillow hits the perfect balance for optimal comfort while staying cool throughout the night. Although as usual, it's always up to your personal preferences.

I just like chewing gum, in general. Always been a fan. It tastes good and gives your teeth something to do in-between meals. My favorite is the one that has the shortest lasting flavor. Bubble mint. In fact, none of them really last a super long time. So I just grab a couple pieces and chew them all at the same time.Which is probably why I go through a 15 pack so quickly. I grab one of these variety packs and a separate 15 pack of bubble mint, since that goes the fastest. If the taste and activity isn't enough to justify the cost, it does help keep my teeth clean. And my Dentist always says to "keep doing what I'm doing." So it's time to order another box!

I think the title is enough to fully justify the 5 stars. But we've tried many different body washes and have always come back to this particular brand and scent. By "we," I mean I tried it, and my wife let me know if she liked the smell or not. And of course, I've grown rather accustom to the smell and even bought the matching deoterant.Unfortunately many local stores have stopped carrying this scent and have new ones which are just weird. Why would I want to smell like the jungle? Seriously. Why. Fortunately, trusty Amazon has been carrying the "fresh" body wash. Time to stock up and keep the wife happy!

Unfortunately, the less popular phones are left with limited options for cases. Especially if you need a holster case, as I do. I hate having anything in my pockets, especially a phone. More so given the fact that this is a 6" phone! I'd normally go with something like a Seidio case/holster, but this was all they had.You'll pretty much find this exact case under different brands. Sometimes they get good reviews, sometimes not so much. Which doesn't make sense since they are the same thing.You have a rubber case that slides onto the phone. It's rather loose, so don't expect to use this without the plastic bracket that attaches to the back of the case. This provides additional protection and helps keep it secure. It also adds noticeable bulk to the phone, which isn't ideal. Then you slide it into the belt holster. This part isn't as easy as it should be due to added friction. In particular when the exposed loose portion of the rubber covering gets caught on something.You also have a pop-out plastic stand for watching movies in landscape mode. This really doesn't work well at all. It's extremely difficult to open it with your fingers. I just pretend it's not there. Much easier.If you can find a better holster, go for it. Otherwise, this is probably going to be as good as it gets. :)

Too soft? I usually use Soft or Very Soft tooth brushes as my gums are a bit more sensitive to hard bristles. But after using this tooth brush for a few days, I really didn't like it. It left my gums with this odd sensation and left them a bit more sensitive than they usually are. It's hard to explain, but it's as though these fine bristles are simply too soft. And you don't feel as though you're really cleaning anything. I went back to my normal software tooth brushes.

Perfect OEM replacement for my Samsung Galaxy Note 3. After nearly a year of use, the battery was starting to show signs that it was time for replacement. It just wasn't lasting quite as long as it used to. This Samsung battery looked identical to the one it was replacing. I installed it, gave it a full charge, and I'm back to "like-new" performance.Just make sure you check the seller's reputation. Sometimes they'll sneak in there and sell knock-off products under the wrong product category. Which is usually where you run into negative reviews.

PROS:+ Light weight package+ Very portable & compact+ Nice 2-in-1 Tool+ Adjustable power settings+ Simple assembly+ Retractable cord*+ Flexible floor nozzle (i.e. "Turbo Floor Tool")CONS:- Bit pricey- Retractable cord can be finicky- Not ideal for thick carpet- Spinning bristles can't be turned off- Plastic connectors don't always want to cooperate- Noisy on hard surfaces with floor nozzleOUT OF THE BOX & SETUPAs there aren't very many parts, setup and assembly is fairly straight forward. You could read the manual, but you might just be more confused. It's one of the guides that tries to cram as many languages on the same page as possible. Pictures aren't much more help. The most awkward part that took a few extra seconds was the bag installation. It goes into a plastic bracket that has two tabs which slide into the back of the housing. Then the lid simply closes over it. It might be confusing if you didn't actually see it installed like this.The rest of the components all snap in simple enough. Although I did find that some required a bit more effort to get the plastic clips to actually align and snap into place properly. You'll need to do this rather often when you switch between the floor nozzle and 2-in-1 tool. Some just slide on and are held in place with friction. Others use the tab/lock mechanism which may or may not decide to cooperate.FEATURES & FUNCTIONALITYThere are apparently sightly different version of this unit as the one I received didn't have an actual handle when using the floor nozzle. You just grab onto a hard plastic piece towards the top of the hose. That also means the only way to power it on/off is by press the odd button on the base unit itself. There is a "power control" on the hose that simply opens allows air to escape.But the real "power control" is on the main unit itself. You can adjust a slider to increase and decrease the power of the motor itself. Which is actually somewhat handy when you just don't need this thing running at 100%. On the opposite side of the power button is another button that retracts the power cord. Speaking of which, this didn't always work perfectly. Sometimes it will pull the cord in at a fast speed (watch your fingers!) or require multiple presses to coax it back into the unit.You do have the removable exhaust filter (F83) and of course the disposable bag (Type R). There is also a light on the front to let you know when it's time to replace the bag. And that's about it for features.REAL WORLD USEWe have moderately thick carpet and found the floor nozzle had some difficulty managing to clean it. At the very least, it did require turning the power to maximum so the spinning brushes would keep up. Of course with this design, the spinning bristles are powered via the air suction. If they get caught up in thick carpet, or you end up applying too much pressure, they will sometimes just stop spinning.You also can't turn them off, so it's really no ideal for tile or hard wood surfaces. It will technically work, but the brushes usually end up throwing dirt all over the place. It also gets very loud when the floor nozzle is spinning at full speed. However, if there is one thing the floor nozzle is good at, that's getting into low and tight spaces. I can pretty much vacuum the entire underside of the king size bed. It's quite flexible!Although the most beneficial part to me is using the clever 2-in-1 tool, which is actually 3 tools in one. A tool for crevices, a brush for dusting, and a more tradition open nozzle for cleaning larger spaces. Using this mode you can usually turn down the power and get cleaning. The main vacuum will happily follow you along or since it's so light, just carry it along.CONCLUSION:While I really do appreciate it's compact and light weight features, I found it to be rather limited in versatility for my particular situation. If you don't have thick carpet and avoid hard surfaces, this vacuum should work perfectly. Although some may find it more efficient (i.e. cheaper) to just purchase a vacuum that already done most of those things out of the box.It almost feels like a companion to a larger full featured vacuum cleaner that might not be able to handle 100% of the floor cleaning. It's really not a bad vacuum cleaner, but it's probably better suited for small houses or apartments where the pros might outweigh the cons for your particular use. Otherwise I'd suggest looking for a different type of vacuum cleaner in general.

PROS:+ Really gets things clean+ Easy to setup+ Simple operation+ Detachable hose+ Provided solution smell nice (and cleans)CONS:- Very noisy- Expensive- Somewhat heavy- Can be cumbersome to operate for some- Drying on thick carpetOUT OF THE BOXYou've got what is basically a typically sized vacuum cleaner. Except this one is meant to compliment your existing cleaning arsenal and tackle the fun job of really getting in there and actually cleaning the carpet and tile-like surfaces. Assembly is fairly straight forward and was easy enough to manage without needing to dig into the manual.Some of the components that need to be removed and re-installed can be a bit stubborn to install. Such as the dirty water canister and even the hose attachment. It requires a bit of force and there isn't always much noise to indicate it's actually snapped into place. There is a squeegee attachment that's mean for hard surfaces that is the hardest to remove. But it needs to be secure, so that's understandable.SETUPBefore you begin, it's important that the surface is already clean. So make sure you've swept or vacuumed first. Fill the top cannister with water and the provided cleaning solution. Speaking of which, there are two 16 oz bottles, one for tile and one for carpet. It'll take about half of that before it's full. This isn't going to last very long, so plan on purchasing more.For example, with tile, we were able to clean the kitchen, dining, entry way, pantry, and a bathroom done before we ran out. Carpet area is comparable, but this all varies depending on the square footage.THE CLEANINGOnce the area is prepped and open, it's time to fire it up. First thing you'll notice is that this thing is LOUD. We have to move past that and start cleaning, however. There is a dial on the front you need to switch from Rise and Clean. You of course will start with Clean and squeeze the trigger on the handle to dispense the cleaning solution on the floor as you move in a forward and backwards motion. After releasing the trigger, you'll just let it suck up the water.Also note that during this time, there are multiple scrubbing brushes going to work at cleaning the surface. And it's loud. So you know it's working. Then you switch over to rise and repeat the process above. Except this time you'll want to go a little slow as you move back and forth to make sure it sucks up the water.Which I should add, it does quite well. Do note that there is a squeegee in use on hard surfaces. Once it starts to get dry in spots, there is much more added resistance. That's another sign that it's probably dry and time to move on to the next section. If for some reason it doesn't get dry, the dirty water canister is probably getting full. This dirty water is also nice indicator showing just how dirty everything was!As for carpet, you simply remove the squeegee and repeat the exact same process. Except you want to use the carpet cleaning solution. Both of which smell rather nice, by the way. Even with thick carpet, cleaning was a little easier than tile. Main issue is getting the carpet too wet, as the drying function doesn't work as well on our thick carpet. You have to press down on the unit to get it to really pull out the water in extra damp areas.Although the dark colored water in the unit proved how effective the cleaning action was. If you've used a steam cleaner, you know they are effective, but require a bit of work.CONCLUSION:The real issues arise in the actual cleaning of your hard surfaces and carpet. In that it actually requires a bit of work. You're moving a vacuum cleaning like thing over the same surface area multiple times. All while having more resistance than you're use with on carpet and on title when the squeegee hits some dry spots.For example, my wife got tired after a few minutes and was ready to move on to something else. Unfortunately this meant that I had to take over most of the cleaning. This alone basically cost it a star. :)  But seriously, it's not too difficult, you just need to follow the simple directions, take your time, and plan on a bit of work. After it's all done, you'll be happy with the clean looking and smelling results. And it's not something you'll get with a vacuum and mop!Just make sure you wear some ear plugs. Overall, I consider it recommended!

I have many flashlights, including a few Streamlights, and even the similar sized Streamlight 66118. Except the standard flash light uses normal batteries. What makes this one different? First, it has a "sleeve" towards the front that slides down to revel a micro-USB charging port. This feels solid and shouldn't allow dirt and such in there. The battery itself is a proprietary size Lithium-Ion battery pushing out 3.V, 660mAh, and 2.4Wh. Slightly concerning is the fact that the Cell and Assembly is from China. Only time will tell how long it holds up!Otherwise it is rated for 3.5 hours, which honestly, isn't the best I've seen. Putting in normal lithium-ion batteries my other streamlights would result in considerably longer run time (more than double). However, this does push out more lumens, and of course, easily rechargeable! I mean, who doesn't have AC and DC micro-USB chargers all over the place?Yes, it uses a standard micro-usb port and so far 3 phone chargers that I have laying around, including a 2A, work great. The included charger is 1A. There is also a nifty red/green LED to indicate when it's fully charged, or charging.Otherwise it's your typical durable and high quality streamlight with it's sealed rubber button at the back to power on/off. And that's about it. I do wish it lasted longer on a charge and the battery source is questionable, but I'm impressed enough to give it a solid 4.9 stars. :)

We've installed quite a few wall mounts for everything from a 32" to 65" LED TV. However, those were all the basic low-profile variety. I wanted an articulating wall mount for use in our game room. This looked like it fit the bill perfectly. Out of the box there is the mount, screws, HDMI cable, level, etc. All expected things.Everything appears to be of good quality and feels quite solid. I certainly have no issues trusting it to hold up a 39" LED Insignia TV. I simply followed the very well written instructions to mount by doing the basic measurements, marking the holes via stud finder, drill into the stud, and tighten down with a socket wrench by hand. They've even included a template for drilling the 3 holes.The TV attaches easily to the mount via the standard VESA bracket. It latches into place so you don't have to hold it while screwing things in. Once up there, just install the 2 screws for the VESA bracket you were asked to remove earlier, and it's installed.  Use the hand-adjustable screws at the top to get the angle you want. There is a nifty level attached to the back of the base to help keep it, well, level.Then route your cables with enough slack for future movement, and off you go. I was able to get it install by myself without any issues. For a heavier TV, additional help wouldn't hurt.Now it can get pushed back or tilted left, right, or angled up/down. Perfect for it's intended use. Which in my case, is mounted above my computer workstation that works as 4th screen, connected to the PC. I have a TV tuner that displays stuff on it. See attached photo.Given it's functionality and build quality, I consider this one highly recommended.

OUT OF THE BOXBelkin has been going with simple and straight forward packaging as of late, and this WeMo starter set continues that trend. You've got the two 800 lumen LED bulbs and the WeMo Link. There's a super basic quick start card and that's about it. The WeMo link simply plugs into an A/C outlet, preferably in a central location to allow the best communication with your other WeMo devices.The bulbs are standard A series and only look slightly different than a typical light bulb. Except these are of course, wireless! Let's see how they do.SETUPThis is the part that seems to be hit or miss and I can see why that is. They've really made it "simple" to setup, in that it's nearly entirely automated. You plug in the Link adapter, lights bulbs, turns on the light switch, and install the app on your Android or iOS device. Once you launch the app, it will guide you through the steps I noted above, as well as connecting to the WeMo link via WiFi for the initial setup.You do this so that you can tell the WeMo link to talk to your home WiFi network and is a one-time process. After that, you can simply switch back to your normal WiFi connection. The app then automatically starts searching for any devices. In my case, it initially only found 1 light bulb. After closing and restarting the app, it then found the other bulb and all was well.But that's really all it takes to set it up. And once you have it going, it's just a matter of playing with the software. We also installed the app on other Android devices that were on our WiFi network, and they immediately found the WeMo devices, ready to go!THE APPThe app is only available for iOS and Android. No PC or Windows Phone support, which is somewhat unfortunate as it does sort of limit it's full potential. I'm typing this review on a Dell XPS 15 ultrabook. If I wanted to turn the light on/off, I'd have to grab my phone. Or actually get out of my chair. That's simple unacceptable. :)But seriously, that support should be there out of the box. I hope it will be made available soon! Otherwise the app does give you the ability to name the lights, adjust brightness, turn on/off, sync with sunrise/sunset, or turn on/off are a predetermined time to give the impression you are actually home.From the time it takes to launch the app and allow it to "sync" with your bulbs, it usually takes about 4-5 seconds before I have full control. If the app is running, usually less than 1-2 seconds. No difference on WiFi or LTE with my Galaxy Note 3. Otherwise it's nearly immediate for the controls to respond to your commands.I also noticed that when first opening the app or when it's possibly still communicating with the lights, sometimes the drop-down menu for the individual lights glitches out a bit. It'll close right when opening, for example. Just minor bugs that need fixing.REAL WORLD USEI have one bulb in our dining room and one under lamp shade in the family room. I've got the family room light set to turn on/off on a schedule so it allows folks to navigate the open family room at night. Then it turns off before bed. The one in the dining room isn't on a timer, but I do frequently use the dimmer.This room is part of the living room where the TV is, so it's quite handy being able to dim while watching TV or turn it up if other activities are happening in this room. Speaking of turning up the brightness, I've found that when using the bulbs on their own, they do have a neutral to slightly warm color temp. Although when compared to a typical CFL or incandescent bulb, they will appear to be noticeably whiter. This is due to the fact that these bulbs have a color temp of 3000K and the CFL bulbs I use are no more than 2700k. Plus, the LED's do get brighter. Technically these LED's are on the warm side though.Back to normal usage, the biggest question was, "what if I just want to quickly turn a light on/off without an app-enabled device?" Simple. Just turn the light switch off and on again, and the bulb will default to it's brightness setting. You will of course need to jump back into an app to adjust brightness since it won't remember this when you manually use a normal household light switch.PROS:+ Relatively easy initial setup+ Fully functional iOS/Android Apps+ Bright 800 Lumen LED bulbs (60W equivalent)+ Only 9.5W per bulb+ Warmer color temp than most LED's (3000K)+ Works on WiFi or 3G/LTE (i.e. Remote)+ Nice "practical" features+ Light still turns on when switch used manually+ Lots of current and future WeMo compatible devicesCONS:- Expensive- Some bugs during initial setup- Not available for PC, Mac, Windows Phone, etc- Initial app connect delay should be improved- Bulb doesn't remember setting when manually turned off/on- Color temp may appear "cooler" compared to traditional bulbs- Indoor use only- Potentially Buggy- Support IssuesCONCLUSION:Of course this isn't something you can't live with out. But it's one of those nifty gadgets that can make things a little easier to live with. It's also new technology, so there are going to be a few bugs here and there. But considering how new it is, I think Belkin did a pretty darn good job at making this easy to use and provide some nice features.It's a bit pricey, but if you're looking to try out this new tech, this is an excellent way to jump in. For me? Next thing on the list: A soon-to-be released WeMo coffee maker. :)*** UPDATE 12/30/14 ***One of the light bulbs has decided to stop being detected wireless. It still turns on/off as a normal light bulb, but of course only one setting now. I've gone through all of the recommended full reset procedures for both the bulb and receiver. No go. One works, the other doesn't.Unfortunately I haven't had any luck contacting Belkin as I just keep getting automated surveys implying I'm out of the 90 day warranty. Still working on this, but until resolved, I'd recommend against purchase.

I've tried many energy drinks and additives over the years and have never been impressed. They tend to make me jittery and have a very unnatural effect. These results do vary of course as I know many don't experience those symptoms. For me, they just don't work. So when I saw a new more natural approach, I decided to give it a try.Recently I was feeling tired at the usual time of day. You know, about mid-day around 2-3 pm. Tried a can and I did notice I felt more alert, as I was earlier during the day. It didn't give me a big boost or jolt of energy as others do. But I did feel better, which is nice. Certainly better than going the other unhealthy routes to help get you through the day.The results still didn't last long, but were enough to get me through dinner time. I should also note that tropical blast did have a nice fruity taste and wasn't unpleasant at all. I could easily drink this all day long. I like it. Except for the fact that these little cans are quite pricey. And despite the small size of each can, they are "2 points" each, if you're on weight watchers.Overall, I consider these recommended to anybody looking for a more healthy energy boost during the day. Just be ware of the cost-per-can before you get too carried away.

Considering you can basically get the previous "30MB/s" card for about the same price as the new "48MB/s" card, it's pretty much a given to simply buy this updated card with faster read performance. I've used countless flash media over the years and have always come back to SanDisk for their reliability, performance, and value. This latest speedy card is no exception.But I never make assumptions, so I did run CrystalDiskMark Benchmark on the new version to see how it did. With a 45.92MB/s Read and 14.44 MB/s Write (Sequential), it did not disappoint. Your results will likely vary depending on the system you are using, but that's basically right about what can expect from this class card. I'm on a Dell XPS 15 running Win 8.1.BENCHMARK: READ / WRITE (in MB/s)Sequential: 45.92 / 14.44Random 512K: 41.82 / 0.637Random 4K: 4.251 / 1.421Random 4K QD 32: 3.536 / 1.438Basically it's going to be perfect for most uses in phones, tablets, and other portable devices where sequential speeds are most relevant for media storage. The only exception being something that needs a very high write speed, such as 4K video and high-end SLR cameras. In which case, you'll be looking at a much more expensive card.For typical everyday tasks, I'll take the nice "free" bump in read speeds and consider this card highly recommended.

PROS:+ Very compact design & foot print+ Fast printing speeds+ Nice photo print quality+ 6 Separate Ink Cartridges+ Great touch screen and interface+ Easy Setup Process+ Automatic paper output tray+ Software is basic, but functional+ 2-Sided Printing (with thicker paper)CONS:- Limited paper storage- Flimsy touch panel assembly- Cheap plastic CD Tray- Android and PC Software need improvements- Bit expensiveMy first impression was simply how compact the box was, let alone the printer itself. It's rare I can actually carry a printer box with one hand. So we've got a compact high-end ink-jet printer that promises to provide a lot of features. Now it's time to see how it worked out in my hands.OUT OF THE BOXUn-boxing goes just about as you'd expect with a new printer. Lots and lots of tape / wrapping to keep everything in place during shipment. You've also got a power cable, quick start guide and driver CD in the box; and that's it. No USB or network cables included; although if you have Wi-Fi, they aren't technically needed. Just plug it in and off you go with setup.You'll also immediately note that there are in fact 6 different colored ink cartridges. Be sure to shop around for prices as these can get expensive if you plan on ordering them all. On the plus side, you only need to replace the colors that happen to be low. In either case, they are quite easy to install.DESIGNBefore we start setup, let's look at the printer. As initially noted, the printer is super compact. I'm surprised they fit all of these features into such a small package. You do sacrifice paper storage and such. But for most home and home offices who aren't printing 100 pages a day, that's all you need. Not to mention, you wouldn't be buying an ink-jet!The printer has a nifty LCD screen that automatically rotates outward when you power it on. Then closes again, at power off. The LCD and it's user friendly interface as a nice touch. Which can also be taken literally as it's also a touch screen. One that happens to be fast and intuitive to navigate. A slight negative here is that the touch panel assembly wobbles a bit when you push it, in particular in the closed position. More noticeable as the power button is on the same panel.The output tray even automatically extends when you print to catch the print-outs. A button on the touch panel allows you to easily open and close at will. Nice. Not so nice? The CD "tray" is a cheap piece of plastic that slides in at the bottom of the printer.SETUPFirst step, toss the CD, and go to epson's website to download the Driver and Software suite. It's going to be more up-to-date. Then run the file and follow the steps. I decided to do this via Wi-Fi as I suspect that's how many folks will tackle this step. You can also setup via LAN and USB cable, if you choose to do so. Even though as previously noted, those cables aren't included.During setup, it will try to attach to the printer with your notebooks wireless card. So yes, you will need a computer with wireless capability if you choose to go this route. Alternatively, you could manually setup via the printer's touch panel. Unless some older printers, this is nowhere near as painful as it used to be. But I'd still stick with the software to save a few steps.In my case, the software failed to connect automatically on the first try on my Windows 7 notebook. I instructed me to kick off a few steps on the printer itself to get it ready to go, and then off it went. Software installed and ready to go. I did note that on both test systems, one with Windows 7 and the other with Windows 8, the firmware update failed (software crashed). Simply reboot and run the Software Updater program separately. Fairly easy to do as it's all automated.At this point you've got the printer attached to your Wi-Fi network, drivers, and software installed ready to go!PRINTING (ANDROID)I first decided to try printing from my Galaxy Note 3 phone and Galaxy Note Pro 12.2 tablet. I simply installed the Epson "iPrint" application from the Play Store, allowed it to find the printer, and it's ready to go. The application itself is rather primitive, but does show the printer's status, ink levels, and other basic info. However, it is limited in functionality.It's only a print application, not a service.
